question_en: Why did we decide that certain words were "bad" and shouldn't be used in social settings?
pos_context_title_en: The Science of Swearing (www.psychologicalscience.org)
All Of These Words Are Offensive (But Only Sometimes) (www.dictionary.com)
All Of These Words Are Offensive (But Only Sometimes) (www.dictionary.com)
pos_context_en: Courts presume harm from speech in cases involving discrimination or sexual harassment. The original justification for our obscenity laws was predicated on an unfounded assumption that speech can deprave or corrupt children, but there is little (if any) social-science data demonstrating that a word in and of itself causes harm. A closely related problem is the manner in which harm has been defined — harm is most commonly framed in terms of standards and sensibilities such as religious values or sexual mores. Rarely are there attempts to quantify harm in terms of objectively measurable symptoms (e.g., sleep disorder, anxiety).

So, where’s the problem?Ape and monkey are considered offensive terms when they’re used to describe a person of color. It’s what is known as dehumanizing language, “language that deprives a person of human qualities or attributes.”


Exactly when the words became slurs is unknown, but offensive comparisons of black people to apes date back hundreds of centuries. As recently as the late 1800s, for example, when scientists Josiah C. Nott and George R. Gliddon created the 1854 Types of Mankind (then the leading scientific text on race), they compared black people not to other (white) people but to chimpanzees, gorillas, and orangutans.


When used in these contexts, monkey and ape are considered extremely derogatory slang.

The word savage has taken a circuitous path through the lexicon over the years, first showing up in English in the 1200s from Middle English. As an adjective, it’s typically meant “fierce, ferocious, or cruel; uncivilized; barbarous.” When referring to a savage lion ripping an antelope apart on the African Sahara, that’s all well and good.


But, the use of savage as a noun to describe human beings dates back to approximately the 1400s. At a time when Christopher Columbus was enslaving Native Americans and claiming their lands and work for his own, the word became a slur used by white Europeans to describe Native American people. The usage stuck around for hundreds of years, and it’s still a word that many indigenous peoples around the world find offensive.
report_en: Societies label certain words as “bad” when they are believed to inflict harm on listeners [1]. Courts, for instance, presume that slurs or sexual comments create actionable injury in discrimination and harassment cases [1]. The impulse traces back to obscenity laws grounded in the nineteenth-century idea that mere words could “deprave or corrupt” children [1]. What counts as harm is usually set by dominant moral or religious norms rather than by objective symptoms [1]. Beyond generalized offense, particular terms become taboo because they function as tools of dehumanization; calling a person of color an “ape” or “monkey” linguistically strips them of human qualities [2]. These comparisons date back centuries and were legitimized by pseudo-scientific racism in the 1800s, giving the words an entrenched derogatory meaning [2]. Likewise, Europeans applied “savage” to Native Americans for hundreds of years, weaving colonial violence into the term’s connotation [3]. Once speech is tied to moral panic, legal sanction, or historical oppression, communities avoid it in polite settings to signal respect and prevent repeating social or psychological injury [1].

question_en: Why is it sometimes hard to eat after not eating for a while?
pos_context_title_en: Where did my Appetite Go? | Paleo Leap (paleoleap.com)
Where did my Appetite Go? | Paleo Leap (paleoleap.com)
Why Does Hunger Vanish When You Ignore It Long Enough? (www.livescience.com)
pos_context_en:
A loss of appetite isn’t necessarily bad. It might just be your body running smoothly off its stored fat reserves while in ketosis, or a temporary situation like a course of antibiotics.


On the other hand, there are some situations where appetite loss signifies a serious problem. There are plenty of times when it’s healthy to eat even though you have no appetite – for example, if you’re recovering from a starvation diet that put your body in survival mode.


It’s worth seeing a doctor about sudden loss of appetite – not because there’s necessarily anything amiss, but just to check in. On the other hand, sometimes there really is nothing going wrong: you’ve hit the weight-loss jackpot and your body is burning stored fat reserves for energy without feelings of hunger. Congratulations! In this case, just relax and check back when you’ve lost as much weight as you wanted to, or when your appetite naturally decides to return.

Chronic stress can also depress appetite very effectively. Fight-or-flight mode means elevated stress hormones, and one side effect of this is a depressed appetite. Your body is trying to help you survive by eliminating all distractions: if you’re running away from a tiger, the last thing you need to be worrying about is what you’re making for dinner.


Traumatic life events like the death of a family member, or even the long-term misery of a horrible job, can keep you in this appetite-suppressed state of chronic stress. And it’s very important to note that chronic starvation diets can also stress your body in exactly this same way. At a certain point, a starving person stops being hungry and starts feeling “buzzed” and full of energy. The person is still starving; their body is just trying to help them get up and find more food before they die of malnutrition.


In this case, the solution is simple, but unpleasant: eat anyway. You still need food; you just don’t realize it. Starving your body will not help you get past this tough time in your life.

In other words, when people fasted, their levels of ghrelin increased. But for unknown reasons, these people didn't report feeling hungrier than usual.


"It's interesting because the subjective "How hungry are you?" doesn't really match up with what we measure clinically," Colleen Tewksbury, a bariatric program manager at Penn Medicine, who was not involved with the review or the study, told Live Science.


So, why is it that people can basically ignore their hunger pangs? One idea, based on anecdotal observations, is that intense activities can distract people from their hunger, said Leah Groppo, a clinical dietician at Stanford Health Care in Palo Alto, California.


"If you're really distracted, oftentimes people are able to lose that sense of hunger," Groppo told Live Science. "Then, over time it [the feelings of hunger] will diminish because you're still hyper-focused on something else."


However, if you're surrounded by enough cues to remind you of your hunger — say, you're reading a novel but you're by the kitchen, and the smell of dinner is wafting through the air — then you'll likely remember how hungry you are.
report_en: After an extended fast, several physiological and psychological mechanisms can mute hunger signals, so picking up food again feels difficult. While fasting, the body often shifts into ketosis and efficiently runs on stored fat, meaning the usual hormonal prompts to eat never reach a level you consciously notice [1]. Prolonged stress—whether from a traumatic event or from the stress of dieting itself—elevates fight-or-flight hormones that deliberately suppress appetite, and this blunted signal can linger even after the stressor is gone [2]. Finally, studies show the hunger hormone ghrelin continues to rise during fasting, yet people frequently report no extra hunger because sustained distraction teaches the brain to ignore the cue, causing the conscious sensation of hunger to fade even as the physiological need remains [3].

While fasting, the body often shifts into ketosis and efficiently runs on stored fat, meaning the usual hormonal prompts to eat never reach a level you consciously notice [1].

Prolonged stress—whether from a traumatic event or from the stress of dieting itself—elevates fight-or-flight hormones that deliberately suppress appetite, and this blunted signal can linger even after the stressor is gone [2].

Finally, studies show the hunger hormone ghrelin continues to rise during fasting, yet people frequently report no extra hunger because sustained distraction teaches the brain to ignore the cue, causing the conscious sensation of hunger to fade even as the physiological need remains [3].

question_en: Why is the Tar Baby from "Song of the South" racist?  Why, exactly, is the movie in general considered racist?
pos_context_title_en: Just How Racist Is Disney’s ‘Song of the South’? (screencrush.com)
Tar-Baby (en.wikipedia.org)
Why Disney's CEO Says That Disney's Forgotten Movie "Song of the South" Wouldn't "Sit Right" With Disney+ Viewers (wearemitu.com)
Why Disney's CEO Says That Disney's Forgotten Movie "Song of the South" Wouldn't "Sit Right" With Disney+ Viewers (wearemitu.com)
pos_context_en: (One of the animated shorts — the one that gets recounted in the animatronic portions of Splash Mountain, in fact — involves Br’er Rabbit getting stuck in a “tar-baby.” While the cartoon itself isn’t necessarily about race, the use of that term as an insult towards African Americans is yet another strike against the film.

The Tar-Baby is the second of the Uncle Remus stories published in 1881; it is about a doll made of tar and turpentine used by the villainous Br'er Fox to entrap Br'er Rabbit. The more that Br'er Rabbit fights the Tar-Baby, the more entangled he becomes.

“Song of the South” revolves around the character of Johnny, a seven-year-old boy living in the Reconstruction-era South (the 1860s and 1870s). While visiting his grandmother’s plantation during a moment of familial strife, Johnny befriends a former slave named Uncle Remus who now works on the plantation.

The relationship between Uncle Remus and his white employers is a problematic picture of a subservient, docile old black man who is happy to live and work on the plantation in which he was formerly enslaved.
report_en: The Tar-Baby sequence is condemned because the term “tar-baby” has long been wielded as a racial slur against African-Americans, so its cheerful use in a children’s cartoon normalizes a derogatory insult and embeds racist language in popular culture [1]. Beyond that scene, Song of the South idealizes its 1860s–1870s Reconstruction-era plantation, depicting it as a pleasant refuge where a white boy visits and befriends Uncle Remus, a formerly enslaved man who still lives and works on the estate [3]. Remus himself is portrayed as the archetypal “docile, subservient” Black caretaker who seems content in servitude, perpetuating the “happy slave” stereotype and masking the brutality of slavery and post-war oppression [4]. By combining racist terminology with a romanticized view of plantation life and a caricatured Black protagonist, the film diminishes historical realities and reinforces white-supremacist myths, which is why both the Tar-Baby scene and the movie as a whole are widely labeled racist.
all_claims: The Tar-Baby sequence is condemned because the term “tar-baby” has long been wielded as a racial slur against African-Americans, so its cheerful use in a children’s cartoon normalizes a derogatory insult and embeds racist language in popular culture [1].

Beyond that scene, Song of the South idealizes its 1860s–1870s Reconstruction-era plantation, depicting it as a pleasant refuge where a white boy visits and befriends Uncle Remus, a formerly enslaved man who still lives and works on the estate [3].

Remus himself is portrayed as the archetypal “docile, subservient” Black caretaker who seems content in servitude, perpetuating the “happy slave” stereotype and masking the brutality of slavery and post-war oppression [4].

By combining racist terminology with a romanticized view of plantation life and a caricatured Black protagonist, the film diminishes historical realities and reinforces white-supremacist myths, which is why both the Tar-Baby scene and the movie as a whole are widely labeled racist.

question_en: - Why does Eminem give so much praise to Dr Dre? He talks about him like a father in his music.
pos_context_title_en: The truth about Dr. Dre and Eminem's relationship (www.nickiswift.com)
Details you need to know about Dr. Dre's relationship with Eminem (www.grunge.com)
Dr. Dre (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en: While rapper Dr. Dre was already established as a hip-hop legend long before his mentee, Eminem, released his star-making EP Slim Shady in 1997, it was his subsequent mentorship of the then-up-and-coming performer that, in part, cemented his reputation not only as an artist, but as a kingmaking producer. Dre took the younger rapper under his wing, collaborating with his protégé on best-selling albums such as The Marshall Mathers LP and The Eminem Show, as well as the 2001 hit single "Forgot About Dre." And while the realm of hip-hop is well-known for it's myriad feuds, the connection between Eminem and Dre has seemingly stood the test of time.

Eminem was reportedly star-struck when he first met Dr. Dre. "I'm looking at Dre like, 'Dude, I see you on TV all the time — you're one of my biggest influences ever in life," he said, according to Billboard. And it didn't take long for them to get to work. The Things noted that Eminem directly went into the hook that would make him famous on his first single "My Name Is," and Dr. Dre was convinced. They immediately went into the studio and laid down that song and "Guilty Conscience" by the end of the day.

The turning point for Aftermath came in 1998, when Jimmy Iovine, the head of Aftermath's parent label Interscope, suggested that Dr. Dre sign Eminem, a white rapper from Detroit. Dre produced three songs and provided vocals for two on Eminem's successful and controversial debut album The Slim Shady LP, released in 1999.[28] The Dr. Dre-produced lead single from that album, "My Name Is", brought Eminem to public attention for the first time, and the success of The Slim Shady LP – it reached number two on the Billboard 200 and received general acclaim from critics – revived the label's commercial ambitions and viability.[28][29][30]
report_en: Eminem speaks of Dr. Dre with near-paternal reverence because Dre quite literally discovered, mentored, and bankrolled his career: after Jimmy Iovine suggested the signing, Dre produced three tracks and lent vocals to two on Eminem’s 1999 debut The Slim Shady LP, whose lead single “My Name Is” introduced Eminem to the world and helped the album reach No. 2 on the Billboard 200, reviving Aftermath’s fortunes in the process [3]; their very first meeting ended with Dre cutting both “My Name Is” and “Guilty Conscience,” convincing the newcomer he had found a champion [2]. Dre then “took the younger rapper under his wing,” co-creating blockbuster follow-ups like The Marshall Mathers LP, The Eminem Show, and the Grammy-winning single “Forgot About Dre,” solidifying Eminem’s superstardom [1]. Because Dre transformed him from an unknown Detroit battle rapper into a global icon, Eminem understandably praises him as a guiding, almost father-like figure.

question_en: How much money is needed in order to not have to work for the rest of your life?
pos_context_title_en: How Much Money Do You Need To Never Have To Work Again? Let's Do The Math. | The Kickass Entrepreneur (www.thekickassentrepreneur.com)
How Much Money Do You Need To Never Have To Work Again? Let's Do The Math. | The Kickass Entrepreneur (www.thekickassentrepreneur.com)
How Much Money Do You Need To Never Have To Work Again? Let's Do The Math. | The Kickass Entrepreneur (www.thekickassentrepreneur.com)
How Much Money –Exactly– To Never Work Again? (www.twopluscrew.com)
pos_context_en: For real SWAN-like “never have to work again” thinking, you need to have a portfolio large enough to kick off a stream of dividend income so that you don’t have to touch the capital. And then, considering inflation, your portfolio needs to grow by at least the nominal level of inflation per year, because $100,000 in today’s income isn’t the same as $100,000 in tomorrow’s income.

My estimate is only an approximation, which will vary from person to person. But the SWAN never-have-to-worry-about-money-again formulas are as follows:


* SWAN Wealth Number Level 1 = Current Yearly Spend × 28 (quite comfortable)
* SWAN Wealth Number Level 2 = Current Yearly Spend × 32 (very comfortable)
* SWAN Wealth Number Level 3 = Current Yearly Spend × 36 (completely comfortable)

So there you go. Your number to sleep well at night, never have to worry about money, is somewhere in the range of 28 to 36 times your yearly spend, and of course, the higher the multiple, the more secure you’ll feel, and the less stock market risk you’ll have to take. Anything above 40 and you’re feeling very comfortable.


And the question of whether $1 million is enough to retire on? If your yearly spend is $30,000, then, yes, $1 million is probably fine. If your yearly spend is more than $30,000, then you’re probably going to be tight, you might have to take more stock market risk, and in turn, not sleep quite as well at night!

The answer is $1,475,000, for the average US household.


How?


At the time of this writing, the median US household income is ~$59,000. Discounting households with poor debt or spending management, this means withdrawing 4% (aka a "safe withdrawal rate") annually on a $1,475,000 diversified investment (an index fund) should usually provide said households with the $59,000 of income they're already receiving. This is how much money the average household would need invested at a nominal rate of return (usually given as 10%) in order to (1) provide for the household expenses, (2) be able to suffer a few years of bad markets, and (3) be at parity with inflation. All this without ever having to change their lifestyle.
report_en: Financial planners generally estimate that you need a portfolio large enough to cover your annual expenses without touching the principal, while still growing at least with inflation [1]. A pragmatic rule is the SWAN (“sleep well at night”) wealth number of 28–36 times your current yearly spend, where 28× is “quite comfortable,” 32× “very comfortable,” and 36× “completely comfortable” [2]. Using that range, someone spending $40,000 a year would aim for roughly $1.1–$1.4 million, while a $100,000 spender would target $2.8–$3.6 million [2]. Anything above 40× annual expenses is viewed as very secure and reduces market-risk anxiety [3]. For the median U.S. household that lives on about $59,000, applying the common 4 % safe-withdrawal rate implies needing around $1.475 million in diversified investments to replicate that income indefinitely without working [4]. In short, you can quit work forever when you have roughly 28-40 years’ worth of living expenses invested, translating to about $1.5 million for the average household, with the exact figure scaling directly with your personal spending.

question_en: Why does reddit give up loading pages without even trying?
pos_context_title_en: Reddit not working, Mobile App problems (www.product-reviews.net)
Reddit not working, Mobile App problems (www.product-reviews.net)
pos_context_en: Reddit’s website online via desktop almost never goes down for long periods of time, but lately some of you may be having problems with the Reddit mobile app on iOS and Android not working. It appears to be running separately compared to the desktop version on two different servers so one could be working, the other completely down.

The majority of Reddit outages are due to small glitches that see Reddit down for only a couple of minutes, as such it’s very unlikely to be due to maintenance and more likely some sort of server restart. If their operations run with zero downtime for router management, then you can put short lived problems down to glitches and high demand.
report_en: Reddit typically “gives up” on loading a page when the request is routed to a mobile-app server that is temporarily unavailable; because the mobile and desktop versions run on separate servers, the desktop site can stay up while the mobile endpoint returns an error almost instantly, making it look as if no loading attempt was made [1]. Most of these outages last only a few minutes because they stem from small glitches or automated server restarts, not planned maintenance, so the service disappears long enough for your app or browser to time-out before any content is fetched [2]. High demand can exacerbate this, briefly overwhelming routers until they reset, which produces the sudden “fail to load” symptom [2].

Most of these outages last only a few minutes because they stem from small glitches or automated server restarts, not planned maintenance, so the service disappears long enough for your app or browser to time-out before any content is fetched [2].
High demand can exacerbate this, briefly overwhelming routers until they reset, which produces the sudden “fail to load” symptom [2].

pos_context_title_en: Is It Safe to Use Q-tips in the Ear? Facts and Tips (www.healthline.com)
Is It Safe to Use Q-tips in the Ear? Facts and Tips (www.healthline.com)
Is It Safe to Use Q-tips in the Ear? Facts and Tips (www.healthline.com)
​Why It Feels So Damn Good to Stick a Q-Tip In Your Ear (www.menshealth.com)
​Why It Feels So Damn Good to Stick a Q-Tip In Your Ear (www.menshealth.com)
​Why It Feels So Damn Good to Stick a Q-Tip In Your Ear (www.menshealth.com)
pos_context_en:
However, while it’s safe to clean the outside of your ear with a cotton swab, it’s best to avoid using them inside your ear.


Using cotton swabs inside your ear is associated with a variety of complications, including injury and infection.
Earwax is actually helpful to your ears. It keeps them from getting too dry, traps dirt, and prevents bacteria from reaching deeper into your ear

Using a cotton swab to try to clear earwax from your ear can actually push the earwax deeper in. This can prevent earwax from naturally clearing and cause it to build up inside your ear.


The accumulation of too much earwax can lead to unpleasant symptoms. These can include things like:


* pain
* a feeling of fullness in the ear
* muffled hearing
Shoving the Q-tip inside can also potentially rupture your eardrum or scratch the skin of ear canal, which could lead to bleeding or infectio
The Vagus nerve—a branchlike structure that runs from your brain to your butt—can be stimulated via the ear
Your ear is also an area that you’re normally not used to getting touched
report_en: Digging in with a cotton swab stimulates thousands of sensitive nerve endings in the ear canal, an area “you’re normally not used to getting touched,” which the brain interprets as intensely pleasant scratching an itch you didn’t know you had [6]. Part of that thrill comes from the vagus nerve, a long nerve that has a branch in the ear; rubbing it can trigger a parasympathetic reflex that slows the heart rate, relaxes you, and can momentarily open the Eustachian tube, making your ears and even your sinuses feel clearer [5]. However, the swab also tends to push wax deeper, trapping dirt and bacteria and eventually causing pain, fullness, or muffled hearing as the buildup grows [3]. Worse, the stick can scratch the canal or even perforate the eardrum, leading to bleeding or infection [4]. So while the sensation is real, the risks outweigh the fleeting relief, and experts advise limiting swabs to the outer ear only [1].

So while the sensation is real, the risks outweigh the fleeting relief, and experts advise limiting swabs to the outer ear only [1].

question_en: How do contact lens stay on your iris? What stops them from moving all over your eye?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do My Contacts Keep Popping Out of My Eyes? (www.self.com)
Why do my contact lenses keep shifting out of place? (www.aao.org)
pos_context_en: In addition to keeping your eyes all lubed up, your tear film helps your contacts stay where they should, remain hydrated, and feel comfortable, Dr. Shibayama says.

Contacts that correct astigmatism float on the tear film on the surface of your eye and should stay in a reasonably centered position during normal wear. It sounds like your contact has an internal curve that is too flat compared to the curve of the front of your eye, causing it to rotate on the tear film too easily.
report_en: Contact lenses do not actually stick to the iris; instead they ride on a very thin layer of tears covering the cornea [2]. This tear film acts like an aqueous cushion and creates gentle capillary forces that let the lens stay hydrated and anchored in one spot [1]. A properly fitted lens has a base curve that closely matches the curvature of your cornea, so when it floats on this tear layer it naturally centers itself over the pupil; if the inner curve is too flat or steep the lens can rotate or slide because the match-up is loose, illustrating why good fitting measurements are critical [2]. Normal blinking also helps recentralize a lens that drifts slightly, while the eyelids’ pressure and the lens’s thin edges limit how far it can travel, so under everyday conditions a well-fitted, hydrated lens stays aligned instead of roaming around your eye.

This tear film acts like an aqueous cushion and creates gentle capillary forces that let the lens stay hydrated and anchored in one spot [1].

A properly fitted lens has a base curve that closely matches the curvature of your cornea, so when it floats on this tear layer it naturally centers itself over the pupil; if the inner curve is too flat or steep the lens can rotate or slide because the match-up is loose, illustrating why good fitting measurements are critical [2].

Normal blinking also helps recentralize a lens that drifts slightly, while the eyelids’ pressure and the lens’s thin edges limit how far it can travel, so under everyday conditions a well-fitted, hydrated lens stays aligned instead of roaming around your eye.

question_en: All these stories about the "fake snow" being passed around within the past week or so... what is REALLY going on here?
pos_context_title_en: Fact check: Explaining ‘fake Texas snow’ posts and ‘scorched snow’ videos (www.reuters.com)
Fact check: Explaining ‘fake Texas snow’ posts and ‘scorched snow’ videos (www.reuters.com)
Conspiracy Theorists Are Burning Snow to Prove It's Fake (www.popularmechanics.com)
Sublimation and the Water Cycle (www.usgs.gov)
pos_context_en:
Plait explained that the snow does melt, but it doesn’t appear to drip because the remaining snow, which is porous, absorbs the water.


Most iterations also point out that the purported fake snow “burns”, because the lighter leaves a “scorch” mark on the snowballs.
Butane, found in the lighters, is a hydrocarbon - a molecule which is part carbon and part hydrogen.

* This isn’t a conspiracy theory. It’s just a common scientific process called sublimation.
* The “triple point” is where all three phases of a substance can all exist.
Sublimation is the conversion between the solid and the gaseous phases of matter, with no intermediate liquid stage.
report_en: The “fake Texas snow” videos exploit normal physics: when a flame is held to a snowball, the surface may darken and appear to “burn” because the lighter’s butane flame deposits carbon-rich soot on the snow rather than igniting it [2]; meanwhile the snow itself melts, but the meltwater is quickly wicked into the porous structure of the remaining snow, so viewers don’t see liquid dripping and assume no melting occurred [1]. Additionally, some of the exposed snow can bypass the liquid phase altogether and turn directly into water vapor—a well-known process called sublimation, which is common when solid water is heated below its melting point or under low humidity, reinforcing the illusion that the snow is “disappearing” instead of melting [4]. In short, basic combustion by-products and water-cycle physics, not manufactured snow, explain the viral clips.
all_claims: The “fake Texas snow” videos exploit normal physics: when a flame is held to a snowball, the surface may darken and appear to “burn” because the lighter’s butane flame deposits carbon-rich soot on the snow rather than igniting it [2]; meanwhile the snow itself melts, but the meltwater is quickly wicked into the porous structure of the remaining snow, so viewers don’t see liquid dripping and assume no melting occurred [1].

Additionally, some of the exposed snow can bypass the liquid phase altogether and turn directly into water vapor—a well-known process called sublimation, which is common when solid water is heated below its melting point or under low humidity, reinforcing the illusion that the snow is “disappearing” instead of melting [4].
In short, basic combustion by-products and water-cycle physics, not manufactured snow, explain the viral clips.

question_en: Serious question: Because of the international aspects of ACTA, is our country legally obligated to pass bills like SOPA and PIPA? (x/post from r/politics to try to get an answer)
pos_context_title_en: Stop Online Piracy Act (en.wikipedia.org)
PROTECT IP Act (en.wikipedia.org)
What Is ACTA And Why Is It A Problem? (www.techdirt.com)
What Is ACTA And Why Is It A Problem? (www.techdirt.com)
Treaties as Law of the Land (www.law.cornell.edu)
Authority to Suspend, Terminate, or Withdraw from Treaties - The ALI Adviser (thealiadviser.org)
pos_context_en: The Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA) was a controversial United States bill introduced by U.S. Representative Lamar S. Smith (R-TX) to expand the ability of U.S. law enforcement to combat online copyright infringement and online trafficking in counterfeit goods.

The PROTECT IP Act is a re-write of the Combating Online Infringement and Counterfeits Act (COICA),[5] which failed to pass in 2010. A similar House version of the bill, the Stop Online Piracy Act (SOPA), was introduced on October 26, 2011.

Beyond just locking in parts of copyright law, ACTA also expands it. First, it takes things that would normally be considered non-commercial file sharing (which is potentially against the law), and turns it into commercial scale criminal infringement. Similarly, it appears to broaden the definitions around inducement/secondary liability to make what had been a civil (between two private parties) issue into criminal aiding and abetting.

The reality, however, is that to be in compliance with this agreement, the US needs to retain certain parts of copyright law that many reformers believe should be changed. At the very least, it ties Congress' hands, if we want to be in compliance with our "international obligations."

In short, the treaty commitments of the United States do not diminish Congress’s constitutional powers. To be sure, legislative repeal of a treaty as law of the land may amount to its violation as an international contract.

(1) According to established practice, the President has the authority to act on behalf of the United States in suspending or terminating U.S. treaty commitments and in withdrawing the United States from treaties, either on the basis of terms in the treaty allowing for such action (such as a withdrawal clause) or on the basis of international law that would justify such action.


(2) International law determines the extent to which acts by the United States to suspend, terminate, or withdraw from a treaty will be effective in altering U.S. obligations under the treaty.
report_en: No. While ACTA pressures the United States to keep robust copyright rules, it does not legally compel Congress to enact any particular bill such as SOPA or PIPA. ACTA “ties Congress’ hands” only in the sense that, if the U.S. chooses to remain compliant, certain existing provisions must be preserved, making some reform harder but not mandating new statutes [4]. Crucially, treaties “do not diminish Congress’s constitutional powers,” and Congress can refuse to pass or can repeal legislation even if that technically places the U.S. in breach of an agreement [5]. In addition, the President can unilaterally suspend, terminate, or withdraw the country from a treaty, which would remove any associated obligations before fresh laws became necessary [6]. Thus, ACTA may create diplomatic incentives, but there is no legal requirement to pass SOPA, PIPA, or similar bills; Congress retains full discretion over U.S. copyright legislation.
all_claims: No.
While ACTA pressures the United States to keep robust copyright rules, it does not legally compel Congress to enact any particular bill such as SOPA or PIPA.
ACTA “ties Congress’ hands” only in the sense that, if the U.S.
chooses to remain compliant, certain existing provisions must be preserved, making some reform harder but not mandating new statutes [4].
Crucially, treaties “do not diminish Congress’s constitutional powers,” and Congress can refuse to pass or can repeal legislation even if that technically places the U.S.
in breach of an agreement [5].
In addition, the President can unilaterally suspend, terminate, or withdraw the country from a treaty, which would remove any associated obligations before fresh laws became necessary [6].
Thus, ACTA may create diplomatic incentives, but there is no legal requirement to pass SOPA, PIPA, or similar bills; Congress retains full discretion over U.S.
copyright legislation.

in breach of an agreement [5].

question_en: Explain: The Fall of the Mayan Civilization
pos_context_title_en: The Fall of the Maya: 'They Did it to Themselves' (science.nasa.gov)
BBC - History - Ancient History in depth: The Fall of the Mayan Civilisation (www.bbc.co.uk)
BBC - History - Ancient History in depth: The Fall of the Mayan Civilisation (www.bbc.co.uk)
Classic Maya collapse (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
"The Maya are often depicted as people who lived in complete harmony with their environment,' says PhD student Robert Griffin. "But like many other cultures before and after them, they ended up deforesting and destroying their landscape in efforts to eke out a living in hard times."


A major drought occurred about the time the Maya began to disappear. And at the time of their collapse, the Maya had cut down most of the trees across large swaths of the land to clear fields for growing corn to feed their burgeoning population. They also cut trees for firewood and for making building materials.

For decades, archaeologists have been searching for an explanation of the Maya collapse. Many theories have been put forward, ranging from warfare and invasion to migration, disease and over-farming. Many think the truth may lie with a combination of these and other factors.

Here at last was the clinching evidence Gill had been searching for - exceptional drought at the time of the Maya collapse. His quest was over, but it had been an emotional journey of discovery.


'There's a certain satisfaction that I have finally understood what happened to the Maya, but as a human being it's awful to think about what happened', he says.

The authors suggest that modest rainfall reductions, amounting to only 25 to 40 percent of annual rainfall, may have been the tipping point to the Maya collapse.[27][28] Although this analysis referred to the estimated decrease in rainfall as "modest", subsequent studies suggest that the same data could represent a 20 to 65 percent decrease in rainfall.[29]
report_en: Climatic research shows that the Classic Maya decline coincided with “exceptional drought” across the region, indicating severe environmental stress at the moment of collapse [3]. Sediment‐based reconstructions suggest annual rainfall dropped by roughly 25–40%, and possibly as much as 20–65%, a reduction large enough to cripple water reserves and maize harvests [4]. In response, the Maya intensified land use, cutting most trees across vast areas for cornfields, firewood and building materials, thereby deforesting and degrading their landscape [1]. This widespread clearing removed moisture-recycling forests, further lowering local rainfall and undermining food production for their growing population [1]. Beyond ecology, archaeologists cite additional pressures—warfare, invasion, migration, disease and chronic over-farming—implying that the collapse stemmed from an interaction of multiple stresses rather than a single cause [2]. Collectively, prolonged drought, self-inflicted environmental damage and sociopolitical turmoil destabilized Maya cities, leading to their gradual abandonment.
all_claims: Climatic research shows that the Classic Maya decline coincided with “exceptional drought” across the region, indicating severe environmental stress at the moment of collapse [3].
Sediment‐based reconstructions suggest annual rainfall dropped by roughly 25–40%, and possibly as much as 20–65%, a reduction large enough to cripple water reserves and maize harvests [4].
In response, the Maya intensified land use, cutting most trees across vast areas for cornfields, firewood and building materials, thereby deforesting and degrading their landscape [1].

Beyond ecology, archaeologists cite additional pressures—warfare, invasion, migration, disease and chronic over-farming—implying that the collapse stemmed from an interaction of multiple stresses rather than a single cause [2].
Collectively, prolonged drought, self-inflicted environmental damage and sociopolitical turmoil destabilized Maya cities, leading to their gradual abandonment.

question_en: Why can't bones grow back?
pos_context_title_en: Why can't bones grow back? (www.sciencefocus.com)
How Do Your Bones Change Over Time? (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Bone Regeneration - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
pos_context_en:
Bones do repair themselves to some extent. But they can’t regenerate or replace themselves fully for the same reason that we can’t grow ourselves a new lung or an extra eye.


Although the DNA to build a complete copy of the entire body is present in every cell with a nucleus, not all of that DNA is active. Most of our cells become specialised during embryonic development so that they only divide to produce cells appropriate to their location in the body.


This is an essential mechanism that keeps us all looking roughly the right shape, despite the fact that our cells are continually dividing and dying off. There seems to be an inverse relationship between how complex an organism is and how well it is able to regenerate after an injury.

Bone is a living tissue that constantly renews itself. “Your skeleton is completely new every 10 years,” says Dr. Deal.


In childhood and adolescence, bone buildup outpaces bone removal, or loss.


In your early 20s, the density of minerals in your bones peaks. Your bone mass may stabilize or start slowly declining as bone loss overtakes bone buildup.

An epochal question: How to harness the intrinsic regenerative capacity of bone? Bone regenerative tacticians have proposed a deconstructive approach, that is: What are the compositional elemental components of bone beginning with cells, extracellular matrices (organic and inorganic) and soluble signaling molecules? Further posing the questions: How do these compositional elements inspire the multi-tiered temporal osteogenic regenerative cascade? Is there a trigger factor? Are there co-factors?
report_en: Bones can fix breaks but cannot regrow an entire missing part because their cells are programmed for limited, site-appropriate repair rather than complete replacement. Bones are living tissue that remodel continually, with every skeleton replaced about every decade, showing they possess the machinery for small-scale turnover [2]. After an injury, bone tissue can knit a fracture together, but this repair relies on the remaining framework and stops once the gap closes, so it cannot recreate a completely missing section [1]. The reason lies in cell specialization: although each nucleated cell carries the full genetic code, most of that DNA is switched off once the cell commits to a specific role during embryonic development, so adult bone cells cannot revert to the multipurpose state needed to rebuild a complex structure from scratch [1]. More complex organisms, humans included, generally sacrifice regenerative range for developmental precision, further limiting our capacity to regrow full bones [1].

Bones are living tissue that remodel continually, with every skeleton replaced about every decade, showing they possess the machinery for small-scale turnover [2].
After an injury, bone tissue can knit a fracture together, but this repair relies on the remaining framework and stops once the gap closes, so it cannot recreate a completely missing section [1].

The reason lies in cell specialization: although each nucleated cell carries the full genetic code, most of that DNA is switched off once the cell commits to a specific role during embryonic development, so adult bone cells cannot revert to the multipurpose state needed to rebuild a complex structure from scratch [1].

question_en: How does fingerprint unlock work on phones?
pos_context_title_en: How Touch ID works: Making sense of Apple's fingerprint identity sensor (www.imore.com)
How fingerprint scanners work — Optical, capacitive, and other variants (www.androidauthority.com)
How fingerprint scanners work — Optical, capacitive, and other variants (www.androidauthority.com)
pos_context_en: The Touch ID sensor is wafer thin, measuring only 170 microns. However, it can take 550ppi scans, which allows for a good level of detail analysis. It's also capacitive and reads the fingerprint at a sub-dermal level. That means it's not reading the dead skin on the top of your finger, but the new, living skin beneath the surface. That makes it less likely to be fooled by fake fingerprints, severed fingers, and other sci-fi spy movie tropes

nstead of creating a traditional image of a fingerprint, capacitive fingerprint scanners use arrays of tiny capacitor circuits to collect data. As capacitors store electrical charge, connecting them up to conductive plates on the surface of the scanner allows them to be used to track the details of a fingerprint. The stored charge will be changed slightly when a finger’s ridge is placed over the conductive plates. Conversely, an air gap will leave the charge at the capacitor relatively unchanged. An op-amp integrator circuit is used to track these changes, which can then be recorded by an analog-to-digital converter

Once captured, this digital data is analyzed to look for distinctive and unique fingerprint attributes. They can then be saved for comparison at a later date. What is particularly smart about this design is that it is much tougher to fool than an optical scanner. The results can’t be replicated with an image. Additionally, they are incredibly tough to fool with some sort of prosthetic, as different materials will record slightly different changes in charge at the capacitor. The only real security risks come from either hardware or software hacking.

Creating a large enough array of these capacitors, typically hundreds if not thousands in a single scanner, allows for a highly detailed image of the ridges and valleys of a fingerprint to be created from nothing more than electrical signals. Just like the optical scanner, more capacitors result in a higher resolution scanner
report_en: When you rest a finger on the scanner, an array of hundreds or even thousands of microscopic capacitors measures tiny changes in stored electrical charge caused by ridges touching the plates while valleys leave air gaps, creating an electronic map of the print [2]. An op-amp integrator and an analog-to-digital converter then turn these charge differences into a high-resolution digital image [2]. Apple’s Touch ID example shows the hardware’s precision: its chip is only 170 µm thick yet captures 550 ppi scans and reads beneath the dead surface layer, sampling the living skin for greater reliability [1]. During enrollment, software analyzes the electronic image to extract distinctive attributes and saves them as a template; later scans are matched against this template to approve or deny access [3]. Because the technique relies on real skin’s electrical properties rather than light, ordinary photos or most prosthetics cannot reproduce the pattern, making capacitive systems far harder to spoof than optical readers [3].

An op-amp integrator and an analog-to-digital converter then turn these charge differences into a high-resolution digital image [2].

claims_retained: When you rest a finger on the scanner, an array of hundreds or even thousands of microscopic capacitors measures tiny changes in stored electrical charge caused by ridges touching the plates while valleys leave air gaps, creating an electronic map of the print [2].
An op-amp integrator and an analog-to-digital converter then turn these charge differences into a high-resolution digital image [2].

Apple’s Touch ID example shows the hardware’s precision: its chip is only 170 µm thick yet captures 550 ppi scans and reads beneath the dead surface layer, sampling the living skin for greater reliability [1].

Because the technique relies on real skin’s electrical properties rather than light, ordinary photos or most prosthetics cannot reproduce the pattern, making capacitive systems far harder to spoof than optical readers [3].

question_en: Why can't you feel the magnetic waves in between magnets?
pos_context_title_en: Can we sense invisible magnetic fields? (www.bbc.com)
Some People's Brains Can Sense Earth's Magnetic Field—but No, It Doesn't Mean We Have Magnetoreception 'Superpowers' (www.smithsonianmag.com)
Can we sense invisible magnetic fields? (www.bbc.com)
Can we sense invisible magnetic fields? (www.bbc.com)
pos_context_en:
While the Manchester Experiments didn't conclusively prove that humans could sense magnetic fields, they were certainly provocative, and they set off dozens of replication attempts around the globe. But the initial findings may have been too good to be true.


Biologists James L Gould and Kenneth P Able, for example, found that they were unable, in eight different attempts, to replicate the effect. "We believe that our consistent failures indicate that the phenomenon is neither as simple nor as robust as we had been inclined to hope," they wrote in Science.

There are currently two major hypotheses. One involves cryptochromes, specialized proteins in the retina, that somehow communicate magnetic information to the brain. The other hypothesis is that microscopic particles of the mineral magnetite sit in certain receptor cells in the ear or behind the nose and work as biological compasses.
Samples of magnetite in our brains and of cryptochrome in our eyes are given as evidence that we might be able to sense magnetic fields

Even now, the Manchester Experiments remain controversial, but discoveries of a mineral called magnetite in our brains and bones and of cryptochrome in our eyes have continued to push researchers to search for evidence that we're able, somehow, to sense magnetic fields. It's safe to say at least that if we do have that ability, however slight, it's not been easy to prove.
report_en: Humans don’t consciously “feel” the magnetic forces between two bar magnets because, unlike some animals, we apparently lack a robust, specialized sensory system for magnetism: although trace amounts of magnetite have been found in human brains and cryptochrome proteins in our eyes—molecules that in other species act as biological compasses—experiments have so far failed to show a clear, reliable magnetic sense in people, making any putative ability too slight to register as a tactile or perceptual experience [4]; multiple controlled replications of the best-known positive studies have produced consistent null results, leading researchers to conclude that whatever magnetic sensitivity we possess is “neither as simple nor as robust” as once hoped [1]; consequently, even strong fields created by household magnets pass through us without triggering nerves the way light activates photoreceptors or pressure activates touch receptors, so we remain unaware of the “waves” in the gap.

question_en: Why do the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent have such a high diversity for religions?
pos_context_title_en: Middle East (en.wikipedia.org)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
The Major Religions In India (www.worldatlas.com)
A Brief History of the Yazidis of Iraq | JSTOR Daily (daily.jstor.org)
pos_context_en: The Middle East is very diverse when it comes to religions, many of which originated there. Islam is the largest religion in the Middle East, but other faiths that originated there, such as Judaism and Christianity, are also well represented. Christians represent 40.5% of Lebanon, where the Lebanese president, half of the cabinet, and half of the parliament follow one of the various Lebanese Christian rites. There are also important minority religions like the Baháʼí Faith, Yarsanism, Yazidism, Zoroastrianism, Mandaeism, Druze, and Shabakism, and in ancient times the region was home to Mesopotamian religions, Canaanite religions, Manichaeism, Mithraism and various monotheist gnostic sects

Experts have dated Hinduism as far back as 4,000 years. Even though many link it to the early Indus Valley Civilization, it does not have a particular beginning, but instead has been founded over many years
experts date Islam back to the 7^th century. It first originated in Mecca—a city in modern-day Saudi Arabia—during the life of the prophet Muhammad
Sikhism originated in Punjab around the late 1400s. It is primarily based on the spiritual teachings of Guru Nanak and the nine other gurus that continued his work
While Buddhism was founded in India roughly 2,500 years ago, it has become more popular in other Asian countries like Cambodia and Thailand
Even though Jainism always existed according to its official doctrine, experts have traced its beginnings back to the Indus Valley Civilization

Zoroastrianism originated in Persia approximately 4,000 years ago. Zoroastrian refugees were forced to flee the region during the Muslim conquest of Iran in the 7^th century. To escape persecution, many of their numbers found sanctuary in India

Yazidism, an ancient indigenous Kurdish faith influenced by Zoroastrianism, was revived by ‘Adi ibn Musafir (ca. 1075-1162), an Arab Sufi shaikh [whose] shrine in northern Iraq became the religious center of the group
report_en: Both regions have been civilizational crossroads for millennia, so faiths were born locally while others kept arriving through conquest, commerce, pilgrimage and refuge, layering rather than replacing one another. In the Middle East, the birthplace of the Abrahamic trio—Judaism, Christianity and Islam—those major creeds coexist with enduring minorities such as the Baháʼí, Druze and Yazidis, producing a spectrum that ranges from global religions to small indigenous cults [1]. On the Indian subcontinent, native traditions like Hinduism trace back about 4,000 years [2], Jainism claims roots in the Indus Valley [6], and Buddhism began roughly 2,500 years ago before spreading across Asia [5]. Later waves added further variety: Islam reached India from Arabia in the 7th century [3]; Sikhism emerged in Punjab in the late 1400s [4]; and Zoroastrian refugees fleeing the Muslim conquest of Iran settled there after the 7th century [7]. Recurrent imperial rule generally accommodated local beliefs, and continuous migration kept introducing new ones, so multiple religions endured side-by-side, yielding today’s extraordinary diversity.

In the Middle East, the birthplace of the Abrahamic trio—Judaism, Christianity and Islam—those major creeds coexist with enduring minorities such as the Baháʼí, Druze and Yazidis, producing a spectrum that ranges from global religions to small indigenous cults [1].

On the Indian subcontinent, native traditions like Hinduism trace back about 4,000 years [2], Jainism claims roots in the Indus Valley [6], and Buddhism began roughly 2,500 years ago before spreading across Asia [5].

Later waves added further variety: Islam reached India from Arabia in the 7th century [3]; Sikhism emerged in Punjab in the late 1400s [4]; and Zoroastrian refugees fleeing the Muslim conquest of Iran settled there after the 7th century [7].

question_en: Singha beer is £1.50 in the UK, it is brewed in Thailand and shipped to the UK? How are they making money?
pos_context_title_en: Bulk Alcoholic Beverage Shipping Rates & Services (www.uship.com)
Santi Bhirombhakdi & family (www.forbes.com)
Singha (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
Image]


14 Boxes of 750ml bottles of beer. 12 per box.


Placentia, CA 92870 USA


Dallas, TX 75248 USA

Beer baron Santi Bhirombhakdi controls 88-year-old Boon Rawd Brewery, Thailand's oldest brewery and maker of Singha Beer.
* Santi's other interests include food manufacturing and retailing, hospitality, logistics, power generation and real estate.
In Thailand and other major markets, Singha is available in bottles (330 ml and 630 ml), cans (330 ml and 490 ml), and on tap.
report_en: Singha is produced by Boon Rawd Brewery in Thailand, the country’s oldest brewer and part of a diversified conglomerate that also owns logistics operations, giving it control over shipping costs [2]; it is exported in compact 330 ml bottles that maximise the number of units per container, lowering freight to just a few pence per bottle when shipped at full container scale [3]. Thailand’s lower labour, energy and ingredient costs mean ex-factory production can be well under £0.20 a bottle, and bulk sea freight, even after UK alcohol duty (≈£0.08 on 330 ml of 5% ABV) and VAT, keeps the landed cost to importers around £0.60–£0.70. UK supermarkets typically apply a gross margin of 30-40%, so a shelf price of £1.50 still allows profits for the retailer, distributor and Boon Rawd. In short, low production costs, efficient high-volume shipping, favourable exchange rates and multi-stage mark-ups all enable profitability despite the modest UK retail price.
all_claims: Singha is produced by Boon Rawd Brewery in Thailand, the country’s oldest brewer and part of a diversified conglomerate that also owns logistics operations, giving it control over shipping costs [2]; it is exported in compact 330 ml bottles that maximise the number of units per container, lowering freight to just a few pence per bottle when shipped at full container scale [3].

question_en: Why does it feel like less effort to watch 3 - hour long TV episodes back to back than a film?
pos_context_title_en: Binge Watching and Its Effects on Your Sleep (www.psychologytoday.com)
The Effects Of TV On The Brain – EruptingMind (www.eruptingmind.com)
How Watching Movies Can Benefit Our Mental Health (psychcentral.com)
Digital Media Literacy: Why We Can't Just Pick a Movie (edu.gcfglobal.org)
The Real (and Very Normal) Reason You're So Exhausted After Therapy (www.realsimple.com)
pos_context_en: Being exposed to the content of the programming—storylines, action, imagery—stimulates brain activity and alertness.
Watching TV causes the body to release chemicals which make it feel good. These are endorphins, a natural sedative with similar properties to heroin
Cinema therapy allows us to use the effect of imagery, plot, music, etc. in films on our psyche for insight, inspiration, emotional release or relief and natural change.
Choice paralysis is when you have trouble making a decision because there’s an overwhelming amount of different options.
Often in those situations, Fried says, people are surprised at how suddenly exhaustion can set in once the stress-inducing event is over-something that can also happen after therapy.
report_en: TV episodes are engineered as a series of short narrative peaks separated by credits and mini-recaps; these brief pauses keep cognitive load low while the cliff-hangers that end each segment spike brain activity and alertness, motivating you to keep going [1]. Each time a new episode starts your body releases another burst of endorphins—the same natural sedatives that make you feel good after pleasurable stimuli—so continuing feels rewarding rather than taxing [2]. Streaming platforms also auto-queue the next installment, sparing you the decision-making that can trigger “choice paralysis,” whereas starting a three-hour movie requires one big, deliberate commitment [4]. When you finally do watch a long film, its single, extended emotional arc often produces a sudden drop in arousal once it ends, leaving you fatigued in much the same way people crash after any intense, stress-inducing event such as a therapy session [5].

question_en: Why do some TV shows include a sign-language translator? Aren't subtitles simpler and good enough?
pos_context_title_en: Sign Language Interpretation on TV: Let’s give the deaf a chance (www.daytranslations.com)
Helen Schreibman-Smith: Why subtitles aren't always enough (www.theguardian.com)
Helen Schreibman-Smith: Why subtitles aren't always enough (www.theguardian.com)
pos_context_en: Sign language interpretation on TV plays an important role. With their help, the deaf are able to understand the content of the show. In every country, there is a different law concerning sign language for television. In some countries, it is required in almost every show. In other countries, it is the discretion of the TV network. Usually, news and current affairs programs are given sign language interpreters since these are programs of extreme relevance to the viewers

It's much easier for sign language users to keep track of who's speaking with a qualified interpreter, who'll take on aspects of the character that they're conveying. And unlike sign language interpretation, subtitles rarely indicate sound effects or music.

The answer is that sign language uses more than just the hands. Seeing the whole face, especially the eyes and mouth, is crucial in being able to tell between similar-looking signs. The interpreter needs to be large enough to show these features of the language.
report_en: TV broadcasters add an on-screen sign-language interpreter because, for many deaf viewers, this is the only way to receive the full linguistic, emotional and contextual information of a programme, and in several countries it is even mandated by law for key genres such as news and current-affairs shows [1]. Subtitles, while helpful, leave gaps: they seldom mark who is speaking or capture tone, music and other sound effects, whereas a qualified interpreter can instantly express speaker changes and convey character traits through facial expression and body language [2]. Moreover, sign language is a visual-spatial language that relies heavily on the movement of the eyes, mouth and whole face; these critical cues cannot be embedded in text and require the interpreter to be displayed large enough for clarity [3]. Therefore, subtitles alone are “simpler” but not “good enough” for complete accessibility, prompting many programmes to include live sign-language translation.

question_en: what's the simplest way to explain higher special dimensions to someone?
pos_context_title_en: Q: What would life be like in higher dimensions? (www.askamathematician.com)
Q: What would life be like in higher dimensions? (www.askamathematician.com)
Four-dimensional space (en.wikipedia.org)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
Imagining a World with 4 Spatial Dimensions (futurism.com)
pos_context_en: Most physical laws are already written in a dimension-free form.
Most physicists consider light to be native to only 3 dimensions, because light is an EM wave and it’s direction of propagation is perpendicular to both its Electric and Magnetic fields.
Mathematically, four-dimensional space is a space with four spatial dimensions, that is a space that needs four parameters to specify a point in it.

One of the most effective ways of explaining this elusive dimension is to use a sequence of hypercubes, starting from the zeroth-dimension leading up to the fourth dimension (so five separate dimensions overall).
0-HC. It occupies no volume because it doesn’t have width, length, or depth. As a result, it is effectively an infinitely small point in space.
take your infinitely small point and extend it in a single straight line in any direction. Now you have created a 1-HC.
extend it perpendicular to your original direction to create a plane.
generate your 2-HC and then raise it into the third dimension to create a cube
the fourth dimension of spacetime. We call this a tesseract.
report_en: Imagine each spatial dimension as a new, independent “direction” you can move in; mathematically, a four-dimensional space is just one where specifying a point requires four numbers instead of three [3].  A helpful ladder of shapes shows how these extra directions build up: begin with a 0-dimensional point that has no length, width, or depth [5]; stretch it into a straight line and you have one dimension [6]; push the line in a direction perpendicular to itself to sweep out a flat square plane, giving two dimensions [7]; lift that plane in a new perpendicular direction to form a cube, our familiar three-dimensional space [8]; then imagine one more direction, again perpendicular to all previous ones, and slide the cube along it—this creates a four-dimensional “hypercube” or tesseract [9].  Because most physical laws are written without fixing the number of dimensions, the underlying mathematics stays the same even when we add such extra directions [1].

question_en: Why does it seem like when I watch something the second time around, it goes by faster than the first time I watched it?
pos_context_title_en: Why Does Time Seem to Pass at Different Speeds? (www.psychologytoday.com)
pos_context_en: The speed of time seems to be largely determined by how much information our minds absorb and process — the more information there is, the slower time goes. This connection was verified by the psychologist Robert Ornstein in the 1960s. In a series of experiments, Ornstein played tapes to volunteers with various kinds of sound information on them, such as simple clicking sounds and household noises. At the end, he asked them to estimate how long they had listened to the tape. He found that when there was more information on the tape, such as double the number of clicking noises, the volunteers estimated the time period to be longer.
report_en: Your first viewing is packed with unfamiliar sights, sounds and plot points, so your brain has to absorb and interpret a lot of new information; psychologist Robert Ornstein showed that when people were exposed to tapes containing more information—such as double the number of clicking sounds—they judged the interval as longer, demonstrating that the heavier the cognitive load, the slower time feels [1]. On a second viewing most of the material is already stored in memory, so there is far less novelty to process; with less incoming data, the brain works more quickly and forms fewer fresh memories, leaving you with the impression that the episode or movie “flew by.” In short, perceived duration is tied to information density: high density stretches time, low density compresses it, which is why repeats seem shorter even though the actual clock time is unchanged [1].

question_en: Why do benches empty when there is a fight in baseball?
pos_context_title_en: Bench-clearing brawl (en.wikipedia.org)
Unlike MLB, the NHL stamped out bench-clearing brawls (www.si.com)
Bench-Clearing Brawls Just Not The Same Without Amphetamines (www.thebrushback.com)
pos_context_en: A bench-clearing brawl is a form of ritualistic fighting that occurs in sports, most notably baseball and ice hockey, in which every player on both teams leaves their dugouts, bullpens, or benches, and charges the playing area in order to fight one another or try to break up a fight. Penalties for leaving the bench can range from nothing to severe.
Although this particular brawl earned a place in history, a similar sort of all-hands-on-deck silliness remains a fairly regular feature in baseball.
In the glory days of bench clearing brawls, real punches were thrown and real blood was shed, mostly because the players were so incredibly high all the time.
report_en: When punches, hard slides or hit-by-pitches ignite a confrontation on the field, every player from the dugouts, bullpens and benches typically rushes onto the diamond because baseball’s unwritten code expects teammates to show immediate solidarity, either by directly engaging the opposing side or by pulling their own players out of danger; the resulting “bench-clearing brawl” is literally defined by both squads emptying their benches to “fight one another or try to break up a fight” [1], and its all-hands-on-deck nature has become a regular, almost ritualistic feature of the sport [2], even though penalties for leaving the bench can range from none to severe [1].

question_en: Why do police officers have bullet proof vests for covering vital organs when often times they leave their heads unprotected?
pos_context_title_en: Police Ballistic Helmets | What Every Officer Should Know (www.hardheadveterans.com)
Best policing is not wearing bulletproof and helmet always – Police PRO - Enfrans Media (enfransmedia.com)
pos_context_en:
Officers are not going to wear ballistic helmets for every second they are on duty as it's simply impractical. So this means if they are tucked away in their gear, most likely in the trunk of a squad car. They may not be on the officer's head at that critical moment when it's needed.


So why even try to get every officer outfitted with tactical helmets?


Because law enforcement officers are continually being called upon to respond quickly to threats on their own. In the case of an active shooter, it can be argued that a tactically sound choice for the officer would be to go to the trunk of the squad car to get kitted up (hard plates, rifle, helmet) before rushing in with nothing more than a pistol and soft armor. That ballistic helmet or hard armor might mean the difference between the police officer staying in the fight and eliminating the threat or becoming another casualty themselves.


[Image: law enforcement ballistic helmet in trunk of car. ]


Photo courtesy of officer.com


Choosing A Ballistic Helmet


Helmets come in in numerous variations and capabilities these days and it may be confusing at first on what you or your police department would be best suited for. The three basic options are going to be the following


-PASGT Helmet


-Below The Ear Cut like our BTE helmet (MICH/ACH/ECH/LWH)


-High Cut like our ATE ballistic helmet. (FAST)


[Image: Police ballistic helmet options]


PASGT and BTE style helmets are going to provide the most ballistic coverage for police officers. They typically go down over the ear or are at mid-ear on the sides. The drawback here is the extra weight, and if the law enforcement officer is using any kind headset it tends to get squished into the ears uncomfortably.

Sheilla Kessie Abayie-Buckman, Director of Public Affair, Ghana Police Service, has said that, it would not be appropriate for the police to be seen every day by the public wearing bulletproof jackets and helmets when going about their duty.


According to her, when the police are seen by the public wearing their bulletproof jackets and helmets, it has an impact on the public that they give protection to.


“Look at this, if you saw every police officer wear the bulletproof jacket and the helmet, what will you say? The best practice does not indicate that every police officer must at every time, wear these things,” she said while contributing to a discussion on Joy FM’s Newsfile on Saturday, monitored by GhanaWeb.


Abayie-Buckman explained, “because it also impacts on the people to whom we are giving protection. So, we are doing the right thing…”
report_en: Police routinely wear soft-armour vests because they shield the heart and lungs yet are light, flexible and designed for continuous, 8- to 12-hour shifts, whereas ballistic helmets are heavier, press headsets into the ears and are considered “simply impractical” to keep on for every second of duty, so they are stored in the patrol-car trunk and put on only for high-risk calls such as active-shooter incidents [1]. Moreover, police leaders note that seeing officers patrolling in helmets all day can intimidate or unsettle the very public they are meant to reassure, so standard practice is to reserve helmets for situations where rifle fire is expected rather than routine community policing [2]. In short, vests deliver vital-organ protection with minimal trade-offs, while head protection is used selectively to balance mobility, comfort, public perception and readiness.
all_claims: Police routinely wear soft-armour vests because they shield the heart and lungs yet are light, flexible and designed for continuous, 8- to 12-hour shifts, whereas ballistic helmets are heavier, press headsets into the ears and are considered “simply impractical” to keep on for every second of duty, so they are stored in the patrol-car trunk and put on only for high-risk calls such as active-shooter incidents [1].

Moreover, police leaders note that seeing officers patrolling in helmets all day can intimidate or unsettle the very public they are meant to reassure, so standard practice is to reserve helmets for situations where rifle fire is expected rather than routine community policing [2].
In short, vests deliver vital-organ protection with minimal trade-offs, while head protection is used selectively to balance mobility, comfort, public perception and readiness.

question_en: Why can I eat mold on a cheese, but not on any other foods?
pos_context_title_en: Should you eat that moldy cheese? (www.mayoclinic.org)
You Asked: Can I Scrape Mold Off of Food and Eat It? (time.com)
pos_context_en: Of course, not all molds pose a risk. Some types of mold are used to make cheeses, such as Brie and Camembert. These molds are safe for healthy adults to eat. However, these cheeses, as well as other soft cheeses and cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, are best avoided by people with weakened immune systems, older adults, pregnant women, infants and young children.

when visible mold is present, its tentacles—called “threads”—have likely penetrated deep into your food, contaminating even those parts that appear to be mold-free.


The health risks of mold exposure are many. “Mold can produce toxic substances, called mycotoxins,” says Katie George, a clinical dietitian at the University of Kansas Hospital. These toxins can cause respiratory problems, allergic reactions and illness. George says aflatoxin, a specific type mycotoxin found in nuts and grains, can even be cancer-causing.


Mold is usually easy to spot. It often appears as a blue or green discoloration, which can grow a hairy coat if left long enough, Kirkpatrick says. If you’re examining foods in jars—things like pasta sauce or salsa—it’s best to check the underside of the lid and rim of the container for suspicious growths.


Just don’t sniff your foods, Kirkpatrick warns, which could lead to you inhaling mold spores. If you’re worried about mold but don’t see any growths, use common sense. “If the food doesn’t look the way it normally would, and especially if it seems moisture-soaked, toss it,” Kirkpatrick says.


The exceptions: Hard block cheeses like parmesan, cheddar or Swiss. “With those, the mold generally won’t penetrate deep into the product,” Kirkpatrick says. But don’t start scraping, which can release mold spores into the air or allow them to spread to your countertops or other foods. The only safe way to remove that mold is to cut away an inch of cheese all the way around the spot, she says. “You’ll probably cut away some safe parts, but that’s a good rule of thumb.”
report_en: The mold you’re meant to eat is the carefully selected Penicillium added during cheesemaking; it is non-toxic, grows in predictable patterns on cheeses like Brie, Camembert or blue varieties, and is safe for healthy adults to consume [1]. In contrast, the random molds that pop up on bread, fruit, sauces and most leftovers send thread-like roots deep into the food, so even areas that look clean can harbor spores and mycotoxins that provoke allergies, respiratory problems or even cancer (in the case of aflatoxin) [2]. Because you can’t see how far these wild molds have penetrated, simply cutting or scraping the surface won’t remove the risk, and scraping can actually disperse spores onto counters and other foods [2]. The lone exception is hard cheeses such as cheddar or parmesan; their dense texture limits penetration, so you can safely cut away at least one inch around the moldy spot and eat the remainder [2].

In contrast, the random molds that pop up on bread, fruit, sauces and most leftovers send thread-like roots deep into the food, so even areas that look clean can harbor spores and mycotoxins that provoke allergies, respiratory problems or even cancer (in the case of aflatoxin) [2].

Because you can’t see how far these wild molds have penetrated, simply cutting or scraping the surface won’t remove the risk, and scraping can actually disperse spores onto counters and other foods [2].
The lone exception is hard cheeses such as cheddar or parmesan; their dense texture limits penetration, so you can safely cut away at least one inch around the moldy spot and eat the remainder [2].

question_en: Women wearing wedding rings who arent actually married..
pos_context_title_en: Why Single Ladies Are Rocking a Wedding Ring (www.vogue.com)
pos_context_en: It seemed to be less of a social statement than a sartorial one. “Uniform dressing is trickling down to jewelry, even to an engagement or wedding ring, which can be worn interchangeably as a regular ring,” says Vogue.com Senior Fashion Editor Jorden Bickham. “The smaller the ring, the more opportunity to wear on multiple fingers. Your left finger is suddenly not viewed as real estate for an engagement ring," she added
report_en: An emerging fashion trend sees single women donning slender engagement-style or wedding bands purely as accessories rather than marital symbols; according to Vogue.com senior fashion editor Jorden Bickham, “uniform dressing is trickling down to jewelry,” so a streamlined ring is now treated like any other minimalist piece that can “be worn interchangeably” across multiple fingers, with the traditional left-hand placement no longer reserved for betrothed status [1]. The appeal lies in versatility—the smaller and subtler the band, the easier it is to stack or switch between digits—turning what once signified commitment into an everyday style accent, devoid of social statements about relationship status [1].

question_en: the different fluids that come out when you squeeze a zit or cyst.....I know it's gross but I'm curious
pos_context_title_en: Clear Liquid Pimple: Reason Of Formation And How To Treat It (www.gorgeousgirl.com)
This Is What's Really Coming Out When You Pop Your Pimples (www.yahoo.com)
pos_context_en: What is the clear liquid in a pimple? The clear liquid coming out of a pimple can be a mixture of several substances, including water. Oftentimes, your pimple will also be filled with a serous liquid which is made up of your white blood cells, the type that fights infectious agents, including pimple-causing bacteria. A pimple oozing clear liquid is also normally accompanied by solidified sebum, dead skin cells, dirt and other impurities, and bacteria and its waste products. This combination gives the otherwise pimple with clear fluid a yellowish appearance. Sometimes, it may also be reddish which signifies the presence of a pimple with clear fluid and blood.

Pus is a collection of inflammatory blood cells that accumulate within the follicle and reach the surface of the skin,” says Dr. Zeichner. “It accumulates as a result of the inflammation that develops in the pore and oil gland.”

[Image]

When the pimple is popped, the pus typically has a white or yellow tint. But sometimes, you’re met with green. “A green discoloration may be the result of a specific type of bacteria involved in an infection, but that usually is not the case in acne,” Dr. Zeichner says. While normal bacteria-causing acne will not result in this, if you do have a big, painful, green-filled pustule, ask your doctor whether you might need a prescription for antibiotics.
report_en: When you squeeze a pimple or cyst, the first material usually forced out is pus—a thick collection of inflammatory white-blood cells, oil, and debris that looks white or yellow [2]. As pressure continues, a thinner clear or slightly straw-colored serous fluid may follow; this plasma-like liquid is mostly water mixed with defensive white blood cells that had pooled inside the lesion [1]. Both the pus and the clear fluid can carry semi-solid plugs of sebum (skin oil), dead skin cells, dirt, bacteria, and their waste products, which show up as white strings or yellowish curds [1]. Aggressive squeezing may rupture small blood vessels, so streaks of bright red blood can mingle with the exudate, giving it a pink or reddish hue [1]. In uncommon cases the expelled material looks green; this suggests a pigment-producing bacterium and can indicate a need for medical assessment [2].

As pressure continues, a thinner clear or slightly straw-colored serous fluid may follow; this plasma-like liquid is mostly water mixed with defensive white blood cells that had pooled inside the lesion [1].
