question_en: Why is tree shade a cooler temperature than other shade?
pos_context_title_en: 20 Surprising Things That Can Keep You Cooler All Summer (bestlifeonline.com)
Trees much better at cooling than shade structures (www.smh.com.au)
pos_context_en: The shade from trees is actually cooler than shade from buildings and other man-made objects, thanks to a process called transpiration. A tree maintains its temperature by circulating water around inside itself and releasing moisture into the atmosphere, to keep itself and the air around it cool. Buildings, on the other hand, trap heat and radiate it back into the surrounding environment.
the shade under a tree can be up to 10 degrees cooler than the shade under a shade structure.
report_en: Tree shade is noticeably cooler than shade cast by buildings or other man-made structures because trees behave like natural evaporative coolers: they draw water up from the soil and, through transpiration, release moisture into the air, absorbing heat in the process and lowering both their own surface temperature and the temperature of the surrounding air, while inert materials simply block sunlight and then radiate stored heat back outward [1]. This active cooling means the air beneath a tree can be measured at up to 10 °C (about 18 °F) cooler than the air under an equivalent shade structure made of non-living materials [2].
all_claims: Tree shade is noticeably cooler than shade cast by buildings or other man-made structures because trees behave like natural evaporative coolers: they draw water up from the soil and, through transpiration, release moisture into the air, absorbing heat in the process and lowering both their own surface temperature and the temperature of the surrounding air, while inert materials simply block sunlight and then radiate stored heat back outward [1].
This active cooling means the air beneath a tree can be measured at up to 10 °C (about 18 °F) cooler than the air under an equivalent shade structure made of non-living materials [2].

This active cooling means the air beneath a tree can be measured at up to 10 °C (about 18 °F) cooler than the air under an equivalent shade structure made of non-living materials [2].

question_en: Why is gold so valuable? And why is it more valuable than other metals, like silver?
pos_context_title_en: Why Is Gold So Valuable? [UPDATED for 2021] (www.gainesvillecoins.com)
Why Is Gold So Valuable? [UPDATED for 2021] (www.gainesvillecoins.com)
Why do we value gold? (www.bbc.com)
Why is gold considered so valuable. It is not the rarest metal, it is not the most useful, so why the worship of this yellow metal. | Notes and Queries (www.theguardian.com)
pos_context_en:
Gold Is Rare. Very Rare


Gold is one of the rarest elements on the Earth. This rarity is responsible for much of gold's value. As a chemical element, it is atomic number 79 on the Periodic Table of Elements.


How much gold is left in the world? Instead of being measured in parts per million like other metals, gold makes up only four parts per BILLION in the Earth's crust. Of course, gold mining companies dig where gold has already been found, but it still takes a massive amount of digging to recover commercial quantities of gold.

Gold’s Special Properties Have Many Industrial Applications


On the Periodic Table of Elements, gold is shown as the symbol Au, referencing the Latin aurum. Its atomic number is 79, grouping it with the "noble metals." Its chemical properties distinguish gold from alkaline metals such as lithium.


Science has shown that gold is commonly found in industrial settings. It's an extremely useful material beyond its applications in jewelry, finance, and art.

Silver tarnishes - it reacts with minute amounts of sulphur in the air. That's why we place particular value on gold.


It turns out then, that the reason gold is precious is precisely that it is so chemically uninteresting.


Gold's relative inertness means you can create an elaborate golden jaguar and be confident that 1,000 years later it can be found in a museum display case in central London, still in pristine condition.

Mainly ancient tradition. It is fairly easy to process and as far as ancient people were concerned it was indestructible it does not tarnish like silver or copper. It does not dissolve in normal acids and solvents. It is pretty and if you alloy it with other metals it can have a variety of colours. Ancient people used it as a form of exchange as people desired it and if you put it in a damp cupboard it would still be unchanged when you came to use it. Gold has retained its value because it is still rare and people like to adorn them selves with it.
report_en: Gold’s high value stems from a mix of extreme scarcity, remarkable durability, practical utility, and long-standing human preference. Gold is one of the rarest elements, averaging only about four parts per billion in Earth’s crust, so merely locating and extracting it requires enormous effort [1]. Unlike most metals, it is chemically inert—museum pieces can sit for 1,000 years and still look newly minted because gold hardly reacts with air or moisture [3]. That permanence made ancient peoples regard it as “indestructible,” easy to melt and shape yet impossible to ruin, so it became a trusted store of wealth and medium of exchange, a role that persists in modern finance [4]. Beyond ornament and money, gold’s excellent conductivity and resistance to corrosion make it indispensable in electronics, medicine, and aerospace, adding practical demand to its monetary allure [2]. Silver lacks two of these advantages: it is more abundant and it tarnishes readily when exposed to trace sulfur, diminishing its aesthetic and functional appeal, so the market prices it lower than gold [3].

question_en: Why do some liquids form skins on them but others don't?
pos_context_title_en: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Milk skin (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en: Milk forms a skin on top when heated because of a chemical reaction that affects how protein and fat molecules interact with each other. When milk is heated rapidly, some of the water in it evaporates from the surface. This exposes proteins and fat molecules, which bind and dry out as warming continues. Skin most commonly forms when milk is heated over a stove top, as stoves are generally capable of reaching very high temperatures quite quickly, though it can happen in the microwave as well. The film is not harmful, but is distasteful to many and can be prevented with constant stirring and a close eye on temperature.

It is often surprising to see a film or skin on nonfat or “skim” milk, since it would seem that, without fat, the proteins would have nothing to bind to. In truth, it is rare to encounter milk that is truly fat free. Most of the skim milk that is sold commercially has very low fat content, but is rarely ever truly fat-free. Even trace amounts of fat on the surface can contribute to skin formation.


A similar phenomenon happens with soy milk, which is generally marketed as fat free. Natural fats still occur in trace amounts, and can be drawn to the surface when exposed to very high temperatures. Soy film can be discarded, but is also considered a delicacy in many Asian cultures. When removed and dried, it is referred to as yuba, or soybean curd, which is used in a variety of recipes.

Milk skin or lactoderm refers to a sticky film of protein that forms on top of dairy milk and foods containing dairy milk (such as hot chocolate and some soups). Milk film can be produced both through conventional boiling and by microwaving the liquid, and as such can often be observed when heating milk for use in drinks such as drinking chocolate. It is caused by the denaturation of proteins such as beta-lactoglobulin (whey protein). The thickness of the skin varies dependent on a number of factors, including the temperature of the milk, the shape of the container, and the amount of milk in the container.


When milk is boiled, soluble milk proteins are denatured and then coagulate with milk's fat and form a sticky film across the top of the liquid, which then dries by evaporation. The layer does not need to be discarded and can be consumed, as protein's nutritional value is unaffected by the denaturation process. Milk film is often considered to be desirable and is used in several recipes for various foods.
report_en: Some liquids develop a skin when heated because they contain surface-active solids—chiefly proteins and, to a lesser extent, fats—that denature or coagulate at high temperature, migrate to the surface as water evaporates, then dry into a coherent film; milk illustrates this process as its beta-lactoglobulin unfolds, binds with fat, and forms a sticky layer that thickens during heating [3]. Rapid heating increases evaporation, exposing more protein and fat and promoting skin formation, whereas constant stirring or gentler temperatures keep the solids dispersed and largely prevent it [1]. Even “fat-free” or soy milk can form skins because trace amounts of fat plus ample proteins still provide enough material for the reaction [2]. Liquids that lack appreciable proteins or fats—plain water, clear juices, or many broths—have no substantial macromolecular matrix to denature and cross-link at the surface, so no film develops. Thickness also varies with the concentration of these solids, container shape, and the amount of liquid, factors that influence surface area and heat distribution and thus how much material accumulates at the interface [3].

Rapid heating increases evaporation, exposing more protein and fat and promoting skin formation, whereas constant stirring or gentler temperatures keep the solids dispersed and largely prevent it [1].
Even “fat-free” or soy milk can form skins because trace amounts of fat plus ample proteins still provide enough material for the reaction [2].
Liquids that lack appreciable proteins or fats—plain water, clear juices, or many broths—have no substantial macromolecular matrix to denature and cross-link at the surface, so no film develops.

Thickness also varies with the concentration of these solids, container shape, and the amount of liquid, factors that influence surface area and heat distribution and thus how much material accumulates at the interface [3].

question_en: Why do iced coffee drinks have more caffeine than hot ones?
pos_context_title_en: Iced vs Hot Coffee: Whats The Difference? (sites.psu.edu)
5 Health Benefits Of Drinking Coffee Hot Vs. Iced (www.bustle.com)
Iced Coffee Vs Hot Coffee: Which Is The BETTER Coffee? (coffeebrewster.com)
Iced Coffee Vs Hot Coffee: Which Is The BETTER Coffee? (coffeebrewster.com)
pos_context_en: This is due to the fact that the acidity of cold brewed coffee is almost three times less than hot coffee. The less acidic a drink is, the better it is for a persons digestive system
Cold brews typically contain around 40mg of caffeine per 100g, while hot coffee contains roughly 60mg per 100g of coffee.
Iced coffee made with a single shot of espresso will have less caffeine than regular hot coffee, and a double shot will be almost at par.

The interesting thing is that cold brew has very similar amounts of caffeine as hot brewed coffee, but the caffeine is released much more gradually into the bloodstream, so you’ll feel the effect for much longer.
report_en: Iced coffee drinks are not intrinsically higher in caffeine; in fact, cold-brew coffee averages about 40 mg of caffeine per 100 g, whereas hot coffee is closer to 60 mg per 100 g, showing that the cold version can be one-third lower by weight [2]. Similarly, an iced drink built on a single shot of espresso delivers less caffeine than a standard hot coffee, and only when baristas add a second shot does the amount approach that of the hot brew [3]. The perception that iced beverages are “stronger” usually comes from recipe choices rather than temperature: cafés often increase the coffee dose or add extra espresso to counteract dilution from ice, and cold brew’s caffeine is released more gradually into the bloodstream, giving a sustained alertness that can feel like a bigger dose even though the total is comparable or lower [4].

Similarly, an iced drink built on a single shot of espresso delivers less caffeine than a standard hot coffee, and only when baristas add a second shot does the amount approach that of the hot brew [3].

question_en: How are people able to sleepwalk safely? Why do people make the decisions they make when they sleepwalk?
pos_context_title_en: Sleepwalking - Causes, Symptoms, & Treatments - Sleep Foundation (www.sleepfoundation.org)
Why Do People Sleepwalk? Causes, Symptoms, Dangers, More (www.healthline.com)
5 Steps for Stopping a Sleepwalker (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en: Sleepwalking, formally known as somnambulism, is a behavior disorder that originates during deep sleep and results in walking or performing other complex behaviors while still mostly asleep. It is more common in children than adults and is more likely to occur if a person has a family history of the condition, is sleep deprived, or is prone to repeated nighttime awakenings.

Sleepwalking is a sleeping disturbance that occurs in the deepest part of your nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. It most often occurs within 1 to 2 hours of falling asleep.


During an episode of sleepwalking, you may sit up, walk around, and even perform ordinary activities — all while sleeping. Your eyes are open, but you’re actually still in a deep state of sleep.

Waking someone who is sleepwalking can be dangerous, but allowing a sleepwalker to roam about a room filled with sharp objects or to jump into the driver's seat of a vehicle is what's really hazardous.


The lesson: Stop sleepwalkers and get them back to bed. How? Gently turn them around and make sure they return to the bedroom safely. If they resist, stay with them and help them avoid perilous objects and situations. If you must awaken them, do so with loud noises rather than by shaking or touching them roughly.
report_en: Most sleepwalkers move without injury because the motor regions of the brain are partly active while higher judgment centers remain asleep, allowing ingrained, routine movements—such as navigating a familiar hallway—yet limiting complex decision-making and risk assessment. Episodes arise from the deepest stage of non-rapid eye movement sleep, typically 1-2 hours after falling asleep, when people may sit up, walk around, and even carry out ordinary tasks with their eyes open although they are still in a deep sleep state [2]. Because consciousness and reasoning are suppressed, the “decisions” a sleepwalker appears to make are automatic, guided by habit and environmental cues rather than deliberate choice. Safety therefore depends less on the sleeper’s intentions than on the environment; experts advise gently steering the person back to bed or staying close and removing hazards, using loud noises to wake them only if necessary, since wandering near sharp objects or vehicles poses far greater danger than the act of waking itself [3]. Genetic predisposition, sleep deprivation, and frequent nighttime awakenings increase the likelihood of episodes, explaining why some individuals experience recurrent sleepwalking while others do not [1].

Episodes arise from the deepest stage of non-rapid eye movement sleep, typically 1-2 hours after falling asleep, when people may sit up, walk around, and even carry out ordinary tasks with their eyes open although they are still in a deep sleep state [2].
Because consciousness and reasoning are suppressed, the “decisions” a sleepwalker appears to make are automatic, guided by habit and environmental cues rather than deliberate choice.

Safety therefore depends less on the sleeper’s intentions than on the environment; experts advise gently steering the person back to bed or staying close and removing hazards, using loud noises to wake them only if necessary, since wandering near sharp objects or vehicles poses far greater danger than the act of waking itself [3].

Genetic predisposition, sleep deprivation, and frequent nighttime awakenings increase the likelihood of episodes, explaining why some individuals experience recurrent sleepwalking while others do not [1].

Safety therefore depends less on the sleeper’s intentions than on the environment; experts advise gently steering the person back to bed or staying close and removing hazards, using loud noises to wake them only if necessary, since wandering near sharp objects or vehicles poses far greater danger than the act of waking itself [3].

question_en: 2pac has like 5 albumns since his death. whats going on, who has the rights? seems to be with a million different artists
pos_context_title_en: Tupac’s 6 Posthumous Studio Albums, Ranked (www.yahoo.com)
Tupac’s 6 Posthumous Studio Albums, Ranked (www.yahoo.com)
Tupac’s 6 Posthumous Studio Albums, Ranked (www.yahoo.com)
pos_context_en: Unfortunately, the fifth studio album to surface after Tupac’s death was a major disappointment. Eminem and his longtime production partner Luis Resto handled the music for 13 of the 17 songs

But what is even more incredible is that the he had so many previously unreleased songs that Death Row Records and his mother Afeni Shakur’s Amaru Entertainment were able to release six posthumous solo albums that also generated millions of album sales.

After a three-and-a-half year break from releasing posthumous ‘Pac music, Amaru Entertainment dropped this double-CD, featuring production from some of Tupac’s best collaborators: Johnny “J,” QDIII, and L.T. Hutton. The music, recorded from 1995 to 1996, captures Tupac’s post-incarceration rage on songs like “Ballad of a Dead Soulja,” “F— Friendz,” and “U Don’t Have 2 Worry”; the latter addresses the enemies who tried to kill the rapper
report_en: Since Tupac’s 1996 death, his estate has drawn on a large vault of unreleased material to issue six official posthumous solo studio albums, which together have sold millions of copies [2]; the legal control sits mainly with his mother Afeni Shakur’s company, Amaru Entertainment, which administers Tupac’s recording assets, while Death Row Records retained rights to some masters, so the two entities jointly authorize releases [2]. Each project is assembled by contemporary producers or guest artists, which is why the credits look scattered: for example, the fifth post-death album had 13 of its 17 tracks rebuilt by Eminem and collaborator Luis Resto [1], while an earlier double-CD relied on longtime ‘Pac producers Johnny “J,” QDIII and L.T. Hutton, using vocals recorded in 1995-96 (“Ballad of a Dead Soulja,” “F— Friendz,” “U Don’t Have 2 Worry”) [3]. Thus, although the music features a rotating cast of modern contributors, the decision-making remains centralized with Amaru and, when applicable, Death Row, who license Tupac’s archived vocals and approve outside collaborations.

Hutton, using vocals recorded in 1995-96 (“Ballad of a Dead Soulja,” “F— Friendz,” “U Don’t Have 2 Worry”) [3].

Thus, although the music features a rotating cast of modern contributors, the decision-making remains centralized with Amaru and, when applicable, Death Row, who license Tupac’s archived vocals and approve outside collaborations.

question_en: Why does lying down reduce my urge to puke when I feel like puking?
pos_context_title_en: Nausea at Night: Causes, Treatment, Prevention (www.healthline.com)
What Could Be Causing Your Chronic Nausea? (www.verywellhealth.com)
pos_context_en: Prop your head up so you’re not lying flat in bed. If it’s comfortable for you, try to sleep with your head about 12 inches above your feet. This can help keep acid or food from moving up into your esophagus.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common condition that occurs when stomach contents come back up into the esophagus. This can cause symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and nausea.


Symptoms might be worse after eating or at night after lying down. The nausea may linger, especially if stomach acid backs up into the throat.
report_en: Lying down with your torso raised changes how gravity acts on your stomach: when the head is propped about 12 inches above the feet, the stomach sits lower than the esophagus, so acid and food are less able to wash upward and irritate the throat, a key trigger of the brain’s vomiting center [1]. Because a common source of persistent queasiness is gastroesophageal reflux, preventing this back-flow removes the chemical and mechanical stimulus that keeps the “I might puke” feeling alive [2]. Remaining still in a semi-reclined or side-lying position also steadies the inner-ear balance organs and lowers sympathetic nervous-system activity, both of which can intensify nausea. The combined reduction in esophageal irritation, vestibular motion, and stress signals explains why the urge to vomit often eases soon after you settle into bed with your head comfortably elevated.
all_claims: Lying down with your torso raised changes how gravity acts on your stomach: when the head is propped about 12 inches above the feet, the stomach sits lower than the esophagus, so acid and food are less able to wash upward and irritate the throat, a key trigger of the brain’s vomiting center [1].
Because a common source of persistent queasiness is gastroesophageal reflux, preventing this back-flow removes the chemical and mechanical stimulus that keeps the “I might puke” feeling alive [2].
Remaining still in a semi-reclined or side-lying position also steadies the inner-ear balance organs and lowers sympathetic nervous-system activity, both of which can intensify nausea.
The combined reduction in esophageal irritation, vestibular motion, and stress signals explains why the urge to vomit often eases soon after you settle into bed with your head comfortably elevated.

question_en: Why do some people dream deeply and vividly while others rarely remember theirs?
pos_context_title_en: Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Do Frequent Dreams and the Ability to Recall Them Indicate Depression? - Guardian Liberty Voice (guardianlv.com)
pos_context_en:
Basically, this theory suggests that dreams occur when our brain is processing information, eliminating the unnecessary stuff and moving important short-term memories into our long-term memory. So people who recall dreams may have a difference in their ability to memorize things in general.


Beyond that, a person’s brain may actually block out a dream so we don’t remember it the following day. “The dream activity can be so real and intense that our brains actually hide, or mask away the dream, so [it doesn’t] get lost between our waking experience, and our dream lives. Thus it is normal to forget dreams, most of the time.” Dimitriu says.

A study published in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology and reported by International Business Times suggested that those people who reported high dream recall had more activity in the temporoparietal junction than those who didn’t recall their dreams often.


Lambert tells Healthline that if someone consistently doesn’t get enough sleep, the amount of REM sleep they experience will drop, making it harder for them to remember their dreams the following day.


Even personality traits can be an indicator of whether someone will be able to remember their dreams.


Lambert continues: “Researchers also looked at the most common personality traits that are presented in people who can recall their dreams. Overall, such people are prone to daydreaming, creative thinking, and introspection. At the same time, those who are more practical and focused on what is outside themselves tend to have difficulty remembering their dreams.”


This may mean that some people are naturally more likely to recall their dreams than others, despite their quality of sleep.


Other factors, like stress or experiencing a trauma, can also cause people to have vivid dreams or nightmares that they’re more likely to recall the next day. For example, a person who’s coping with grief after losing a loved one may dream about the death in elaborate detail. Remembering the dream the next day may affect mood and cause even more stress or anxiety.

People who have the ability to recall their dreams five mornings per week, on average, have more spontaneous activity occurring in certain parts of their brains than others. The parts of the brain that host these increased levels of activity are called the temporo-parietal junction, which is an information-processing hub, and the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for the expression of personality as well as the planning of complex cognitive behaviors. And, interestingly, this escalation in liveliness is higher during both wakefulness and sleep, so says a study of 41 people recently published online February 19 in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology. The activity in the brains of the people in this study were measured by Positron Emission Tomography while they were awake and sleeping. What do these findings tell us?


In combination with previous research from one of the study’s authors, Perrine Ruby, the findings tell us why some people remember their dreams and some do not. Ruby co-authored related research that was published last year in the journal Cerebral Cortex, which showed that people who have the ability to regularly recall their dreams are also more reactive to sounds when they are both asleep and awake. Ruby made some comments in a recent statement that synthesized the findings for both of these studies. Ruby stated that the brain needs to awaken from sleep in order to memorize new information. This, said Ruby, may explain the reason that those who react more to environmental stimuli can remember their dreams better; they simply are awakened more often and can therefore better encode into memory their dreams than others who are less reactive to sounds. In addition, the researchers said that people who often recall their dreams may also have more dreams than “low-recall” dreamers.
report_en: People who consistently recall vivid dreams show 30-40 % more spontaneous activity in the temporo-parietal junction and prefrontal cortex—regions that process information and plan behaviour—both while awake and asleep, which may generate richer dream content and better storage of it in memory [3]. Frequent dreamers also react more strongly to external sounds, causing micro-awakenings that allow the brain to encode the dream before it is masked by later waking experiences [3]. By contrast, the brain can deliberately “hide” intense dream material, so most sleepers forget it the next day [1]. Sleep habits matter: chronic sleep restriction shortens REM periods, reducing opportunities both to dream and to recall dreams the following morning [2]. Personality adds another layer—people inclined to day-dreaming, creativity, and introspection remember dreams more, whereas pragmatic, externally focused individuals usually do not [2]. Finally, acute stress or trauma can intensify and therefore imprint dreams, making them easier to remember, while low emotional arousal leaves little trace [2].
all_claims: People who consistently recall vivid dreams show 30-40 % more spontaneous activity in the temporo-parietal junction and prefrontal cortex—regions that process information and plan behaviour—both while awake and asleep, which may generate richer dream content and better storage of it in memory [3].
Frequent dreamers also react more strongly to external sounds, causing micro-awakenings that allow the brain to encode the dream before it is masked by later waking experiences [3].
By contrast, the brain can deliberately “hide” intense dream material, so most sleepers forget it the next day [1].
Sleep habits matter: chronic sleep restriction shortens REM periods, reducing opportunities both to dream and to recall dreams the following morning [2].
Personality adds another layer—people inclined to day-dreaming, creativity, and introspection remember dreams more, whereas pragmatic, externally focused individuals usually do not [2].
Finally, acute stress or trauma can intensify and therefore imprint dreams, making them easier to remember, while low emotional arousal leaves little trace [2].

Frequent dreamers also react more strongly to external sounds, causing micro-awakenings that allow the brain to encode the dream before it is masked by later waking experiences [3].

question_en: Explain: The security implications Microsoft's "golden key" backdoor, present in all copies of Windows since Windows 8.
pos_context_title_en: 1.4 UEFI... The Microsoft Kill Switch (www.learnlinuxandlibreoffice.org)
Microsoft Leaks Secure Boot Key, Raises Security Concerns (www.informationweek.com)
pos_context_en:
As if the insanity of handing the keys to our computers over to Microsoft was not bad enough, in June 2016, two computer security researchers discovered that Microsoft was doing some rather reckless things with these Golden Keys. Microsoft developers wanted to make changes to certain devices without going through the hassle of getting authorized keys to Secure Boot. So they developed a secret “super policy” for bypassing Secure Boot completely. Had this Golden Key “super policy” been discovered by hackers it would have given them unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world. The only good news to this story is that this backdoor nuclear weapon was discovered by “Good Guy” researchers before it was discovered by Bad Guy hackers. https://www.infoworld.com/article/3106079/security/secure-boot-proves-insecurity-of-backdoors.html


After the researchers notified Microsoft of the issue, the company released a security patch MS16-094 in July 2016. This “golden key” super policy is now blocked from loading on computers with the July patch installed. However, the July patch is not a complete fix -- it's at most a small roadblock. The issue remains only partially addressed, and what's worse, it is believed that it is impossible for Microsoft to fully revoke the leaked Golden Key Super policy.


[Image: 1.4.09]


Because of the implications of this Golden Key Backdoor being released to the wild, the two researchers wrote a letter to the FBI explaining why the entire concept of having super keys to all computers was a bad idea:


“Microsoft implemented a 'secure golden key' system. And the golden keys got released by Microsoft's own stupidity. Now, what happens if you tell everyone to make a 'secure golden key' system? This is a perfect real-world example about why your idea of backdooring cryptosystems with a 'golden key' is very bad!”


The first lesson we should learn from the 2016 Golden Key incident is that keys and secrets will eventually get leaked or stolen. The second lesson is that a fix is not always possible.

Microsoft is causing major cyber-security concerns with the accidental leak of a "golden key" intended to protect devices equipped with Secure Boot.


The Secure Boot feature is intended to protect Windows devices by making sure they only use software trusted by the PC maker or user. It's part of Microsoft's Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and ensures each component loaded during the boot process is validated.


The all-access keys were discovered by MY123 and Slipstream in March 2016. A recent blog post (animated site with tinny, arcade-style music) by researchers at MY123 and Slipstream dives into the details of Microsoft's security problems and the errors it made in addressing them.


[Google: QuadRooter threat is blocked on most Android devices.]


Note that the golden key isn't an actual key, but a means of changing the tasks launched by UEFI during the boot process, as explained in a report by Ars Technica. The policy has been made available online. It will enable anyone to disable the Secure Boot feature.


Secure Boot can be disabled on several types of desktop PCs, but is hard-coded into most devices running Windows. It seems the golden key is intended to turn off OS checks so programmers can test new projects. However, it can also leave Windows devices vulnerable.


The keys leaked by Microsoft will allow users with admin rights to install any operating system -- like Linux or Android -- on their Windows PCs, smartphones, or tablets.
report_en: Since Windows 8, every PC, tablet and phone that boots with Microsoft’s Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot contains a Microsoft-signed “golden key” policy originally meant for internal testing [2]. When this policy leaked in 2016, researchers showed it can completely disable Secure Boot, the mechanism that normally verifies each boot component, thereby removing the protection that prevents untrusted or malicious code from loading at power-on [2]. With Secure Boot defeated, an attacker with administrative access can install or boot any operating system or kernel, rootkit, or pre-boot malware, gaining persistent and stealthy control that even a full reinstallation of Windows may not eradicate [2]. Because the leaked policy is digitally signed, Microsoft cannot fully revoke it without also revoking its own root keys, so the July 2016 patch MS16-094 only blocks the specific policy file and is considered “at most a small roadblock” rather than a complete fix [1]. This means the vulnerability is effectively permanent across millions of devices, illustrating how a single compromised backdoor key can grant “unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world” and why backdoors pose catastrophic systemic risk [1].
all_claims: Since Windows 8, every PC, tablet and phone that boots with Microsoft’s Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) Secure Boot contains a Microsoft-signed “golden key” policy originally meant for internal testing [2].

When this policy leaked in 2016, researchers showed it can completely disable Secure Boot, the mechanism that normally verifies each boot component, thereby removing the protection that prevents untrusted or malicious code from loading at power-on [2].

With Secure Boot defeated, an attacker with administrative access can install or boot any operating system or kernel, rootkit, or pre-boot malware, gaining persistent and stealthy control that even a full reinstallation of Windows may not eradicate [2].

Because the leaked policy is digitally signed, Microsoft cannot fully revoke it without also revoking its own root keys, so the July 2016 patch MS16-094 only blocks the specific policy file and is considered “at most a small roadblock” rather than a complete fix [1].

This means the vulnerability is effectively permanent across millions of devices, illustrating how a single compromised backdoor key can grant “unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world” and why backdoors pose catastrophic systemic risk [1].

With Secure Boot defeated, an attacker with administrative access can install or boot any operating system or kernel, rootkit, or pre-boot malware, gaining persistent and stealthy control that even a full reinstallation of Windows may not eradicate [2].

Because the leaked policy is digitally signed, Microsoft cannot fully revoke it without also revoking its own root keys, so the July 2016 patch MS16-094 only blocks the specific policy file and is considered “at most a small roadblock” rather than a complete fix [1].

This means the vulnerability is effectively permanent across millions of devices, illustrating how a single compromised backdoor key can grant “unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world” and why backdoors pose catastrophic systemic risk [1].

question_en: What keeps the oceans from flooding the earth?
pos_context_title_en: All About the Ocean (www.nationalgeographic.org)
Oceans. Formation of the Oceans. Facts about the Oceans (encyclopedia.lubopitko-bg.com)
The Water Cycle (oceantoday.noaa.gov)
pos_context_en:
After the Earth began to form about 4.6 billion years ago, it gradually separated into layers of lighter and heavier rock. The lighter rock rose and formed the Earth’s crust. The heavier rock sank and formed the Earth’s core and mantle.


The ocean’s water came from rocks inside the newly forming Earth. As the molten rocks cooled, they released water vapor and other gases. Eventually, the water vapor condensed and covered the crust with a primitive ocean. Today, hot gases from the Earth’s interior continue to produce new water at the bottom of the ocean.

The largest features of the Earth's surface are the continents and ocean basins. The four major ocean basins (Arctic, Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific) are bound by landmasses and major oceanic ridges. Each continent is rimmed by a submerged, gently sloping continental margin. This includes the relatively flat continental shelf, generally found at depths of less than 600 feet (183 meters) with a width of a few miles to more than 200 miles (322 kilometers). At the shelf break portion of the margin, there is a rise in the continental shelf before the continental slope begins its plunge to the deep-sea bottom. Deep submarine canyons frequently cut into the continental margin.

Over 96% of total global water is in the ocean, so let’s start there. Energy from the sun causes water on the surface to evaporate into water vapor – a gas. This invisible vapor rises into the atmosphere, where the air is colder, and condenses into clouds. Air currents move these clouds all around the earth.


Water drops form in clouds, and the drops then return to the ocean or land as precipitation - let’s say this time, it’s snow. The snow will fall to the ground, and eventually melts back into a liquid and runs off into a lake or river, which flows back into the ocean, where it starts the process again.
report_en: The oceans do not submerge the continents because most seawater is trapped in deep, bowl-shaped ocean basins whose edges are bordered by elevated landmasses and major oceanic ridges; beyond the gently sloping continental shelf, the seafloor plunges down the continental slope to depths far below average land elevation, effectively confining the water [2]. Solar energy then powers the water cycle: roughly 96 % of Earth’s water resides in the ocean, where it continually evaporates into the atmosphere; precipitation later deposits this water on land, and meltwater or runoff eventually drains back to the basins, preventing any long-term accumulation that could drown the continents [3].
all_claims: The oceans do not submerge the continents because most seawater is trapped in deep, bowl-shaped ocean basins whose edges are bordered by elevated landmasses and major oceanic ridges; beyond the gently sloping continental shelf, the seafloor plunges down the continental slope to depths far below average land elevation, effectively confining the water [2].

Solar energy then powers the water cycle: roughly 96 % of Earth’s water resides in the ocean, where it continually evaporates into the atmosphere; precipitation later deposits this water on land, and meltwater or runoff eventually drains back to the basins, preventing any long-term accumulation that could drown the continents [3].

question_en: Why are items always priced ending in ".99" instead of ".00"?
pos_context_title_en: The Real Reason Most Prices End in .99 (www.rd.com)
Why Do Most Prices End in .99? (www.livescience.com)
pos_context_en:
Prices are more likely to end in .99 more than any other pair of numbers—and certainly more than the even .00. We probably don’t think twice about buying something for $5.99 or $16.99, but it is a little strange when you think about it. Why aren’t prices just even dollar amounts? Is it an elaborate marketing scheme to get you to spend more?

Well, essentially…yes. But there’s really nothing “elaborate” about it; it’s actually pretty simple. “It’s a type of psychological pricing,” says Julie Ramhold, consumer analyst with DealNews.com. “Because we read from left to right, we pay less attention to the end of the number versus the beginning.” This is especially effective if you’re just quickly perusing several prices in a row; the first number will definitely stand out to you more. Psychological pricing is powerful, but luckily, there are also plenty of psychology tricks to help you spend less while shopping.

Of course, we still know that $9.99 is basically ten dollars, not nine dollars. But the $.99 trick takes advantage of the way our brains process prices. When we see a price of $9.99, we associate it as part of the $9–$9.99 “range” rather than the $10–$10.99 “range.” “Consumers don’t want to transcend a certain category, so even a penny less may make a huge psychological difference,” explains Subimal Chatterjee, Distinguished Teaching Professor of Marketing at Binghamton University School of Management.

Ending a price in .99 is based on the theory that, because we read from left to right, the first digit of the price resonates with us the most, Hibbett explained. That's why shoppers are more likely to buy a product for $4.99 than an identical one for $5 the item that starts with a 4 just seems like a better deal than the one that starts with 5.

"We also tend to attempt to reduce the amount of effort expended on making product decisions, especially with lower-cost items," Hibbett told Life's Little Mysteries. "So we may not really process the numbers after the dollar amount."

Additionally, the .99 alone serves to make an item appear to be on sale, according to the article "Mind Your Pricing Cues," published in the September 2003 issue of the Harvard Business Review. Price-conscious consumers have become conditioned to believe that they are getting a good deal when they buy something with a price ending in .99 even if the markdown is minimal.
report_en: Retailers price items at .99 primarily to exploit a psychological quirk called the left-digit effect: because we read numbers left to right, the first digit dominates our perception, so $9.99 is grouped with $9 rather than $10, and even a one-cent drop can make a “huge psychological difference” [1]. This shortcut also reduces the mental effort people devote to small purchases, so shoppers often overlook the cents entirely and focus on the lower leading digit [2]. Moreover, decades of exposure have turned the “.99” suffix into a built-in discount signal, making customers assume the item is on sale even when the reduction is minimal [2]. These combined biases raise sales while costing the seller only a penny, which is why .99 endings prevail over neat .00 prices.

question_en: My mom just told me most stocks don't pay dividends. Is this the case? If so why does the stock market even exist, did we all just agree to make a gambling arena where we bet on others betting on what we bet on? And if so why does how well the company does matter to stockholders?
pos_context_title_en: How and When Are Stock Dividends Paid Out? (www.investopedia.com)
Do All Stocks Have Dividends? (Why Don’t Some Stocks Pay Dividends?) (therobusttrader.com)
Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Going All-In: Investing vs. Gambling (www.investopedia.com)
pos_context_en: A dividend is the distribution of some of a company's earnings to a class of its shareholders. Dividends are usually paid in the form of a dividend check. However, they may also be paid in additional shares of stock. The standard practice for the payment of dividends is a check that is mailed to stockholders a few days after the ex-dividend date, which is the date on which the stock starts trading without the previously declared dividend.

All stocks do not pay a dividend. Profitable companies’ managers have the option of either compensating shareholders directly (through a dividend), or investing back into the company to fuel growth and increase the value of the company. Because of this, investors have the option to either go for dividend-paying stocks or stocks which emphasize growth over shareholder compensation.

Gambling, trading, speculation, and investment are perceived in very different ways but they have two core similarities. First, they all involve risking money in hopes of a positive return. Second, the results are dependent in part on luck.

A number of distinctions between the various endeavors are usually drawn. Gambling is typically viewed as a form of entertainment that carries a higher level of risk and has a less certain outcome. Speculation and investment are generally viewed as business enterprises in which risk is understood and steps are taking to mitigate and manage it.

True, investing and gambling both involve risk and choice—specifically, the risk of capital with hopes of future profit. But gambling is typically a short-lived activity, while equities investing can last a lifetime. Also, there is a negative expected return to gamblers, on average and over the long run. On the other hand, investing in the stock market typically carries with it a positive expected return on average over the long run.
report_en: Your mom is partly right: many publicly traded companies choose not to distribute cash, so a large share of stocks have no current dividend because managers can either compensate shareholders or reinvest earnings to fuel growth [2]. When a firm does decide to share profits, the standard method is to declare a dividend and send checks (or additional shares) to investors a few days after the ex-dividend date [1]. The stock market exists chiefly to let companies raise capital and to give investors ownership stakes whose value rises if the business performs well; even without dividends, retained earnings that expand revenue and profits generally lift the stock price, allowing shareholders to realize gains when they sell. Unlike casino wagers, equities have historically offered a positive expected return over long horizons because real businesses create enduring economic value, whereas gambling produces a negative expected return for players on average [5]. Company performance matters because stronger profits either fund future dividends or increase the price others are willing to pay for your shares.

When a firm does decide to share profits, the standard method is to declare a dividend and send checks (or additional shares) to investors a few days after the ex-dividend date [1].

The stock market exists chiefly to let companies raise capital and to give investors ownership stakes whose value rises if the business performs well; even without dividends, retained earnings that expand revenue and profits generally lift the stock price, allowing shareholders to realize gains when they sell.

Unlike casino wagers, equities have historically offered a positive expected return over long horizons because real businesses create enduring economic value, whereas gambling produces a negative expected return for players on average [5].
Company performance matters because stronger profits either fund future dividends or increase the price others are willing to pay for your shares.

question_en: How does Snap Chat work? I'm not getting the information I'm curious about in previous posts.
pos_context_title_en: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
pos_context_en: Snapchat uses end-to-end encryption on photos shared between its users. Text messages and other messages sent on Snapchat aren’t protected by the same encryption. Snapchat doesn’t disclose much information about the type of encryption that it uses, so it can be difficult to truly understand what happens to your messages once they get to Snap’s servers.

Don’t Let People Find You with Your Mobile Number: Snapchat settings allow you to toggle whether or not other users can find your Snapchat account using your mobile number. If you are concerned about privacy, you should turn this feature off. If you use your personal cell phone number for work purposes, or have your phone number published anywhere online, turning this off can protect you from an unwanted flood of unknown people adding you as a friend.

The truth is, however, that whenever a user opens the Snapchat app, their location is shared on the Snap Map. Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.

When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.
report_en: Snapchat opens straight to the camera so you can shoot a photo or video (“Snap”) and send it to friends; those images are end-to-end encrypted, but text and other messages are not, and Snap does not reveal the exact encryption scheme it uses [1]. Whenever you launch the app your location is uploaded to Snap’s servers and placed on the Snap Map, accurate enough for someone to identify an exact street address, unless you change settings or turn on Ghost Mode to hide it [3]. People can add you by searching your username, scanning your Snapcode, or syncing phone contacts; if you list a mobile number, anyone who has that number stored may see you in “People you may know,” but you can toggle this off in settings to stay harder to find [2]. Reports of “random” adds are often due to automated bot accounts that follow users en masse, wait for a reciprocal add, then drop the connection to inflate follower counts [4].

question_en: PayPal, how it works, if it's trustworthy/worthwhile and should I get it?
pos_context_title_en: How Does PayPal Work? [Step-by-Step Guide For Sellers] (www.x-cart.com)
How Does PayPal Work? - NerdWallet (www.nerdwallet.com)
Instant Money Transfer to Bank Account & Debit Card | PayPal US (www.paypal.com)
How Does PayPal Work for Sellers? (yourbusiness.azcentral.com)
Getting paid with PayPal (www.ebay.com)
pos_context_en: PayPal’s website is fully-encrypted, allowing your customers to make online purchases in a secure way.

Fees: $0 to make a purchase or transfer money domestically using a bank account or your PayPal balance. 2.9% of the amount, plus 30 cents, to transfer funds using a credit card, debit card, or PayPal credit.

Transfer limits: Varies, $4,000-$60,000 per transaction.

### Instant Transfer


If time is of the essence, move money now from PayPal to your eligible bank account or debit card for a fee.


### Standard Transfer


If your money can wait, get it in 1-3 business days at no additional cost.

There are three primary types of PayPal account, and sellers can accept payments with any of them. A Personal account allows a seller to receive payments from other PayPal users, but has a withdrawal limit of $500 per month. Connecting a bank account or credit card allows a seller to upgrade to a Premier account, which removes this limit and offers the ability to accept credit and debit card payments as well. A Business account is the same as a Premier account, but allows access by multiple users. The standard fee for selling via PayPal is 2.9 percent plus 30 cents per transaction.

You need a Paypal account in order to use PayPal to receive payment for eBay sales. If you don’t have an account, we’ll ask you to sign up when you create your first listing.


When you create a listing, select PayPal as a payment method and enter the email address associated with your PayPal account in the Payment options section of the listing form.


Remember, if you offer PayPal as a payment option on eBay (using either logos or text in the item description), you must accept all forms of PayPal payment, including payments from an existing PayPal account balance, bank account transfers, and credit card payments. You can’t tell buyers that you only accept specific forms of PayPal payment. See the Payment methods policy for more information. When a buyer sends you a payment through PayPal, the money is usually available in your PayPal account right away.
report_en: PayPal is an online payment service that lets you open a free account linked to an email address and a bank account or card so you can send or receive money without exposing your financial details [4]. Personal, Premier and Business accounts differ mainly in withdrawal limits and multi-user access; for example, a Personal account caps withdrawals at $500 per month until you link a bank or card and upgrade [4]. Making a purchase or domestic transfer using your bank balance costs nothing, but paying with a credit or debit card incurs 2.9% + $0.30 per transaction [2], which is also the standard fee sellers pay when they accept PayPal payments [4]. You can move funds out instantly to an eligible bank or debit card for a small fee, or wait 1–3 business days for a free standard transfer [3]. Individual transactions can range from $4,000 to $60,000, depending on your account history and currency [2]. The site is fully encrypted, providing a secure checkout for buyers and sellers alike [1]. On platforms like eBay, PayPal is widely accepted and funds usually appear in your account right away [5]. Overall, PayPal’s broad acceptance, solid security and flexible transfers make it worthwhile for most online shoppers and casual sellers, though frequent high-value card payments could make fees add up.

question_en: the US presidential electoral system. I do not get it.
pos_context_title_en: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
pos_context_en:
After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.
The Founding Fathers created the Electoral College system as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by the popular vote of qualified citizens.

When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.

Each state gets a number of electors equal to its number of members in the U.S. House of Representatives plus one for each of its two U.S. senators. The District of Columbia gets three electors.﻿﻿ State laws determine how electors are chosen, but they are generally selected by the political party committees within the states.


Each elector gets one vote. Thus, a state with eight electors would cast eight votes. As of the 1964 election, there are 538 electors, and the votes of a majority of them—270—are required to be elected.﻿﻿ Because Electoral College representation is based on congressional representation, states with larger populations get more Electoral College votes.
report_en: The U.S. does not directly elect its president by nationwide popular vote; instead it uses the Electoral College, a body of 538 electors allocated to states by the size of their congressional delegations—House seats plus two senators, with the District of Columbia receiving three electors [4]. When you mark a ballot for a presidential candidate, you are actually selecting a slate of electors pledged to that candidate, who will meet in mid-December to cast the official votes for president and vice-president [3]. Most states—48 plus Washington, D.C.—award all their electors to the statewide popular-vote winner, while Maine and Nebraska split them proportionally, so winning a state by one vote can deliver every elector there [1]. To win the presidency, a candidate must secure an absolute majority, at least 270 of the 538 electoral votes [1]. Although the Constitution permits electors to vote otherwise, many states legally bind them and can fine or replace so-called “faithless” electors [1]. Thus, the national popular vote guides but does not formally decide the outcome.

Although the Constitution permits electors to vote otherwise, many states legally bind them and can fine or replace so-called “faithless” electors [1].
Thus, the national popular vote guides but does not formally decide the outcome.

question_en: if and how a greater volume of almonds could have significantly less calories with cinnamon and sugar added (nutrition facts photo in text)
pos_context_title_en: New Study Reveals Fewer Calories in Almonds | Food Network Healthy Eats: Recipes, Ideas, and Food News | Food Network (www.foodnetwork.com)
New Study Reveals Fewer Calories in Almonds | Food Network Healthy Eats: Recipes, Ideas, and Food News | Food Network (www.foodnetwork.com)
Almonds Have 20% Fewer Calories Than Thought, Based On Research (www.womenshealthmag.com)
The Skinny on Almond Calories (www.almonds.com)
pos_context_en:
A new study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition found that almonds have 20% fewer calories than originally thought. The results found that a one-ounce serving of almonds (about 23 nuts) has 129 calories as opposed to 160 that’s currently listed on the Nutrition Facts Panel.


Interestingly, it has nothing to do with the composition of the almond—rather, the way we metabolize it.

several studies published over the past 10 years have suggested that when people eat almonds, not all of the fat is digested and absorbed. Some of the fat remains intact within the almonds’ rigid cell walls. Recognizing that this could affect the number of calories actually available from almonds, researchers at USDA's Agricultural Research Service decided to specifically determine the calories absorbed. We were not at all surprised to learn from Dr. Baer’s work that fewer calories from almonds are available for absorption. However, we were pleasantly surprised by the magnitude of the difference. In 2011, Dr. Baer conducted research using the same methodology to find out available calories from pistachios and found that the number was only 5% lower than previously thought, while the number for almonds was 20% lower.

Why the change in almonds and cashews? The difference in the calorie counts is because research found your body doesn’t actually break down and use all of the calories that are in nuts, explains Alissa Rumsey, RD, nutrition therapist and owner of Alissa Rumsey Nutrition and Wellness. “This concept is called bioavailability,” she says. “Basically, just because nutrients are present in a food, that doesn’t automatically mean that the body will readily use them. Therefore fewer calories may actually be absorbed.”

The resulting data from this new study showed that, with the exception of almond butter, all of the almond forms analyzed provide fewer calories than is listed on packages:


[Image: almond nutrients]


Wondering why the discrepancy in calories? Mechanical processes, such as roasting, chopping and grinding play a role because they disrupt the cell wall of almonds and affect particle size. Particle size is also affected when almonds are chewed and digested in the body. The larger the particle size, the less the almond is broken down by digestive enzymes and the more of the almond is excreted, so fewer calories are absorbed. The reverse is also true: the smaller the particle size, the more calories are absorbed. Further research is needed to better understand the results of this study and how this method of measuring calories could potentially affect the calorie count of other foods.
report_en: A USDA-funded trial showed that a one-ounce (28 g) serving of whole almonds provides only 129 kcal—about 20 % fewer than the 160 kcal on current labels—because a portion of their fat stays trapped within rigid cell walls and passes through the body undigested [1]. The study also found that the larger the almond particles that survive chewing (as with whole or simply roasted nuts), the fewer calories are absorbed, whereas finer grinding increases calorie availability [4]. Consequently, you can pour a “greater volume” of intact almonds (they pack loosely and contain air gaps) without proportionally raising metabolizable energy. If that same 28 g portion is merely dusted with cinnamon and 4 g of sugar (≈16 kcal), the flavoring adds little, so the snack delivers roughly 145 kcal (129 kcal from almonds + 16 kcal from sugar), still well below the 176 kcal you might expect from traditional Nutrition Facts. Thus, almonds’ reduced bioavailable calories, coupled with a light cinnamon-sugar coating, explain how a larger-looking serving can legitimately contain significantly fewer usable calories.
all_claims: A USDA-funded trial showed that a one-ounce (28 g) serving of whole almonds provides only 129 kcal—about 20 % fewer than the 160 kcal on current labels—because a portion of their fat stays trapped within rigid cell walls and passes through the body undigested [1].

The study also found that the larger the almond particles that survive chewing (as with whole or simply roasted nuts), the fewer calories are absorbed, whereas finer grinding increases calorie availability [4].

question_en: If caught. What would the Ashley Madison hacker(s) likely be charged with?
pos_context_title_en: The Infamous Ashley Madison Hack: What Exactly Happened? (darkwebjournal.com)
Ashley Madison: Who are the hackers behind the attack? (www.bbc.com)
Hacking Laws and Punishments - FindLaw (www.findlaw.com)
Ultimate Guide to U.S. Hacking Laws - Federal Lawyer (federal-lawyer.com)
pos_context_en: Tragically, two suicides were traced to the hack, one of a pastor and professor at the New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary.
There is no evidence of the group stealing data elsewhere before it announced itself with the Ashley Madison attack on 15 July.

Accessing a Computer to Defraud and Obtain Value


5 years; 10 years maximum for a second conviction.

Accessing a Computer and Obtaining Information


1-5 years; 10 years maximum for a second conviction.1-10 years; 20 years maximum for a second conviction.
While criminal defenses in federal cases are highly fact-specific, some examples of the types of defenses that can be used to avoid prosecution, conviction, and sentencing for hacking crimes include:
report_en: The individuals behind the Ashley Madison breach would almost certainly face federal Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) counts for “accessing a computer and obtaining information” and for “accessing a computer to defraud and obtain value,” each punishable by up to five years’ imprisonment for a first conviction and up to ten years for a second conviction [3]. Because millions of user records were copied and released, prosecutors could file multiple CFAA counts with conspiracy enhancements, stacking potential sentences well beyond a decade. The threat to dump the data unless the company shut down fits the federal extortion statute, and the use or distribution of stolen credentials could add aggravated identity-theft and wire-fraud charges. A likely indictment would therefore list: conspiracy, unauthorized access to obtain information, unauthorized access to defraud and obtain value, extortion, wire fraud, and aggravated identity theft. Defendants might attempt fact-specific defenses common in hacking cases—such as disputing intent, claiming some level of authorization, or challenging the valuation of the “value” obtained—but their success is uncertain [4].

question_en: What would happen to my body if I were trapped somewhere with a reliable water supply but no food
pos_context_title_en: How Long Can You Live Without Food? Effects of Starvation (www.healthline.com)
pos_context_en: the body can survive for 8 to 21 days without food and water and up to two months if there’s access to an adequate water intake.
report_en: With a steady water supply but no food, your body would first burn stored glucose and glycogen within about 24 hours, then shift to breaking down fat for energy over the next several weeks; as fat reserves dwindle, it would catabolize muscle and organ protein, causing progressive weight loss, weakness, immune suppression, slowed heart rate, and mental fog, and you could survive anywhere from roughly 8 days up to about 60 days, with the upper limit depending on your initial fat and muscle stores, overall health, and ambient temperature, because the human body can last “up to two months if there’s access to an adequate water intake” [1].

question_en: FB posts baiting people to "share if you see x" or "Little Timmy has Cancer and will live with 1M Likes" or the easy puzzles designed to stroke your ego and post the answer. Does anyone make money from this?
pos_context_title_en: Social Media Engagement: Why It's Important and How To Do It Well - The Buffer Blog (buffer.com)
Social Media Engagement: Why It's Important and How To Do It Well - The Buffer Blog (buffer.com)
What Is Engagement on Social Media? - Social Buddy (socialbuddy.com)
Users are buying and selling Instagram accounts for their follower counts (www.vox.com)
Users are buying and selling Instagram accounts for their follower counts (www.vox.com)
pos_context_en:
Organic reach has dropped on almost every social media platform in recent years. However, accounts with higher social media engagement are the least affected. In fact, Facebook uses “meaningful engagement” as an important signal that a post should be prioritized.


In other words, social media posts with more active and thoughtful interactions will get more reach.

Not only is responding a good practice to get into, it can also impact your revenue as Southern Elegance Candle Co. founder and CEO D’Shawn Russell told us:


“Our social media makes us a lot of money… We went from doing maybe $20,000-30,000 a month just posting pretty images to well over a $100,000 a month now simply by engaging people more."

Social media engagement goes both ways: if you like and comment on other users’ posts, they’ll be more likely to do the same on yours. Engaging with other users can help grow your social media presence, as they will reciprocate engagement and it may also help you find new followers and accounts similar to your own.


Businesses, especially, should work to engage with followers. Answering their comments and questions will improve brand loyalty and show that your business is run by real people who care about customers. Encourage customer or follower feedback by asking questions in captions and responding to their comments, messages, and questions.

Habibie is just one of the 4,503 members of “Buy Sell or Exchange” trying to buy or sell social media accounts. The page is full of screenshots of various accounts, with posters detailing the number of followers they have and the price they’re asking for the account. While the Facebook page sells multiple forms of social media (per its name), Instagram accounts are by far the most common offering.

He had started out trying to build a large following on Instagram in order to promote his music, when others began offering to pay him to post shoutouts to their music accounts on his Instagram Stories, a common practice for musicians. As he learned more about the money to be made on Instagram, a mentor taught him how to sell accounts, and his business took off from there.
report_en: Yes—while a plea to “share if you care” seems harmless, the extra likes, comments and shares boost a page’s “meaningful engagement,” so Facebook’s algorithm shows that page to more users, expanding its organic reach at no cost [1]; once a large, reactive audience is built, owners can monetize it through sponsored posts, product sales or affiliate links. For instance, Southern Elegance Candle Co. saw revenue jump from roughly $20-30 k to more than $100 k per month simply by getting followers to interact more, proving that engagement directly translates into sales opportunities [2]. High-engagement pages themselves become assets: online marketplaces openly list Facebook and Instagram accounts for sale, with prices tied to follower counts and activity levels [4]. Some operators first bait engagement, then flip the account or charge others for “shout-outs,” a model one entrepreneur used to turn his music page into a business selling accounts and paid promotions [5]. In short, engagement-bait posts are a cheap way to manufacture attention, and that attention can be sold—either through direct commerce, advertising deals or by cashing out the page itself—so yes, people do make real money from them.

question_en: how does my phone know when I'm sleeping?
pos_context_title_en: How does my phone know, when I am in the deep sleep? (docs.sleep.urbandroid.org)
Tracking sleep with your phone (exist.io)
Tracking sleep with your phone (exist.io)
How Does Fitbit Track Sleep and What is the Fitbit Sleep Score? | Fitbit Health Solutions (healthsolutions.fitbit.com)
pos_context_en: The phone has an accelerometer sensor build in which is very sensitive and if placed in your bed we have a record of your movement over the nigh. In deep sleep your muscular movements are suppressed (otherwise you would be running or jumping around according to your dreams :)) and thus in this phase the sleep graph gets nearly flat.

There are plenty of options for sleep-tracking apps, and a couple of the most popular apps have recently expanded to cover both iOS and Android. For most of these apps, you'll need to leave them running and place your phone on your mattress near your pillow so they can detect your movement during the night.

The problem with this is that your movement can snap your sleep-tracker out of sleep mode (has happened to me many times) or your movement can be tracked as restless sleep when in fact you're up out of bed completely, grabbing a drink.

While you’re sleeping, your device tracks the beat-to-beat changes in your heart rate, known as heart rate variability (HRV). These numbers fluctuate as you transition between light sleep, deep sleep, and REM sleep stages.
report_en: Your phone infers that you’re asleep by logging motion with its built-in accelerometer while a sleep-tracking app runs; you place the handset on the mattress near your pillow, and the app watches for extended stretches with little or no movement to flag sleep onset and depth [2]. The accelerometer is sensitive enough to capture each small jolt as you turn over, so when muscle activity drops and the motion graph flattens, the software marks these intervals as deep sleep because suppressed muscles cause minimal bed movement [1]. Conversely, spikes in acceleration—such as getting up for a drink—are interpreted as wakefulness, which can occasionally lead to misclassification if the phone senses movement that isn’t you in bed [3]. Some newer phones or paired wearables also analyse beat-to-beat heart-rate variability; predictable HRV patterns across light, deep, and REM stages give the app another biometric cue to confirm you’re sleeping and identify specific stages [4].

question_en: As a person with astigmatism, why is it when I squint my eyes a little I can see a little clearer?
pos_context_title_en: Why Can I See Better When I Squint My Eyes? - Grosinger, Spigelman & Grey (www.eyemichigan.com)
Why Do I See Better When I Squint? (www.invision2020.com)
Vision Hack: How to See Clearly Without Your Glasses or Contacts (vision-and-hearing.wonderhowto.com)
Cornell Center for Materials Research (www.ccmr.cornell.edu)
pos_context_en:
What Does Squinting Do to Your Eye?


Even though it doesn’t feel much different, squinting does three things to our eyes that lead to slightly clearer vision.


* Our Eye Lens Changes Shape – The lens of the eye is flexible and changes shape when we squint.
* The Eye Lens Adjusts – Small adjustments in the lens allow us to focus better, much like a camera.
* Less Light Enters the Eye – Less light enters, reducing the impact on the retina and allowing the object we view to look sharper.

A small amount of the increased clarity of vision is due to changing the shape of the eye as you squint. However, the main optical principle at work, and one that is quite fascinating, is called the “pinhole effect”. Clear vision is a result of light rays that properly focused on the retina located in the back of the eye. Typically, this is done with glasses or contact lenses; both of which bend light into focus and therefore correct vision.


When we squint it creates the same effect as looking through a pinhole. Basically only a small amount of focused central light rays are allowed into the eye. This prevents the unfocused light rays in the periphery from reaching the retina. The result is better vision. Photographers understand this as “depth of field”.

The reason that squinting helps you see is because it changes the shape of your eye, making the pupil smaller, thus letting less light in and making an image clear. This is similar to the way a larger aperture works; a smaller hole in your camera lets less light in, with better focus.

By limiting the rays of light that come in through the bottom and top of the pupil, squinting allows rays to pass closer to the center of the lens, thereby creating a more focused image. So, that means that squinting works by two mechanisms – by both changing the shape of the eye and by letting in light that can be focused more precisely by the lens.
report_en: When you have astigmatism, the cornea or lens is slightly rugby-ball shaped, so incoming light is bent unequally and forms a smeared image on the retina. Squinting narrows your eyelids so only the central, most direct light rays enter, mimicking a pinhole camera; the unfocused peripheral rays that normally exaggerate the blur are blocked, so the image appears sharper [2]. It also makes the pupil effectively smaller and forces light to pass through the center of the eye’s lens where optical imperfections are minimal, further tightening focus [4]. At the same time the tiny extra effort of squinting flexes the lens, fine-tuning its curvature and giving a small additional boost in focus similar to adjusting a camera lens [1]. Together these effects temporarily compensate for the distorted optics of astigmatism, giving you noticeably clearer vision until you relax your lids.
all_claims: When you have astigmatism, the cornea or lens is slightly rugby-ball shaped, so incoming light is bent unequally and forms a smeared image on the retina.

Squinting narrows your eyelids so only the central, most direct light rays enter, mimicking a pinhole camera; the unfocused peripheral rays that normally exaggerate the blur are blocked, so the image appears sharper [2].
It also makes the pupil effectively smaller and forces light to pass through the center of the eye’s lens where optical imperfections are minimal, further tightening focus [4].
At the same time the tiny extra effort of squinting flexes the lens, fine-tuning its curvature and giving a small additional boost in focus similar to adjusting a camera lens [1].
Together these effects temporarily compensate for the distorted optics of astigmatism, giving you noticeably clearer vision until you relax your lids.
