question_en: Why do we have a finite amount of teeth?
pos_context_title_en: An estimated 90% of adults in the US have fillings — here's why we can't just regrow our teeth (www.businessinsider.com)
An estimated 90% of adults in the US have fillings — here's why we can't just regrow our teeth (www.businessinsider.com)
What Are The 4 Types of Teeth and Why Do We Have Them? (www.tandaradental.com.au)
pos_context_en:
Only a handful of mammals can regrow teeth multiple times, compared to the 50,000 species of reptiles and fish. Take geckos, for example, who will replace all 100 teeth, or so, every 3 to 4 months. And since geckos can live for 6 to 10 years, they'll grow anywhere from 1,800 to 4,000 teeth in a lifetime! It's all thanks to a special type of cell in their gums, called stem cells.


Stem cells are handy because they can morph into different cells when needed. Like tooth stem cells to build new teeth. Humans have these stem cells when we're younger. But after our adult teeth grow in, the stem cells die and disappear.

Mammals, on the other hand, developed more specific diets. Like grazers who only eat grass and hunters who rip flesh from their kills. As a result, mammals evolved different shaped teeth for different purposes. And it's this difference, that could also explain why most mammals can't regrow more teeth.


Now, let's say you could regrow your molars multiple times, for example. It's important that the top and bottoms sets match up. Otherwise, they can't grind up food as efficiently. It sounds good in principle, but with each new set, there's a risk that the regrown teeth won't line up. So the leading theory is that adult humans can't regrow our teeth because it was better for survival to only grow one, well-aligned adult set.

As humans, we have 2 sets of teeth. We develop a set of baby teeth from as early as a tiny embryo inside the womb. Baby teeth help shape the way our jaw grows, chew food properly and help us learn to speak our first words.


Most children will start with 20 primary baby teeth, 10 on the top and 10 on the bottom. These teeth are eventually replaced with 32 permanent adult teeth, 16 on each upper and lower jaw, as we grow older and our jaws start to develop.
report_en: Humans, like most mammals, get only two sets of teeth because the biological machinery for making new ones shuts down and evolutionary pressures favored a single durable adult set. After our adult teeth emerge, the tooth-generating stem cells in the gums disappear, so no new enamel organs can form [1]. In contrast, reptiles such as geckos retain these stem cells and can replace hundreds of teeth throughout life, but mammals lost this ability when their diets became more specialized [1]. Mammals evolved differently shaped incisors, canines, premolars and molars, and efficient chewing depends on the upper and lower sets aligning precisely; if replacement teeth came in slightly off-kilter, it would hinder food processing and survival [2]. Natural selection therefore favored limiting tooth regeneration rather than risking repeated malocclusion, leaving us with the finite allotment we erupt in childhood and adolescence [2]. In humans this allotment is 20 baby teeth followed by 32 permanent teeth that must last the rest of our lives [3]. Under this developmental and evolutionary framework, we inevitably have a finite number of teeth.
all_claims: Humans, like most mammals, get only two sets of teeth because the biological machinery for making new ones shuts down and evolutionary pressures favored a single durable adult set.
After our adult teeth emerge, the tooth-generating stem cells in the gums disappear, so no new enamel organs can form [1].
In contrast, reptiles such as geckos retain these stem cells and can replace hundreds of teeth throughout life, but mammals lost this ability when their diets became more specialized [1].

Mammals evolved differently shaped incisors, canines, premolars and molars, and efficient chewing depends on the upper and lower sets aligning precisely; if replacement teeth came in slightly off-kilter, it would hinder food processing and survival [2].
Natural selection therefore favored limiting tooth regeneration rather than risking repeated malocclusion, leaving us with the finite allotment we erupt in childhood and adolescence [2].
In humans this allotment is 20 baby teeth followed by 32 permanent teeth that must last the rest of our lives [3].
Under this developmental and evolutionary framework, we inevitably have a finite number of teeth.

question_en: What is the "natural" sleeping position for humans.
pos_context_title_en: Best Sleeping Position for Better Sleep and Health (www.healthline.com)
Best Sleeping Position for Better Sleep and Health (www.healthline.com)
Best Sleeping Position for Better Sleep and Health (www.healthline.com)
Best Sleeping Position for Better Sleep and Health (www.healthline.com)
Best Sleeping Position for Better Sleep and Health (www.healthline.com)
Which Sleeping Position is the Best For You? | Sleep.org (www.sleep.org)
Which Sleeping Position is the Best For You? | Sleep.org (www.sleep.org)
Which Sleeping Position is the Best For You? | Sleep.org (www.sleep.org)
pos_context_en: There’s a reason why this is the most popular sleep position. The fetal position has loads of benefits. Not only is it great for lower back pain or pregnancy, sleeping in the fetal position can help reduce snoring.
if you have any issues with joint pain or stiffness, sleeping in a tight fetal position might leave you sore in the morning.

As it turns out, sleeping on your side is actually pretty good for you — especially if you’re sleeping on your left side. Not only can it help reduce snoring, it’s great for your digestion and might even reduce heartburn.
Unfortunately, sleeping on your stomach can cause both neck and back pain. It can also add a lot of unnecessary strain to your muscles and joints
sleeping on your back uses gravity to keep your body in an even alignment over your spine, which can help reduce any unnecessary pressure on your back or joints.

Side-sleeping with an arm overhead is the most common sleep position, representing 55 percent of the time asleep in bed. Research suggests that the preferred side position increases with age due to a loss of flexibility of the spine.


Patients with heart failure, however, instinctively avoid the left side position during sleep, possibly to avoid discomfort and shortness of breath.
Studies indicate that sleeping on your back could worsen certain conditions such as snoring and sleep apnea. Back-sleeping is also not optimal for people with heartburn or GERD.
the prone position causes a higher heart rate than the back position, and may increase their vulnerability to sudden infant death syndrome and hyperthermia
report_en: Observational and polysomnographic data show that humans instinctively favor a lateral posture: side-sleeping with an arm overhead accounts for about 55 % of total sleep time, making it the most common position across age groups [6]. Within this category, the curled “fetal” variant is identified as the single most popular style, further underscoring the natural tendency to sleep on one’s side rather than on the back or stomach [1]. Researchers propose that side-sleeping becomes even more prevalent with age because diminishing spinal flexibility makes other postures less comfortable, hinting at a biomechanical basis for its “natural” status [6]. Moreover, lateral positions confer physiological advantages—such as reducing snoring and easing digestion—which align with evolutionary pressures for unobstructed breathing and efficient gut function, reinforcing why the side/fetal posture is commonly regarded as the natural sleeping position for humans [3].

question_en: Why is automatic transmission fluid so unique? Does the viscosity of ATF change the more it moves?
pos_context_title_en: Why Automatic Transmission Fluid Is Quite Special - Keith's Guide to Keeping Your Car On the Road (locostcaraudio.com)
Why Automatic Transmission Fluid Is Quite Special - Keith's Guide to Keeping Your Car On the Road (locostcaraudio.com)
Why Automatic Transmission Fluid Is Quite Special - Keith's Guide to Keeping Your Car On the Road (locostcaraudio.com)
Why Automatic Transmission Fluid Is Quite Special - Keith's Guide to Keeping Your Car On the Road (locostcaraudio.com)
Why Automatic Transmission Fluid Is Quite Special - Keith's Guide to Keeping Your Car On the Road (locostcaraudio.com)
Automatic Transmission Fluid - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
pos_context_en: Within each gearbox are many moving parts that are engineered to work together under stress. A variety of different cogs, gears and bearings must engage with each other in order to work, and transmission fluid is essential to lubricate those parts. Without the fluid, the vehicle would suffer from an excessive amount of wear and tear, and you would need to replace those internal parts frequently.
Yet the automatic transmission is very different from the manual in many respects. It's not possible, therefore, to use a fluid that was designed for a manual transmission in an automatic variant.

The automatic transmission fluid is also designed to be pressurised so it can activate the various clutches and other internal parts that change your gears automatically. It is typically synthesised so that it will work under high pressure and temperature situations, and is far less likely to break down or oxidise.

Nevertheless, even though the fluid is quite sophisticated, there's only so much that it can do, and an element of wear and tear is inevitable. Tiny specks of metal will eventually grind away and will float within the fluid. Some of this debris will be caught by filters, but it'll nevertheless build up over time and affect the consistency of the fluid.

As the months go by, the automatic transmission fluid will be less capable of protecting those internal parts. It may not perform so well when pressurised, either, and this could adversely affect vehicle performance. Manufacturers recommend, therefore, that you take the vehicle in for an automatic transmission service at predetermined intervals.

Automatic transmissions (wet clutches) require hydrodynamic clutches, torque converters and wet brakes. Due to the function-related fluid losses, these always require low-viscosity, mildly additivated gear lubrication with a high oxidation stability. In order to reduce fuel consumption ATFs must have lower viscosities while at the same time maintaining protection for gears and bearings despite the lower lubricant film thickness.
report_en: Automatic transmission fluid (ATF) is purpose-built to do two jobs at once: lubricate dozens of meshing gears and bearings while also transmitting hydraulic pressure that engages clutches and torque-converter elements, jobs that ordinary manual-gear oils cannot fulfil [2]. To meet these demands it is synthetically blended with low base viscosity, friction modifiers and high oxidation stability so it stays pumpable, resists foaming and withstands the heat and pressures inside the box without breaking down or oxidising [3]. Engineers also tune viscosity to be as low as possible to cut fuel use, yet high enough to keep a protective film on wet clutches and gears [6]. Viscosity does change: in the short term the fluid thins whenever it heats up from movement (a normal property of all oils), and in the long term shear, oxidation and the gradual build-up of microscopic metal particles alter the fluid’s consistency, making it less able to protect parts or hold pressure [4]. Because of this gradual viscosity drift manufacturers specify periodic ATF replacement to restore correct hydraulic behaviour and lubrication [5].
all_claims: Automatic transmission fluid (ATF) is purpose-built to do two jobs at once: lubricate dozens of meshing gears and bearings while also transmitting hydraulic pressure that engages clutches and torque-converter elements, jobs that ordinary manual-gear oils cannot fulfil [2].

To meet these demands it is synthetically blended with low base viscosity, friction modifiers and high oxidation stability so it stays pumpable, resists foaming and withstands the heat and pressures inside the box without breaking down or oxidising [3].
Engineers also tune viscosity to be as low as possible to cut fuel use, yet high enough to keep a protective film on wet clutches and gears [6].

Viscosity does change: in the short term the fluid thins whenever it heats up from movement (a normal property of all oils), and in the long term shear, oxidation and the gradual build-up of microscopic metal particles alter the fluid’s consistency, making it less able to protect parts or hold pressure [4].
Because of this gradual viscosity drift manufacturers specify periodic ATF replacement to restore correct hydraulic behaviour and lubrication [5].

question_en: How did people drink liquids before cups?
pos_context_title_en: Cup! The Amazing Story of the World’s Greatest Container for Liquids (www.mcsweeneys.net)
Who Invented the Drinking Cup? (www.reference.com)
Cup (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
Primitive man, or Homo Nocuppus, first brought water to his mouth by lapping it up with his tongue as he had seen the beasts of the jungle do. But man soon realized that, unlike the animals he hunted, cooked, and occasionally attempted to breed with, he had hands. Hands that could come together to form a shallow, curved bowl, which could be used to hold a small amount of drinking water — this was the next important step in cup evolution, achieved after many painful years of experimentation with other body parts, such as the navel.


Eventually, somebody who wasn’t stupid was born. Forming a cylinder of clay, with one open end he used his primitive cup mostly to listen through doors at other people’s conversations. Then one day said vessel came into contact with water.

The original inventor of the drinking cup is not known, as the drinking cup existed before recorded history. For early cultures, the drinking cup would have been a vast improvement over drinking liquids with cupped hands.

Cups are an improvement on using cupped hands or feet to hold liquids. They have almost certainly been used since before recorded history, and have been found at archaeological sites throughout the world. Prehistoric cups were sometimes fashioned from shells and hollowed out stones.[7]
report_en: Before dedicated vessels existed, people often drank by bending to a stream and lapping water directly with their tongues like other animals, then evolved to scoop liquid into their mouths using both hands pressed together as a shallow bowl [1]; this simple, tool-free technique dominated early hydration practices until true cups appeared, which were viewed as a “vast improvement” over relying on cupped hands alone [2]. Archaeological evidence further indicates that cups mark progress beyond makeshift methods that included not only hand scoops but even the occasional use of feet to hold small amounts of water, underscoring how any available body part was employed before containers were developed [3].

question_en: How do ads follow me from my phone to my computer?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Ads Follow Me Around the Internet? (askleo.com)
How Ads Follow You from Phone to Desktop to Tablet (www.technologyreview.com)
How Internet Ads Follow You Around (lifehacker.com)
pos_context_en:
It works like this:


1. You visit a shopping site, or a site that offers some kind of service. This site may or may not show ads, but they do include content from an advertising network.
2. The advertising network places a cookie on your computer. That cookie contains information to the effect of, “This computer was looking at X,” where X is the product or service offered by the site you’re visiting.
3. Eventually, you move on to another website — a site that also displays ads, and coincidentally uses the same advertising network as the site we started at.
4. That advertising network is given its own cookie back — the one that says, “This computer was looking at X” — and as a result, elects to show you ads for X.
Signing into Google or Facebook as well as websites and apps using those logins confirms which devices you own.
Facebook and Google can collect data on you even if you don’t have an account, by scooping up your friends’ phone contacts or by logging usual browser data.
report_en: Ads trail you from phone to computer because advertising networks tie every device you use to a common identifier, usually an account login, and then reuse that link whenever they show you ads [2]. When you open an app or site on your phone while signed in to Google or Facebook, the network notes that this particular user looked at, say, sneakers and stores that detail in a cookie or similar ID [1]. Later, when you browse on your laptop, the same network reads its cookie (or sees the same login) and realizes the user who viewed sneakers on the phone is now on the computer, so it serves sneaker ads again [1]. Because both devices share the same login credentials, the network permanently stitches the phone’s and computer’s identifiers into a single cross-device profile that can be targeted anywhere you go online [2]. Even if you avoid logging in, companies can still match devices through shared IP addresses, browser fingerprints, or contact data gathered from your friends, allowing the ads to keep following you [3].

Because both devices share the same login credentials, the network permanently stitches the phone’s and computer’s identifiers into a single cross-device profile that can be targeted anywhere you go online [2].

Even if you avoid logging in, companies can still match devices through shared IP addresses, browser fingerprints, or contact data gathered from your friends, allowing the ads to keep following you [3].

question_en: Why are so many people choosing longboards over traditional skateboards these days? Are they easier to ride? What is the benefit?
pos_context_title_en: Longboard VS Skateboard – Pros, Cons, and Differences – BoardCoast (www.boardcoast.com)
Longboards Vs. Skateboards (www.redbull.com)
Longboard vs Skateboard – Similarities and Differences | SkateboardersHQ (www.skateboardershq.com)
pos_context_en:
Longboards are typically much longer and wider than skateboards. They also have different types of wheels. Longboards have large, soft wheels whereas skateboards have small, hard wheels. Longboards are also much more flexible and tend to be easier to ride for beginners.

The soft wheels on a longboard are great for riding, and rolling over cracks and small debris at high speeds, but they are bouncier than hard wheels. Typically you don’t want to use soft wheels when performing tricks because the board can possibly bounce back up after the wheels hit the pavement. It makes it much more difficult to land tricks and remain stable.

The trucks of skateboards and longboards are also different. Skateboards have small trucks, that stay underneath the board but longboards have wide trucks with a different design. Wide trucks provide more stability which is needed at high speeds.

If you put a longboard and skateboard side by side, you'll notice how flat the nose and tail of the longboard are. On a skateboard, you'll see more of a curve on its nose and tail to make it easier to land tricks and flips.

It should be no surprise that longboards are, of course, longer. They can be as long as 59 inches, while the typical skateboard is around 36 inches. Here's where it gets confusing: longboards also come in sizes as small as 28 inches long. If the length trips you up, just remember the key difference between the two is that longboards are flat and skateboards curve. So, if you see a flat, shorter board, it's probably just a short longboard.

Longboards are wider and longer than skateboards, are more flexible and easier to ride for beginners. Longboards have large soft wheels and skateboard have small hard wheels.

Big soft wheels are great for riding but are more bouncy compared to hard wheels. This means if you do an ollie (jump) for example, the board is more likely to bounce back up. This makes landing a trick unstable and more chances of landing primo (both feet on the side of the deck).

Skateboards have smaller trucks, longboards have wider trucks and have a different design. Wider trucks provide more stability which you need at higher speeds. Smaller trucks make a board more agile which is needed for ollies and flips.
report_en: Many riders are switching to longboards because they are purpose-built for comfortable cruising rather than technical stunts. A longboard can be as long as 59 in while a typical skateboard is about 36 in, giving riders far more standing room [2]. Combined with their greater width and flex, longboards are generally considered easier for beginners to control [1]. Large, soft wheels soak up road vibration and glide over cracks or gravel that would jolt a hard-wheeled skateboard, making daily commutes smoother and faster [1]. Their decks flex more than skateboard decks, further cushioning bumps and enabling surf-like carving that novices find intuitive [1]. Wider trucks add another layer of security; the broad axle width stabilizes the board at speed, whereas the narrower skateboard trucks are optimized for rapid flips and ollies, not straight-line confidence [3]. In short, the stability, shock absorption, and user-friendly handling of longboards explain why many people choose them over traditional skateboards when their goal is transport, downhill fun, or casual carving.

A longboard can be as long as 59 in while a typical skateboard is about 36 in, giving riders far more standing room [2].

Wider trucks add another layer of security; the broad axle width stabilizes the board at speed, whereas the narrower skateboard trucks are optimized for rapid flips and ollies, not straight-line confidence [3].

In short, the stability, shock absorption, and user-friendly handling of longboards explain why many people choose them over traditional skateboards when their goal is transport, downhill fun, or casual carving.

question_en: Why can Parrots talk? Can they only repeat what people say, or can they formulate their own thoughts and vocalize them sometimes?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Parrots Talk? (www.audubon.org)
Why Do Parrots Talk? (www.audubon.org)
How and why do parrots talk? Best talking parrot and teaching your parrot to talk (www.exoticdirect.co.uk)
How and why do parrots talk? Best talking parrot and teaching your parrot to talk (www.exoticdirect.co.uk)
Do Parrots Understand What They Say? - My Animals (myanimals.com)
Do Parrots Understand What They Say? - My Animals (myanimals.com)
pos_context_en: Parrots are vocal learners, meaning they grasp sounds by hearing and then imitating them. Although several other bird species can discern and repeat sounds, parrots are the pros.

For parrots, words may have some associations but not complex meanings, says Wright. “But they are very attuned to the context in which we use [words], and so I think that often fools people a little bit.”
Parrots talk by modifying the air that flows over the syrinx to make sounds. The syrinx is located where the trachea splits into the lungs.
Pssitacines (the parrot family) and Passerines (the song bird families) use their voices to warn, to court, to communicate with their nestlings and to fight to defend a territory.
The syrinx is a bony box made up of fused and widened rings. The vibratory membranes and the division of the trachea, which helps form the bronchi, are found inside it.

So, the challenges that Alex was able to carry out are proof that parrots do understand what they say. Contrary to what we may think, they’re not just randomly repeating what they hear in exchange for a treat.
report_en: Parrots can mimic human speech because they are vocal learners, able to hear sounds and then reproduce them [1]. Anatomically, they modify the stream of air over a specialized voice box called the syrinx, located where the trachea splits into the lungs, to create a wide range of tones that can resemble words [3]. This vocal apparatus originally serves everyday avian communication such as warnings, courtship, and territorial signals, but its flexibility lets parrots imitate novel sounds including human speech [4]. As for meaning, many pet birds mainly associate a word with the situation in which humans use it rather than grasping complex semantics, which can fool owners [2]. Yet experiments with the African grey parrot Alex showed he could correctly answer questions about colours, shapes, quantities and even request objects, demonstrating understanding and spontaneous use of language beyond rote mimicry [6]. Therefore, parrots talk thanks to a unique learning ability and vocal anatomy, and while many simply repeat context-linked phrases, some individuals can generate meaningful utterances reflecting basic cognitive concepts.
all_claims: Parrots can mimic human speech because they are vocal learners, able to hear sounds and then reproduce them [1].

Anatomically, they modify the stream of air over a specialized voice box called the syrinx, located where the trachea splits into the lungs, to create a wide range of tones that can resemble words [3].

This vocal apparatus originally serves everyday avian communication such as warnings, courtship, and territorial signals, but its flexibility lets parrots imitate novel sounds including human speech [4].
As for meaning, many pet birds mainly associate a word with the situation in which humans use it rather than grasping complex semantics, which can fool owners [2].

Yet experiments with the African grey parrot Alex showed he could correctly answer questions about colours, shapes, quantities and even request objects, demonstrating understanding and spontaneous use of language beyond rote mimicry [6].

Therefore, parrots talk thanks to a unique learning ability and vocal anatomy, and while many simply repeat context-linked phrases, some individuals can generate meaningful utterances reflecting basic cognitive concepts.

question_en: Why do Women typically play softball rather than baseball in the U.S.?
pos_context_title_en: Why Can’t American Women Play Baseball? (www.thedailybeast.com)
Why not let girls play baseball instead of softball? (www.carolinacoastonline.com)
Will Women Play Major League Baseball? (And Not Just on TV) (www.nytimes.com)
pos_context_en:
However, like so many advancements for U.S. women during World War II, baseball later ceased to be a professional option. “In the 1950s, we shoved women out of everything,” Ring said. “We have this unfortunate decade for women in American history. It’s a decade when women are sent back into the home.”


With the women’s liberation movement and Title IX, sports reemerged in the 1970s for women, but baseball did not. “Baseball never turned a corner and opened the doors to women,” said Ring.


Indeed, there’s evidence there was a concerted effort to keep girls out of baseball. In 1972, the national Little League organization threatened to revoke the charter of a team in Hoboken, New Jersey, because they allowed 12-year-old Maria Pepe to play. The National Organization for Women took on the case and successfully sued to allow for Pepe and other girls to be able to try out. In response to the pressure, Little League created Little League Softball.

When Title IX, the 1972 law that required equal funding to both male and female sports teams, finally appeared, women were given fair ground on nearly every sport.


Baseball was not on that list, though. Instead, the law dictated that the school must provide an equivalent sport, and in that case, it was softball. Thus, schools were within their right to deny girls who were interested in baseball as long as a softball team was provided.


Since then, women all over the country, and now the world, have fought for the chance to play on their school’s baseball team. Some have succeeded, and most have failed, but none have made a serious impact.

Women’s baseball is not a high school sport in the United States, although it is in other nations, like Canada and Japan. In this country, girls are directed to softball, which is a women’s sport at the high school and collegiate level, Dr. Ring says.


“If a girl here wants to play baseball, she almost has to play with the boys and the pressure to switch from baseball to softball can be overwhelming,” she says. “People will tell her, you’re missing out on college scholarships” and may also suggest that she is hurting both her body and possibly male opponents’ egos if she sticks with hardball.


Playing elite baseball also can be profoundly lonely for a woman, says Ms. Hudek, the Bossier Parish college player and one of the most successful young female pitchers of recent years.
report_en: After the wartime All-American Girls Professional Baseball League folded, women were pushed out of baseball in the 1950s, shutting down their professional path [1]. When Title IX was enacted in 1972, schools could satisfy the law by offering an “equivalent” girls’ sport, and they almost universally selected softball, which allowed them to bar girls from baseball teams [2]. That same year, Little League threatened to revoke a Hoboken charter for letting 12-year-old Maria Pepe play, and after losing in court it created Little League Softball rather than integrate its baseball divisions [1]. Because women’s baseball is still not recognized as a high-school sport in the United States, girls who wish to play must join boys’ teams and face heavy pressure to switch to softball for fear of losing scholarships and acceptance [3].

When Title IX was enacted in 1972, schools could satisfy the law by offering an “equivalent” girls’ sport, and they almost universally selected softball, which allowed them to bar girls from baseball teams [2].

Because women’s baseball is still not recognized as a high-school sport in the United States, girls who wish to play must join boys’ teams and face heavy pressure to switch to softball for fear of losing scholarships and acceptance [3].

question_en: Why does 'quick sand' make you sink and where does the sand go?
pos_context_title_en: Will Quicksand Really Kill You? (thescienceexplorer.com)
Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
pos_context_en:
In fact, studies have found it is impossible to be completely submerged in quicksand because humans are less dense than quicksand and a person would only sink to their chest before they begin to float.


But what can make quicksand deadly is its ability to trap and hold unsuspecting victims.


Quicksand occurs when fine sediment such as clay, sand, silt, or other grainy soil becomes saturated with water, typically from a subterranean source. Often these traps are found near the periphery or edge of natural water sources. Often the sand on top may appear solid, but with the added pressure of a footstep, the sand will mix with the water beneath it forming a thick sludge.

Objects in the quicksand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix and the submerged obje ct floats due to its buoyancy. The density of quicksand is 2 g/ml which is about twice that of a human body (1 g/ml), Thus, a human should sink only half way in (till the waist line), in case he/she does not struggle. Even objects with a higher density than quicksand will float on it—until they move.

The sand particles get displaced and the animal/human sinks in it. Objects in liquefied sand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix. Since Quicksand has a density twice than that of human, thus a person is usually trapped to their waist.


As the weight of the organism becomes equal to that of the displaced quicksand, the liquefaction process stops and the sand eventually forms a semi-solid bed again. The denser sand grains hold the animal tight, preventing it from escaping.
report_en: Quicksand forms where water saturates fine sand or silt from below; the water separates the grains and removes the friction that normally supports weight, so a footstep churns the mix into a sludge that fails to bear you, and you start to sink [1]. The sand-water suspension has a density of roughly 2 g/ml—about twice that of the human body—so you descend only until the weight of your body equals the weight of the displaced mixture, typically to your waist or chest [2]. While you sink, the sand is simply displaced sideways and held in suspension by the water; when your downward motion stops the grains resettle into a semi-solid bed that grips your limbs, explaining both where the sand goes and why getting out is so hard [3].

The sand-water suspension has a density of roughly 2 g/ml—about twice that of the human body—so you descend only until the weight of your body equals the weight of the displaced mixture, typically to your waist or chest [2].

While you sink, the sand is simply displaced sideways and held in suspension by the water; when your downward motion stops the grains resettle into a semi-solid bed that grips your limbs, explaining both where the sand goes and why getting out is so hard [3].

question_en: How did they work out the mass of the comet Phillae landed on?
pos_context_title_en: The tech behind the Rosetta comet chaser: From 3D printing to solar power to complex mapping - TechRepublic (www.techrepublic.com)
(www.vanderbilt.edu)
JimsAstronomy: Using Calculus to determine the mass of a comet (jdetrick.blogspot.com)
pos_context_en: To land on the comet, the ESA had to figure out the best way to orbit Rosetta around it. Rosetta has to be in front of the comet for the best light conditions from the sun. Using high-resolution digital images collected from several cameras on the spacecraft, including a wide angle lens, and scientific cameras to help map the area, the team generated a triangular orbit pattern around the comet. The challenge is now to figure out the gravitational pull of the comet. A pyramid shape allows them to better receive and analyze that data, eventually figuring out the density and mass of the comet.

What is the mass of a comet?


Let's assume the comet is a sphere with a radius of 5 km. Then the volume of this comet is


> V = 4/3 pi R^3= 500 km^3= 5 x 10^17 cm^3


Assuming a density of 1 gm/cc, typical for water ice, then this comet would have a total mass of 5 x 10^17 gm = 5 x 10^14 kg.

- The comet was 2,000 meters long. We can use Calculus to calculate the volume of the comet by measuring the radius at each point along its length then summing up (integrating) an infinite number of areas of circles with each radius over the entire length.
report_en: Engineers first built a detailed 3-D model of comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko by stitching together high-resolution images from Rosetta’s wide-angle and other scientific cameras, then guided the spacecraft through a tight triangular (pyramid-shaped) orbit in front of the comet to keep it well lit by the Sun [1]. As Rosetta followed this track, mission controllers measured the tiny velocity changes induced by the comet’s gravitational tug; from these deviations they calculated the comet’s gravitational parameter and thus its total mass [1]. With that mass and the volume obtained from the 3-D shape model, the team derived the nucleus’s bulk density, confirming it is a low-density, porous object rather than solid rock or ice [1]. A simplified illustration of the method treats a 5 km-radius, water-ice-density sphere, giving an estimated mass of about 5 × 10¹⁴ kg [2].

question_en: can weather or storms actually be controlled or man made? If so, to what extent and how?
pos_context_title_en: Can we control the weather? (science.howstuffworks.com)
New World War: Weather Warfare (www.newworldwar.org)
pos_context_en:
Finally, scientists had found a way to control the weather -- at least in the lab. For the next 30 years, researchers and entrepreneurs across the world began applying the principles developed by Langmuir, Schaefer and Vonnegut to real-world cloud seeding. They flew airplanes into the clouds, releasing their own clouds of silver iodide as they went, or fired artillery shells filled with silver iodide into clouds. In some cases, these weather modifiers were trying to produce rain in drought-afflicted areas, mitigate hail damage by preventing hailstones from growing so large, or disperse fog banks around airports. Many proprietors of this new technology made audacious claims about their cloud seeding services. Unfortunately, hard science could never substantiate the claims. If anything, rigorous experimentation seemed to suggest that cloud seeding barely worked or, worse, didn't work at all.

Still, enough tantalizing evidence has accumulated over the years to keep interest in weather modification alive. For example, research conducted in South Africa and Mexico has shown that seeding warm rain clouds with salt particles -- what is known as hygroscopic seeding -- is more effective than seeding cold rain clouds with silver iodide. And Chinese scientists believe they have mastered cloud seeding to such a degree that they can guarantee a certain day will be rainy or sunny, like say the opening ceremony of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, as this related article describes.

A precision lightning strike with synthetic lightning is also possible. The 2005 book, Weapons Grade: How Modern Warfare Gave Birth to Our High-Tech World, mentioned that artificial lightning had been accomplished using lasers. One reportedly had a range of about 200 meters, but could possibly be extended to about 2 miles. The 1997 Weather Wars: Pentagon Plans Weather as a Weapon article by the New York Times noted that the US Air Force was considering using such lasers for lightning attacks.

The US Air Force itself referenced using controlled lightning strikes to attack its targets. The Tofflers suggested that lasers can even be used to cut holes in the ozone layer above the land of an adversary.

HAARP

According to this information, weather modification is possible using electromagnetic waves. In the US and other countries, large weapons platforms to accomplish this appear to have been created.2

One such weapon is known as the High Frequency Active Auroral Research Project (HAARP). In their book Angels Don’t Play This HAARP: Advances in Tesla Technology, Jeane Manning and Dr. Nick Begich refer to it as one of the most powerful multi-purpose weapons developed by the US military.
report_en: Current technology allows limited, probabilistic influence on some weather phenomena but falls far short of creating or steering full-scale storms. Since the 1940s, cloud-seeding aircraft and artillery have released silver iodide or salt to induce rain, lessen hail, or disperse fog; rigorous experiments often showed little benefit, though warm-cloud salt seeding has proved more promising and is still employed in places like China, which claims it can schedule rain for major events such as the 2008 Beijing Olympics [1]. Laboratory and military research has also produced short-range artificial lightning by firing high-energy lasers into the air, with demonstrated strikes around 200 m and an estimated possible reach of about 2 mi, implying a capacity to direct but not generate thunderstorms [2]. U.S. Air Force documents and commentators further discuss using large electromagnetic installations such as the High-Frequency Active Auroral Research Project (HAARP) to manipulate weather, yet publicly available evidence of operational capability remains speculative [2]. In sum, current methods can modestly enhance or suppress localized precipitation and perhaps trigger isolated lightning, but they cannot reliably manufacture or control large storms or regional climate systems.

Laboratory and military research has also produced short-range artificial lightning by firing high-energy lasers into the air, with demonstrated strikes around 200 m and an estimated possible reach of about 2 mi, implying a capacity to direct but not generate thunderstorms [2].

question_en: If you put water bottles under a frozen lake when the outside temperate is below freezing will the bottles not freeze because the water under a lake is still liquid
pos_context_title_en: Temperature And Ice - Lake Scientist (www.lakescientist.com)
When and how do lakes freeze over? - RMBEL (www.rmbel.info)
How does a lake freeze? (whyfiles.org)
pos_context_en: What happens under the ice of lakes? Water under the ice typically stays very cold, but above freezing. Most lakes that form ice at the surface stay at about 4^oC most of the winter months.

As you all know, water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit. That doesn’t mean, however, when the air temp reaches 32 the lakes freeze. Water is a great insulator and good at holding heat, which is why the lake temperature doesn’t fluctuate much day to day like the air does. Therefore, below freezing temperatures are needed for a week or more to form ice on a large lake.

As winter sets in, lakes lose energy to the atmosphere, and water near the surface cools, becomes more dense, and sinks. Warmer, less dense water under the surface will rise to replace this surface water. When the entire lake reaches 40 F, the surface water cools further, dropping below 40 F. Because this water is now less dense than the surrounding water, it will stay on the top and continue to cool.


Once the surface water falls to 32 F, it freezes. The freezing then spreads downward into the lake and the ice thickens. Unless the lake is very shallow, you will find liquid water below the ice. This deeper water is about 40 F
report_en: Under lake ice, the bulk of the water remains liquid and hovers around 4 °C (39 °F) for most of the winter [1]. This is because, after the whole lake cools to about 4 °C, any colder water becomes less dense, stays at the surface, and eventually freezes while the denser 4 °C water sinks and persists below the ice [3]. Consequently, a sealed water bottle submerged into this 4 °C layer will equilibrate to that temperature and should not freeze even when the air above the ice is well below 0 °C, since the surrounding water itself is above the freezing point [1]. If the bottle is left touching the underside of the ice or is buoyant enough to rise into the surface layer that sits at 0 °C, it can cool to freezing and start to form ice, particularly in very shallow areas where the whole water column can approach 0 °C [3]. Therefore, placing bottles sufficiently deep under the ice of a normally stratified lake keeps them in liquid water at roughly refrigerator temperature, preventing freezing as long as they stay fully submerged.

This is because, after the whole lake cools to about 4 °C, any colder water becomes less dense, stays at the surface, and eventually freezes while the denser 4 °C water sinks and persists below the ice [3].

Consequently, a sealed water bottle submerged into this 4 °C layer will equilibrate to that temperature and should not freeze even when the air above the ice is well below 0 °C, since the surrounding water itself is above the freezing point [1].

If the bottle is left touching the underside of the ice or is buoyant enough to rise into the surface layer that sits at 0 °C, it can cool to freezing and start to form ice, particularly in very shallow areas where the whole water column can approach 0 °C [3].

Therefore, placing bottles sufficiently deep under the ice of a normally stratified lake keeps them in liquid water at roughly refrigerator temperature, preventing freezing as long as they stay fully submerged.

question_en: Why is it cheaper for employers to have their workers get compensatory time instead of overtime pay?
pos_context_title_en: Compensatory Time Off Vs. Overtime Pay | FedSmith.com (www.fedsmith.com)
Comp time vs. overtime – What you need to know (www.insperity.com)
Comp time vs. overtime – What you need to know (www.insperity.com)
Federal Employees - Compensatory Time Off (www.opm.gov)
pos_context_en: Comp time for the Federal employee is one paid hour off for each hour of irregular or occasional overtime that has been worked.
The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) governs what employers must do under federal law.

The legal requirements of each state also factor into what options might be available to you as an employee or as the employer.


Violations of the law relating to overtime pay can be viewed as wage theft and an attempt at evading the law, which can be accompanied by high fines and prison time in some states.

Agencies may require that an FLSA exempt employee (as defined at 5 U.S.C. 5541(2)) receive compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay for irregular or occasional overtime work, but only for an FLSA exempt employee whose rate of basic pay is above the rate for GS-10, step 10.
report_en: Employers save money by offering compensatory time because each overtime hour worked is exchanged for only one hour of future paid leave instead of an immediate cash payment, meaning the employer avoids the extra wage premium that attaches to overtime pay as well as the accompanying payroll-tax outlay and benefit accruals that apply to additional wages [1]. In the federal sector, agencies can even require certain FLSA-exempt employees above GS-10 step 10 to take comp time rather than receive any overtime pay, eliminating direct payroll costs altogether [4]. By substituting leave for cash, employers keep short-term labor expenses flat while shifting the cost of the employee’s time off into the future when staffing levels may already be lower or when replacement labor can be scheduled more cheaply. Finally, because the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) tightly regulates overtime pay and violations can attract significant fines or even criminal penalties in some states, using comp time within legal limits helps employers avoid the financial and legal risks associated with miscalculating or underpaying overtime [2].
all_claims: Employers save money by offering compensatory time because each overtime hour worked is exchanged for only one hour of future paid leave instead of an immediate cash payment, meaning the employer avoids the extra wage premium that attaches to overtime pay as well as the accompanying payroll-tax outlay and benefit accruals that apply to additional wages [1].

In the federal sector, agencies can even require certain FLSA-exempt employees above GS-10 step 10 to take comp time rather than receive any overtime pay, eliminating direct payroll costs altogether [4].

By substituting leave for cash, employers keep short-term labor expenses flat while shifting the cost of the employee’s time off into the future when staffing levels may already be lower or when replacement labor can be scheduled more cheaply.

Finally, because the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) tightly regulates overtime pay and violations can attract significant fines or even criminal penalties in some states, using comp time within legal limits helps employers avoid the financial and legal risks associated with miscalculating or underpaying overtime [2].

In the federal sector, agencies can even require certain FLSA-exempt employees above GS-10 step 10 to take comp time rather than receive any overtime pay, eliminating direct payroll costs altogether [4].

question_en: Clock Speeds and/vs Cores in computers
pos_context_title_en: CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
pos_context_en: The CPU multiplier (sometimes called the “CPU ratio”) is multiplied against the CPU Base Clock (or BCLK) to determine the processor’s clock speed. A CPU multiplier of 46 and a base clock of 100 MHz, for example, results in a clock speed of 4.6GHz.

CPU clock speed is a good indicator of your processor’s performance. Though applications like video editing and streaming are known to rely on multi-core performance, many new video games still benchmark best on CPUs with the highest clock speed.
A CPU with a clock speed of 3.2 GHz executes 3.2 billion cycles per second.
A core is a single processing unit, multi-core processors have multiple processing units. So a dual-core 3.0GHz processor has two processing units each with a clock speed of 3.0GHz.
Multi-threading is the ability of an application or operating system to utilise multiple cores for processing.
Hyper-threading is a proprietary Intel technology that allows a single core to split into a virtual and a logical core and share workload between the two.
report_en: CPU clock speed is the number of cycles per second a processor can execute; for example, 3.2 GHz equals 3.2 billion cycles per second [3]. The speed is set by multiplying the base clock (BCLK) by a CPU multiplier, so a 100 MHz BCLK with a 46× multiplier yields 4.6 GHz [1]. High clock speed is still a strong predictor of performance in tasks like modern video games, which often benchmark best on CPUs with the fastest single-core clocks [2]. A core is an independent processing unit; a dual-core 3 GHz chip therefore has two units each running at 3 GHz [4]. Applications that can split work across cores use multi-threading to tap several cores simultaneously [5]. Intel’s Hyper-Threading even lets one physical core appear as two logical cores to share workloads more effectively [6]. Consequently, workloads with heavy parallelism (rendering, encoding, large spreadsheets) scale with core count, while lightly threaded workloads favor higher clock speed; choosing between them depends on which type dominates your use. In practice, a balanced CPU offering ample cores and high boost clocks often delivers the best general-purpose experience.

The speed is set by multiplying the base clock (BCLK) by a CPU multiplier, so a 100 MHz BCLK with a 46× multiplier yields 4.6 GHz [1].
High clock speed is still a strong predictor of performance in tasks like modern video games, which often benchmark best on CPUs with the fastest single-core clocks [2].

Applications that can split work across cores use multi-threading to tap several cores simultaneously [5].
Intel’s Hyper-Threading even lets one physical core appear as two logical cores to share workloads more effectively [6].

Consequently, workloads with heavy parallelism (rendering, encoding, large spreadsheets) scale with core count, while lightly threaded workloads favor higher clock speed; choosing between them depends on which type dominates your use.
In practice, a balanced CPU offering ample cores and high boost clocks often delivers the best general-purpose experience.

question_en: How do events in my dreams coincide with events that are happening in real life?
pos_context_title_en: Dreaming of the Future (www.psychologytoday.com)
pos_context_en:
Throughout history, people have believed that prophetic dreams can give us glimpses of future events. Is there any reason to believe such dreams are possible?


It would seem not. Most instances of a dream predicting a significant event in waking life are probably just coincidences. For example, people periodically dream of car crashes, so at some point, a person will dream of a car crash the night before actually getting in a car crash. That’s not prophecy, that’s just the law of averages. The claims people make about future-telling dreams are most likely to be fantasies, fabrications, or failures of causal reasoning.


That may be the safest position to take. It’s not the most scientific position, however, because it isn’t based on evidence, just a resolute skepticism. The actual evidence in support of anticipatory dreaming is not so easily dismissed and merits more serious attention than it typically receives.
report_en: Coincidences between dream content and waking events are overwhelmingly attributable to chance: because people frequently dream about common situations such as car crashes, eventually one of those dreams will precede an actual crash, illustrating nothing more mysterious than the law of averages [1]. Reports of seemingly prophetic dreams are further amplified by memory biases—people tend to remember the “hits” and forget the “misses”—and by post-event embellishment, so many striking correspondences are really fantasies, fabrications, or errors in causal reasoning [1]. Although a small amount of research on “anticipatory dreaming” has not been conclusively dismissed, the evidence remains too limited to prove genuine foresight, so the safest interpretation is that most dream-event overlaps stem from randomness combined with selective recall; with four to six dreams per night, you generate thousands of narrative fragments each year, providing ample material for occasional matches with real life.
all_claims: Coincidences between dream content and waking events are overwhelmingly attributable to chance: because people frequently dream about common situations such as car crashes, eventually one of those dreams will precede an actual crash, illustrating nothing more mysterious than the law of averages [1].

Reports of seemingly prophetic dreams are further amplified by memory biases—people tend to remember the “hits” and forget the “misses”—and by post-event embellishment, so many striking correspondences are really fantasies, fabrications, or errors in causal reasoning [1].

Although a small amount of research on “anticipatory dreaming” has not been conclusively dismissed, the evidence remains too limited to prove genuine foresight, so the safest interpretation is that most dream-event overlaps stem from randomness combined with selective recall; with four to six dreams per night, you generate thousands of narrative fragments each year, providing ample material for occasional matches with real life.

Reports of seemingly prophetic dreams are further amplified by memory biases—people tend to remember the “hits” and forget the “misses”—and by post-event embellishment, so many striking correspondences are really fantasies, fabrications, or errors in causal reasoning [1].
claims_retained: Coincidences between dream content and waking events are overwhelmingly attributable to chance: because people frequently dream about common situations such as car crashes, eventually one of those dreams will precede an actual crash, illustrating nothing more mysterious than the law of averages [1].

question_en: Why is the U.S. rail system so awful?
pos_context_title_en: The US is terrible at building high-speed rail — here's why (www.cnbc.com)
The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
pos_context_en:
China has the world's fastest and largest high-speed rail network — more than 19,000 miles, the vast majority of which was built in the past decade.


Japan's bullet trains can reach nearly 200 miles per hour and date to the 1960s. They have moved more than 9 billion people without a single passenger casualty.


France began service of the high-speed TGV train in 1981 and the rest of Europe quickly followed.


But the U.S. has no true high-speed trains, aside from sections of Amtrak's Acela line in the Northeast Corridor. The Acela can reach 150 mph for only 34 miles of its 457-mile span. Its average speed between New York and Boston is about 65 mph.


California's high-speed rail system is under construction, but whether it will ever get completed as intended is uncertain.

High-speed rail isn't just achievable: It already exists. However, as with anything else in the U.S. today, the biggest obstacle in the way of American high-speed rail is politics. Speeding up the Acela Express, for example, would require billions in federal funding, according to Fortune. Good luck with that in today's polarized environment. Meanwhile, the political squabbles that have faced California's bullet train ambitions are now legendary, and not in a good way. While the concept of connecting the Golden State's biggest cities via bullet train is brilliant, Vox says the planning has been horrendous, between the addition of pointless and expensive stops, rushed construction, and bad financial decisions. The political battles got even nastier in 2019, when the Trump administration pulled $929 million in federal grants for California's high-speed rail, according to MSN.

The U.S. automobile obsession is an obstacle for high-speed rail dreams, according to Forbes, because cultural mores impact funding decisions. The U.S. has higher car ownership rates than other nations, so these countries are far more open to the idea of putting higher taxes on vehicles to cut demand — sometimes to the point of taxing purchasers an additional 150 percent on the car's base price. You think a tax like that would ever fly in the U.S.? Not in this lifetime.
report_en: The United States has no true high-speed rail except a 34-mile stretch of Amtrak’s Acela that briefly reaches 150 mph and still averages only 65 mph between New York and Boston [1]. China has built more than 19,000 miles of high-speed track in just a decade, while Japan and France have operated bullet trains for decades, underscoring the gap the U.S. never closed [1]. Creating comparable service would cost billions in federal funds, yet partisan battles routinely block or rescind such money, exemplified by the 2019 removal of $929 million from California’s project [2]. When projects do advance, they are hampered by politically driven route changes, unnecessary stops, rushed construction and other planning mistakes that inflate costs and cause delays [2]. Moreover, America’s high car-ownership rate makes both voters and lawmakers resistant to vehicle taxes or subsidy shifts that could finance rail, maintaining a policy bias toward highways [3]. Consequently, chronic underinvestment, political gridlock, flawed management and car-centric culture keep U.S. rail slow and fragmented while other nations speed ahead [1].

rail slow and fragmented while other nations speed ahead [1].

Creating comparable service would cost billions in federal funds, yet partisan battles routinely block or rescind such money, exemplified by the 2019 removal of $929 million from California’s project [2].
When projects do advance, they are hampered by politically driven route changes, unnecessary stops, rushed construction and other planning mistakes that inflate costs and cause delays [2].
Moreover, America’s high car-ownership rate makes both voters and lawmakers resistant to vehicle taxes or subsidy shifts that could finance rail, maintaining a policy bias toward highways [3].
rail slow and fragmented while other nations speed ahead [1].

question_en: Why does HTTPS/SSL need a certificate to do secure transmission, while SSH does not?
pos_context_title_en: HTTPS: What is a SSL Certificate and Why Do You Need One? | Redwood Valley Technical Solutions Web Design (rvtechsolutions.com)
SSH vs SSL | Top 8 Differences and Comparisons You Should Learn (www.educba.com)
pos_context_en:
[Image: SSL Certificate Secure Browsing]Both HTTPS and SSL are in place to ensure your website is trustworthy and responsible. Through approving your webpage, your audience knows that they are more or less protected when browsing or buying from your page.

If you’re not familiar with HTTPS and SSL, you’ll want to brush up on what they mean and what they include. Let’s begin by taking a look at what HTTPS and SSL stand for.

HTTPS stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, meaning that the communication between your visitor and your website is secure and encrypted.

There are a number of benefits to having an HTTPS website over a standard HTTP, especially if your visitor is frequently entering detailed or sensitive information when they visit your site. If your customer needs to enter credit card information or other personal information, you’ll want to have an HTTPS page.

Having an HTTPS shows your visitor that you’re a valid company, so they don’t need to be worried about entering credit card information to make a purchase online. The information they do enter will become encrypted, so it cannot be stolen or intercepted.

Your HTTPS website can establish a stronger level of trust with your customer. When they know that their information is protected, they’ll be more likely to purchase from your company over your competition.

## What is SSL?

SSL, which stands for Secure Socket Layer, works with your HTTPS website to protect your customer’s information and privacy. SSL, which may also be called TLS, or Transport Layer Security, is the encryption communication that your HTTPS website will use to encrypt the information a customer or client puts into your website.

Both SSH and SSL are public-key cryptography protocols that create a secure, confidential exchange of data and connection across the Internet. Let’s discuss some of the major key differences:

 1. Usually, SSH uses Port 22, whereas SSL uses Port 443. 2. SSH uses a username/password authentication process to establish a secure connection, whereas SSL does not consider it. 3. SSH is based on network tunnelling, whereas SSL is based on certificates. 4. SSL is used for securely transmitting critical information like credit cards and banking. Whereas SSH is used for securely executing commands across the Internet. 5. SSL is used for encrypting communication between browser and server. On the other hand, SSH is used for encrypting communication between two computers over the Internet. 6. In SSL, the communication is authenticated via the private-key/public-key pair. Whereas in SSH, the communication is authenticated via private-key/public-key pair or username/password pair. 7. Technically, SSH is for securing computer networks, whereas SSL is for securing online data transfers. 8. SSL generally (except exceptions) uses X.509 digital certificates for server and client authentication processes, whereas SSH does not. 9. Another major difference is that SSH has more built-in functionality than SSL. It helps in enabling users to log in to a server and execute commands remotely, whereas SSL does not have this functionality. To achieve this functionality, you need to pair it with another protocol like HTTP, FTP.
report_en: HTTPS/SSL relies on digital certificates (typically X.509) issued by trusted certificate authorities to prove a site’s identity to any connecting browser; the protocol is “based on certificates” and “generally uses X.509 digital certificates for server and client authentication” [2]. The browser verifies this certificate, negotiates an encrypted session, and shows visual indicators that foster customer confidence when submitting credit-card or other sensitive data [1]. SSH, in contrast, is “based on network tunnelling” and authenticates connections with either a public-key pair or a username/password, not with CA-issued certificates [2]; a client records the server’s public key the first time it connects and subsequently checks it locally, so no external certificate infrastructure is needed. Therefore HTTPS/SSL needs certificates to provide scalable, third-party-validated identity for the open web, while SSH achieves security through direct key or password verification between two known endpoints.
all_claims: HTTPS/SSL relies on digital certificates (typically X.509) issued by trusted certificate authorities to prove a site’s identity to any connecting browser; the protocol is “based on certificates” and “generally uses X.509 digital certificates for server and client authentication” [2].
The browser verifies this certificate, negotiates an encrypted session, and shows visual indicators that foster customer confidence when submitting credit-card or other sensitive data [1].

SSH, in contrast, is “based on network tunnelling” and authenticates connections with either a public-key pair or a username/password, not with CA-issued certificates [2]; a client records the server’s public key the first time it connects and subsequently checks it locally, so no external certificate infrastructure is needed.

Therefore HTTPS/SSL needs certificates to provide scalable, third-party-validated identity for the open web, while SSH achieves security through direct key or password verification between two known endpoints.

question_en: Why do mobile websites have a "click here to continue reading" button?
pos_context_title_en: Designing “Read More” And “Continue Reading” Links — Smashing Magazine (www.smashingmagazine.com)
How “Hiding” Content Behind a Read More Button Impacts SEO (www.dealer.com)
Read More Button - How to Add, Best Practices & SEO Impacts - SEOptimer (www.seoptimer.com)
pos_context_en:
Before we present the showcase, let’s understand why “Read more” links are so important. They are important for several reasons, most importantly because they allow designers to compress content on the home page. By compressing content, you fit more content in less space. This means that readers can scan headlines more quickly and that you can fit more information above the fold.


More after jump! Continue reading below ↓


Also, “Read more” links allow website administrators to more easily track the most popular content. Designers who put entire articles on the home page may make it difficult for website administrators to track the most popular articles and understand what users want to see.


The third and probably most practical reason for having “Read more” links on a website is money. Websites that monetize traffic understand that the more their readers click on links, the more likely they will look at and click on advertisements. “Read more” links can double or even triple the number of page views a website receives, making it more attractive to advertisers.

At this year’s SMX Advanced in Seattle I asked Google’s Gary Illyes if “hiding” content behind a Read More button affects websites’ SEO.


His answer wasn’t surprising considering Google’s stance on user experience. This practice, which essentially directs users to click a button/link that says Read More or Read On to view the full content, does have an effect on sites’ SEO, including auto retailers using Dealer.com Websites. Specifically, Google does not index content hidden behind these buttons on desktop sites.

The ‘read more ‘ button comes in handy for every webmaster. The button is versatile and has many uses, for example, it can be used to truncate content so that only a part is displayed. It is also used to toggle between showing and hiding content, for example when a site hides content and wants you to subscribe in order to read the rest.
report_en: Mobile screens provide limited space, so sites hide most of an article and show a “click here to continue reading” button to compress content and let users scan more headlines above the fold efficiently [1]. Truncating text also reduces initial page weight, giving a cleaner, faster-loading first view on mobile devices [3]. Each tap on the button creates an extra page view; advertisers value this because “Read more” links can double or even triple total impressions, directly increasing potential ad revenue [1]. Splitting the article further helps publishers track which stories get clicked, since click counts on the button reveal the most popular content without scrolling analytics noise [1]. The main caution is SEO: if the full text remains technically hidden until the user taps, Google may not index that hidden portion, which can lower search visibility unless the implementation follows best-practice guidelines for mobile indexing [2].

question_en: Why do most doors have a two stage locking mechanism instead of one?
pos_context_title_en: Multipoint Locking Systems Explained (brennancorp.com)
Do I Need a Multipoint Lock for My Door? (www.pellabranch.com)
pos_context_en:
The extra locking points strengthen your home’s security by providing a tighter seal along the length of the door, top-to-bottom. This compression also makes the door more weathertight than a standard door, which makes it more energy efficient.


With a standard locking system, your primary lock is in the center, usually a single deadbolt. In that case, the top and bottom of the door don’t have integrated locks which leaves the door more vulnerable to a break-in.

Older door locks with similar functionality could only be secured from the inside and required you to turn a lock at each point. Modern multipoint door locks are easier to operate. The three-point locking system involves just one lock mechanism and dual-action deadbolts. So all three deadbolts respond to the same key turn — no need to stretch or bend down to lock different parts of the door.
report_en: Many modern exterior doors use a two-stage or multipoint mechanism—central deadbolt plus additional bolts—because the extra locking points “strengthen your home’s security by providing a tighter seal along the length of the door, top-to-bottom” [1]. By drawing the door evenly against the frame, this compression makes the entrance more weathertight and therefore more energy-efficient than a standard single-point lock [1]. Convenience is not sacrificed: one key turn simultaneously engages three deadbolts, so homeowners no longer have to stretch up or crouch down to secure each point individually [2]. The blend of greater break-in resistance, improved energy performance, and easy one-motion operation is why two-stage locking is preferred over a single lock on most quality doors.

By drawing the door evenly against the frame, this compression makes the entrance more weathertight and therefore more energy-efficient than a standard single-point lock [1].
Convenience is not sacrificed: one key turn simultaneously engages three deadbolts, so homeowners no longer have to stretch up or crouch down to secure each point individually [2].
The blend of greater break-in resistance, improved energy performance, and easy one-motion operation is why two-stage locking is preferred over a single lock on most quality doors.

question_en: Why is eating burnt food bad for you?
pos_context_title_en: Acrylamide (www.niehs.nih.gov)
Acrylamide Questions and Answers (www.fda.gov)
Does Burnt Food Cause Cancer? | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (blog.dana-farber.org)
Heterocyclic Amine - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
pos_context_en: When certain foods are cooked at high temperatures, sugars, such as glucose and fructose, can react with the free amino acid, asparagine, to form acrylamide. Acrylamide forms as part of a chemical reaction, known as the Maillard reaction, which contributes to the aroma, taste, and color of cooked foods. Acrylamide is one of the hundreds of chemicals that can form during the Maillard reaction.

Acrylamide caused cancer in animals in studies where animals were exposed to acrylamide at very high doses. In 2010, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide is a human health concern, and suggested additional long-term studies. FDA experts participated in the evaluation and provided data from new research studies on acrylamide risk.

When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked.


Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat. Heterocyclic amines (HCAs) are generated from reactions between molecules including amino acids and sugars.


[Image]


HCAs form when meat is exposed to high temperatures for a prolonged period of time; the longer the exposure, the more HCAs are formed. Microwaving meat briefly before cooking at a high temperature reduces the time the meat needs to be cooked, and therefore less HCAs are produced. Although some studies how burnt, fried, or barbecued meat is associated with higher risk of certain cancers in lab tests, the connection between charred food and increased cancer risk is not proven for certain.

HCAs form when amino acids and creatine react at high cooking temperatures and are formed in greater quantities when meats are overcooked or blackened. Seventeen different HCAs resulting from the cooking of muscle meats have been identified, which may pose human cancer risk.


HCAs develop a powerful carcinogenic potential when activated by cytochrome P450 1A2-mediated oxidation of the amino group, which is followed by acetylation or sulfation to form direct-acting reactive mutagens that attack key elements in DNA. When fed to rats, several of these HCAs can induce cancer of the mammary glands, colon, and pancreas.
report_en: Burning or heavily browning food exposes it to temperatures that create potentially harmful chemicals. In carbohydrate-rich foods like potatoes or bread, high heat drives the Maillard reaction, in which sugars react with the amino acid asparagine to form acrylamide [1]; animal studies at very high doses show acrylamide can cause cancer, and global experts consider it a human health concern warranting further study [2]. In meat, charring produces a different set of hazards: flames and smoke generate polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, while prolonged high-temperature cooking causes amino acids and creatine to form at least 17 heterocyclic amines (HCAs) [3]. Once metabolically activated, several HCAs become direct DNA-damaging mutagens and have produced mammary, colon, and pancreatic cancers in rats [4]. Although human data are not yet definitive, these findings suggest that eating burnt or blackened food increases exposure to compounds linked to cancer risk, so limiting charring and using gentler cooking methods is advisable.
all_claims: Burning or heavily browning food exposes it to temperatures that create potentially harmful chemicals.

In carbohydrate-rich foods like potatoes or bread, high heat drives the Maillard reaction, in which sugars react with the amino acid asparagine to form acrylamide [1]; animal studies at very high doses show acrylamide can cause cancer, and global experts consider it a human health concern warranting further study [2].

In meat, charring produces a different set of hazards: flames and smoke generate polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, while prolonged high-temperature cooking causes amino acids and creatine to form at least 17 heterocyclic amines (HCAs) [3].
Once metabolically activated, several HCAs become direct DNA-damaging mutagens and have produced mammary, colon, and pancreatic cancers in rats [4].

Although human data are not yet definitive, these findings suggest that eating burnt or blackened food increases exposure to compounds linked to cancer risk, so limiting charring and using gentler cooking methods is advisable.

In meat, charring produces a different set of hazards: flames and smoke generate polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, while prolonged high-temperature cooking causes amino acids and creatine to form at least 17 heterocyclic amines (HCAs) [3].
Once metabolically activated, several HCAs become direct DNA-damaging mutagens and have produced mammary, colon, and pancreatic cancers in rats [4].

question_en: Explain: (to Americans): Canadian Election today
pos_context_title_en: Elections | The Canada Guide (thecanadaguide.com)
Elections | The Canada Guide (thecanadaguide.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
pos_context_en:
Canadian government is divided into three levels: federal, provincial, and local, and Canadians elect the politicians who run all three.


* A national election, sometimes called a federal election or a Canadian general election, is an election to pick members of the House of Commons.
* A provincial election picks people to sit in one of the 10 provincial parliaments.
* A municipal election chooses city-level officials like the mayor,

The Constitution of Canada says any citizen of Canada over the age of 18 is eligible to vote in a federal, provincial or local election. This includes Canadians living abroad, who can vote via absentee ballots at overseas embassies and consulates, and even Canadians in prison.

Trudeau, Scheer and the leaders of other national parties will tour the country, making the case for their party. At the same time, incumbents and challengers will compete in the 338 separate elections for Commons seats.
One member of Parliament is chosen for each Commons seat. (Canada's other chamber, the Senate, is not elected.)
If the winning party wins 169 seats or fewer, they will form a minority government.
report_en: Canada is holding a federal election today, meaning voters choose the members of the House of Commons, the country’s elected lower chamber of Parliament [1]. There are 338 separate local races—one per riding—so Canadians will be deciding 338 seats in total [3]. The unelected Senate, Canada’s other chamber, is not part of today’s vote [4]. To secure a majority government, a party must win at least 170 seats; if it wins 169 or fewer, it will have to govern as a minority, often seeking support from smaller parties to pass legislation [5]. Any Canadian citizen aged 18 or older can vote, including those living abroad who cast absentee ballots and even citizens currently in prison [2].

question_en: Why do plastic water bottles almost always have ridges in the sides?
pos_context_title_en: Why do Soft Drink Bottles have 5 bumps at the bottom?? (around-us-facts.blogspot.com)
Make a Lighter, Stronger Plastic Bottle (www.wired.com)
pos_context_en:
Water bottles have small indents to improve the stability of the bottle.



The bumps or the corrugations in the foot of the bottle increases the strength of the bottle

Ridges Curved horizontal ribs provide strength and a little style. Vertical troughs running from the shoulder to the base provide support the same way that a fold in a piece of paper allows it to stand up on its own.
report_en: Plastic water bottles are molded with horizontal ribs and vertical trough-like ridges because the corrugated shape stiffens the thin PET walls, letting the package stay upright, resist crushing and internal pressure, and yet use less material than a smooth-walled cylinder would require [2]; the same principle explains the small indents or “bumps” in the base, which further steady the bottle when it is set down and add strength where stress is highest [1].
all_claims: Plastic water bottles are molded with horizontal ribs and vertical trough-like ridges because the corrugated shape stiffens the thin PET walls, letting the package stay upright, resist crushing and internal pressure, and yet use less material than a smooth-walled cylinder would require [2]; the same principle explains the small indents or “bumps” in the base, which further steady the bottle when it is set down and add strength where stress is highest [1].
