question_en: Hacking JLaw's phone was a sex crime but hacking then publicly shaming Ashley Madison users is not. Please explain!
pos_context_title_en: Hacker sentenced to prison for role in Jennifer Lawrence nude photo theft (www.theguardian.com)
Hacking Laws and Punishments - FindLaw (www.findlaw.com)
Why The Stolen Ashley Madison Data Is (Legally) Fair Game For The Internet (consumerist.com)
Why The Stolen Ashley Madison Data Is (Legally) Fair Game For The Internet (consumerist.com)
pos_context_en: George Garofano, 26, was accused of illegally hacking the private Apple iCloud accounts of 240 people, including Hollywood stars as well as average internet users, allowing their nude photos and private information to be spread around the internet.

Hacking is broadly defined as the act of breaking into a computer system. Hacking isn't always a crime as "ethical hacking" occurs when a hacker is legally permitted to exploit security networks. In other words, it's when a hacker has the appropriate consent or authorization. However, hacking crosses the criminal line when a hacker accesses someone's computer system without such consent or authority.

As CNN and Motherboard have both explained, Ashley Madison is filing DMCA requests left and right, claiming that as they own copyright on the leaked materials, it is unlawful to redistribute or look at them. The claims are basically the same sort of takedown requests a film studio would file to get as-yet-unreleased movies pulled offline.


Whether they have a leg to stand on with those claims, however, is another story.


Motherboard delved into a lengthy explanation about what’s copyrightable and what’s not after Ashley Madison challenged a tweet from one of their staff writers. The TL;DR version of the law, which is important here, is that you can copyright original works, but not lists of facts.

Parts of the Ashley Madison data dump are copyrightable information. The source code for their websites, for example, is original work. Any advertising copy they published on their sites is, likewise, original to them. (And the source code for all of Avid Life’s sites has, indeed, been leaked, so they have some grounds there.)


But a big fat *.csv file full of data? That’s a set of facts, and as such, not a thing that is subject to being copyrighted.


Plenty of other information Ashley Madison has or had access to is also subject to copyright: anything the users write on their profiles, and the images they share. But the account-holders — all 30-odd million of them — are the ones who own that material. That’s been how leaked or stolen material has been successfully taken down before, for example when celebrities’ private photos were stolen from their phones in 2014. Google and other companies did comply with requests to take the images down, because those individuals owned their images and had grounds to request their removal.


You Can’t Put The Toothpaste Back In The Tube
As much as Ashley Madison and all its users wish it were not so, not only is the data probably not subject to copyright claims… but also even if it were, the media can still talk about it as much as they want.


The hackers absolutely broke laws when they stole information from inside Avid Life Media. But media who report on the information are not breaking laws. National security concerns aside (that’s covered by different law), the press can basically run with any information given to them innocently, even if the person giving it to them obtained it illegally.
report_en: George Garofano’s breach of Jennifer Lawrence’s iCloud was punished as a sex-related offense because he stole and spread private nude photographs, directly violating the victims’ sexual privacy and turning the hack into non-consensual pornography distribution [1]; the Ashley Madison attackers likewise hacked without consent, making their entry a crime under computer-intrusion statutes [2], yet what they mainly dumped was a *.csv list of user data—names, e-mails, preferences—rather than explicit images, so the act, though humiliating, does not meet legal definitions that hinge on stealing or publishing sexual content. Since factual databases are not copyrightable, efforts to suppress their circulation are weak, and the media may lawfully report on the information even if the source obtained it illegally [4]. Thus, both hacks are illegal privacy breaches, but only the iCloud theft weaponized intimate images, invoking laws and norms aimed at protecting sexual autonomy, while the Ashley Madison leak is treated as a computer and privacy offense accompanied by reputational harm, not a statutory sex crime.

Since factual databases are not copyrightable, efforts to suppress their circulation are weak, and the media may lawfully report on the information even if the source obtained it illegally [4].

Thus, both hacks are illegal privacy breaches, but only the iCloud theft weaponized intimate images, invoking laws and norms aimed at protecting sexual autonomy, while the Ashley Madison leak is treated as a computer and privacy offense accompanied by reputational harm, not a statutory sex crime.
claims_w_citations: George Garofano’s breach of Jennifer Lawrence’s iCloud was punished as a sex-related offense because he stole and spread private nude photographs, directly violating the victims’ sexual privacy and turning the hack into non-consensual pornography distribution [1]; the Ashley Madison attackers likewise hacked without consent, making their entry a crime under computer-intrusion statutes [2], yet what they mainly dumped was a *.csv list of user data—names, e-mails, preferences—rather than explicit images, so the act, though humiliating, does not meet legal definitions that hinge on stealing or publishing sexual content.

Since factual databases are not copyrightable, efforts to suppress their circulation are weak, and the media may lawfully report on the information even if the source obtained it illegally [4].

question_en: Who starts chain letters ("Pass this on or you'll die within the next seven months" or "Send this to ten people within the next seven hours and you'll receive good luck for the next year") and how do they benefit from them? Who profits?
pos_context_title_en: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
pos_context_en: Chain letters are letters that direct the recipient to send out multiple copies so that circulation increases. These letters can be sent via the postal service or by e-mail. The distribution of chain letters through the postal service has neared extinction yet computers have extended the lifespan of this particular type of communication.

They may tell a joke, promise good fortune, threaten you with bad luck, or inform you of another's tragedy or misfortune. These letters often promise the recipients some type of reward if they pass the message on to others. When sent through e-mail, there is usually a long list of previous recipients, but no address or name to identify the original sender. This could possibly be a problem because there is no way to check the authenticity of the letter. Although it is possible for the information to have some truth, chain letters may also contain information that is completely false.

Why do people send chain letters? There are several known reasons to explain the chain letters' popularity. One reason is that it is a great source for obtaining new e-mail addresses. These addresses may lead to new contacts. This tactic can be considered an example of the "free-rider effect". The "free-rider effect" involves depending on others to collectively complete a task. The original senders may, for some reason, decide that they need to obtain e-mail addresses. In order to find these addresses, the senders will initiate a chain letter and rely on the recipients to pass the letter to others. Each time the letter is sent to someone new, their address will be added to the list of recipients and the original senders will have obtained the addresses they wanted while exerting little effort.

Some people send chain letters simply to see how far it will go or to harass another person. There may be times when someone decided that they want to damage a person's or organization's reputation. This is obviously the case with the Neiman-Marcus Cookie Recipe discussed in the Legend of and on the Internet section. Some people are out to get money, and may be successful, through pyramid schemes distributed through an e-mail chain.

Many times these chain letters make promises to the recipient in exchange of sending the message to other people. The recipients may adhere to the senders' request because they believe that sending the message to others will contribute to their good luck. "This belief is an example of self-fulfilling prophecy. Self-fulfilling prophecy is when an originally false social belief leads to its own fulfillment."
report_en: Chain letters are initiated by “original senders” who craft the message and order recipients to forward it, while deliberately omitting any name or address that would reveal their identity [2]. One common motive is harvesting the ever-growing list of e-mail addresses attached as the letter travels; this “free-rider effect” allows the originator to obtain numerous new contacts with almost no effort [3]. Some creators launch a chain merely to monitor its reach or to harass and damage the reputation of a person or organization, such as in the Neiman-Marcus cookie recipe hoax [4]. Others embed pyramid-scheme pitches, hoping that the circulating appeal will funnel money back to them and generate illicit profit [4]. Ultimately, the gains—whether in harvested addresses, personal amusement, reputational harm inflicted on a target, or direct cash—accrue to the initial sender, whereas ordinary participants receive nothing except the fragile promise of good luck or the threat of misfortune that motivates them to comply [5].

question_en: Is Tommy Wiseau serious? Was "The Room" a joke or does he really consider it to be a masterpiece?
pos_context_title_en: The Room: Why so many love ‘the worst film ever made’ (www.bbc.com)
The Room: Why so many love ‘the worst film ever made’ (www.bbc.com)
The Room: Why so many love ‘the worst film ever made’ (www.bbc.com)
Tommy Wiseau - IMDb (www.imdb.com)
pos_context_en: But Room-mania is only just warming up. James Franco is currently directing and starring in The Disaster Artist, a behind-the-scenes comedy about the making of the film. Also in the cast are three of Franco’s fellow Oscar nominees, Bryan Cranston, Sharon Stone and Jacki Weaver. What this means is that some of the best actors in the movie industry are currently pretending to be its worst.

it had a budget of $6 million. Despite looking as if it was thrown together one weekend in a friend’s flat, it was actually shot over six months on a Los Angeles soundstage, and the tales of how Wiseau burnt through all that cash are essential to its mythos. Believe it not, he adapted The Room from a 500-page novel; he shot it on film and on digital video simultaneously; he replaced the crew four times and the cast three times

Somehow, he simply doesn’t see anything wrong with The Room, as much as he enjoys participating in its mockery. “Long story short,” he says, using one of his favourite expressions, “I never called The Room the worst movie ever. That’s number one. Number two, I never called it a cult. But when people call it a cult I think it’s complimentary.”
As a director, I have to feel realism from actors, and they can't be plastic.
report_en: Available evidence suggests that Tommy Wiseau approached The Room as an earnest dramatic project rather than a deliberate parody: he spent an estimated $6 million, shot the film over six months on a Los Angeles soundstage, even running parallel film-and-digital cameras and repeatedly replacing cast and crew—choices more consistent with an ambitious auteur than a prankster [2]; Wiseau insists “I never called The Room the worst movie ever… I never called it a cult,” adding that he sees such labels from fans as merely “complimentary,” indicating he does not perceive the film as a joke [3]; and his own creative credo, “As a director, I have to feel realism from actors, and they can't be plastic,” reinforces that he was striving for authentic drama [4]. While audiences celebrate The Room for its unintentional comedy, Wiseau’s statements and the scale of his financial and logistical commitment imply he genuinely believes he made a serious, high-quality film—perhaps even a masterpiece—only later embracing the cult reception without conceding that the work was meant to be bad.

question_en: How to seeing eye dogs know exactly where their owners want them to go.
pos_context_title_en: How do Guide Dogs work? (chicagolighthouse.org)
Good to know (www.blindenhundeschule.ch)
pos_context_en:
Q: How do dog guides know where to go when traveling?


A: This is a team effort between the dog and its owner. The owner knows where and how he wants to get to a certain place, and he or she is responsible for telling the dog through verbal and hand signals. Directions include forward, left and right. When at a street crossing, the owner is responsible for judging when it is safe to cross based on the sound of the cars, and should then command the dog to begin crossing. Intelligent disobedience is when a dog refuses to cross the street because it is unsafe to do so, even when the owner has commanded it to go forward.

Guide dogs don’t know where the visually impaired or blind person wants to go. The guide dog owner communicates via vocal cues which direction the dog needs to follow. Therefore, guide dog owners need to have a good sense of direction and to keep a map of their route in mind.
report_en: Seeing-eye dogs do not memorize every destination; instead, they work as part of a team in which the visually impaired handler acts as the navigator while the dog serves as the pilot for immediate pathfinding and obstacle avoidance [1]. The handler keeps a mental map of the route and gives clear vocal or hand commands such as “forward,” “left,” and “right,” telling the dog which direction to take at each decision point [1]. At street crossings, the person listens to traffic flow, decides when it is safe, and then instructs the dog to proceed; if a vehicle approaches unexpectedly, the dog is trained to practice “intelligent disobedience,” refusing the command to move until the danger passes [1]. Because the dog relies on these cues to choose paths, guide dog owners must possess good orientation skills and spatial awareness to direct the animal effectively [2].

At street crossings, the person listens to traffic flow, decides when it is safe, and then instructs the dog to proceed; if a vehicle approaches unexpectedly, the dog is trained to practice “intelligent disobedience,” refusing the command to move until the danger passes [1].
Because the dog relies on these cues to choose paths, guide dog owners must possess good orientation skills and spatial awareness to direct the animal effectively [2].

question_en: Can someone explain the Metal Gear Solid plot in story order, not game order.
pos_context_title_en: Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
Can someone provide me with a summary of the Metal Gear Solid series? (gaming.stackexchange.com)
pos_context_en:
## Metal Gear Solid


FOXHOUND rebels and takes over a compound in the Alaska known as Shadow Moses. Once again Solid Snake has to come out of retirement to deal with the bad guys. Luckily this time BIG BOSS is actually dead, but unluckily they have a new METAL GEAR: REX. They also have a couple hostages including Roy Campbell's niece (I never was 100% why all of FOXHOUND except Campbell revolted). You sneak in and save the hostages, fight Revolver Ocelot, who seems to think this is the 1800s, get saved by a creepy Cyborg Ninja, who no one knows and may or may not be a friend and have a short love story with Meryl Silverberg (Campbell's niece).

## Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater


After the cliff hanger at the end of MGS2, in true Metal Gear Solid fashion, MGS3 has nothing to do with it. Instead, MGS3 is a prequel. You're Naked Snake (see how hard was that) who was trained under The BOSS a hero of WW2 who also defects to the Russians. You infiltrate their base, learn about an Illuminati-esque organization The Philosophers who may or may not be dead, meet a young Revolver Ocelot, find out The BOSS didn't defect and is only on a mission, beat up everybody, save the world (but in secret), get dubbed the boss of all bosses: BIG BOSS, and finally get to have sex with a hot chick. Oh and Ocelot works for the CIA under the call sign ADAM... no clue why.

> So apparently after MGS2, when no one decided to do anything about the Patriots they took over the world and made it all about war, either your economy was based on war or your country was in a war. But since it's a modern war its all about the genetic engineered soldiers and nano machines. Controlled, of course, by a system called Sons of the Patriots or SOP (weren't these the guys trying to hide their existance?); and Liquid/Ocelot is out hijack it. So sure enough, Roy Campbell asks Snake to come out of retirement, one more time, and deal with Liquid/Ocelot. Hey, it could be worse. You could be Raiden again...
report_en: In 1964 CIA operative Naked Snake infiltrates Soviet territory, learns his mentor The Boss’s apparent defection is a cover, encounters the secretive Philosophers, destroys the Shagohod, is forced to kill The Boss, and is decorated as BIG BOSS after saving the world in secret [2].  Decades later his former unit FOXHOUND revolts and captures the Shadow Moses base in Alaska, brandishing the nuclear-armed walking tank Metal Gear REX and holding Colonel Campbell’s niece Meryl hostage; retired legend Solid Snake infiltrates, duels Revolver Ocelot and a mysterious Cyborg Ninja, rescues the captives, and eliminates REX, seemingly ending the crisis [1].  Years pass; because no one dismantles the Patriots, they quietly seize global power, turning the entire economy into a nanomachine-regulated perpetual war system called “Sons of the Patriots” (SOP); Liquid/Ocelot aims to hijack this control grid, so Campbell again recalls an aging Snake for one final mission to stop Liquid/Ocelot and shut down SOP, bringing the clandestine struggle full circle [3].

question_en: How do our minds estimate the passage of time?
pos_context_title_en: Your Brain Has 2 Clocks (www.scientificamerican.com)
Physics explains why time passes faster as you age (qz.com)
A stopwatch on the brain's perception of time (www.theguardian.com)
pos_context_en:
Neuroscientists believe that we have distinct neural systems for processing different types of time, for example, to maintain a circadian rhythm, to control the timing of fine body movements, and for conscious awareness of time passage. Until recently, most neuroscientists believed that this latter type of temporal processing – the kind that alerts you when you’ve lingered over breakfast for too long – is supported by a single brain system. However, emerging research indicates that the model of a single neural clock might be too simplistic. A new study, recently published in the Journal of Neuroscience by neuroscientists at the University of California, Irvine, reveals that the brain may in fact have a second method for sensing elapsed time. What’s more, the authors propose that this second internal clock not only works in parallel with our primary neural clock, but may even compete with it.


Past research suggested that a brain region called the striatum lies at the heart of our central inner clock, working with the brain’s surrounding cortex to integrate temporal information.

According to Bejan—who reviewed previous studies in a range of fields on time, vision, cognition, and mental processing to reach his conclusion—time as we experience it represents perceived changes in mental stimuli. It’s related to what we see. As physical mental-image processing time and the rapidity of images we take in changes, so does our perception of time. And in some sense, each of us has our own “mind time” unrelated to the passing of hours, days, and years on clocks and calendars, which is affected by the amount of rest we get and other factors.

It has also been shown that the cerebellum plays a key role in motor tasks requiring perception of implicit timing. Other parts of the brain may be involved in implicit-timing estimates: for example, the left parietal cortex, which manages intended movement, and the left premotor cortex, which plans and organises movement. Sometimes the right prefrontal cortex, usually involved in explicit-timing estimates, is activated for implicit estimates, for instance, when an event does not occur as soon as expected: a traffic light stays red for longer than foreseen. The brain updates its time forecasts, once again anticipating the interval.


In addition, "the regions of the brain involved differ depending on the context, particularly if the stimulus only lasts for a very short time, less than 200 milliseconds," says Coull. The visual cortex is activated when we estimate the duration of a visual stimulus. In the same way, the primary motor cortex comes into play when a timing estimate is associated with an action, whereas the auditory cortex has a part in estimating the length of a sound stimulus.


Above all, the brain's perception of time involves processes linked to memory and attention: witness the impression that time is passing more quickly when we are busy, or doing something amusing or exciting. Time flies even when we are in love. In contrast, a watched pot never boils. Minutes drag by when we are bored.
report_en: The brain does not rely on a single “internal clock”; instead, at least two parallel systems track elapsed time [1]. The dominant mechanism involves the striatum working with surrounding cortex to integrate temporal information, effectively stamping incoming events with time codes [1]. Recent evidence suggests a second clock that can compete with the striatal system, giving the brain an alternative way to sense duration [1]. For very brief intervals (<200 ms) specialized sensory or motor areas—visual, auditory or primary motor cortex—take over timing duties, showing that context shapes which network is recruited [3]. Motor-related timing, such as coordinating a reach, relies on the cerebellum, left parietal and premotor cortices, while unexpected delays (e.g., a lingering red light) engage the right prefrontal cortex to update predictions [3]. Beyond these neural circuits, subjective duration is modulated by memory and attention: time seems to fly when we are busy or emotionally engaged and drags when we are bored [3]. Aging further alters perception because the brain processes and refreshes visual information more slowly, reducing the number of “mental snapshots” and making external time feel faster [2].

The dominant mechanism involves the striatum working with surrounding cortex to integrate temporal information, effectively stamping incoming events with time codes [1].

question_en: Why was the USS Enterprise CVN-65 decommissioned?
pos_context_title_en: USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
USS Enterprise (CVN-65), formerly CVA(N)-65, is a decommissioned[14] United States Navy aircraft carrier. She was the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier and the eighth United States naval vessel to bear the name. Like her predecessor of World War II fame, she is nicknamed "Big E". At 1,123 feet (342 m),[6][7] she is the longest naval vessel ever built. Her 93,284-long-ton (94,781 t)[5] displacement ranks her as the 12th-heaviest carrier, after the ten carriers of the Nimitz class and USS Gerald R. Ford. Enterprise had a crew of some 4,600 service members.[8]


The only ship of her class, Enterprise[15] was, at the time of inactivation, the third-oldest commissioned vessel in the United States Navy after the wooden-hulled USS Constitution and USS Pueblo.[16] She was inactivated on 1 December 2012,[17] and officially decommissioned on 3 February 2017,[18][19] after over 55 years of service.

Enterprise was the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier to be decommissioned.[82] Naval enthusiasts requested that Enterprise be converted into a museum.[83][84] By 2012 this was deemed too expensive to make such an effort practical, in addition to the fact that the ship would need to be partially dismantled anyway to remove the eight reactors safely.[21] A petition was also set up for the next carrier to be named as the ninth USS Enterprise.[85]

The only ship of her class, Enterprise[15] was, at the time of inactivation, the third-oldest commissioned vessel in the United States Navy after the wooden-hulled USS Constitution and USS Pueblo.[16] She was inactivated on 1 December 2012,[17] and officially decommissioned on 3 February 2017,[18][19] after over 55 years of service.
report_en: USS Enterprise (CVN-65) left active service primarily because of her age and the prohibitive cost and complexity of dealing with her eight nuclear reactors. By the time she was inactivated on 1 December 2012 and officially decommissioned on 3 February 2017, she was the third-oldest commissioned vessel in the U.S. Navy, having served for more than 55 years [3]. The Navy considered but rejected proposals to preserve her as a museum, concluding that the expense was too high and that the ship would still have to be partly dismantled to remove the reactors safely [2]. Consequently, Enterprise became the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier ever taken out of service [2].

question_en: Why do actors and voice actors make so much money?
pos_context_title_en: Why celebrities earn so much money — and what it says about our society (www.abc.net.au)
Why celebrities earn so much money — and what it says about our society (www.abc.net.au)
Pros & Cons of Actors' Salaries (work.chron.com)
Pros & Cons of Actors' Salaries (work.chron.com)
pos_context_en: Sports stars and celebrities are idolised for their talents and, oftentimes, their looks, so it makes sense that brands are keen to profit off their cachet through job contracts and endorsement deals.

1. 1.How many people can perform the role
2. 2.Whether the role generates revenue or prestige for the employer

Elite actors usually negotiate their salaries for each movie contract. This gives them the chance to determine how much their skills are worth. They can also compare one opportunity with another. With bigger budgets, blockbuster productions expect to earn a lot of revenue so actors earn more money.
More actors struggle to earn a living than make it big. The median actor pay in 2019 was ​$20.43​ per hour, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
report_en: Actors and voice actors secure multimillion-dollar deals for the same reasons other high-profile celebrities do: only a handful of performers can convincingly carry a lead role, so their scarcity lets them charge premium rates [2]. Studios accept these prices because star power is proven to generate ticket sales, streaming subscriptions and merchandising, meaning a blockbuster’s nine-figure budget can be recouped only if bankable names attract audiences; therefore, as expected revenue rises, so do negotiated salaries [3]. Elite performers also monetise their public image through endorsements, with brands willing to pay to borrow the prestige and fan loyalty that stars command [1]. Crucially, these headline figures apply to a tiny upper tier—most actors earn far less, and the U.S. median acting wage was only $20.43 per hour in 2019, underscoring that the industry’s pay is highly unequal [4]. Thus, extraordinary income reflects rarity, revenue potential and marketable fame rather than the average experience of the profession.

question_en: why does the file size of digital photos vary when the pixel count doesn't change?
pos_context_title_en: What is the difference between image size, file size, and image quality? (www.sony.com)
Factors affecting file size (digitalmediaresources.weebly.com)
Bitmaps and File Size | Understand How Color Works in Photoshop (www.peachpit.com)
Color Depth (65k, 262k, 16.7M colors) (focuslcds.com)
pos_context_en:
Image size: This represents the physical size and resolution of an image measured in pixels. For example, A 10 megapixel (MP) camera may provide settings to take pictures in 10.2 MP (3872 x 2592), 5.6 MP (2896 x 1944), and 2.5 MP (1936 x 1296). A higher image size setting means a larger picture and bigger file size. A lower image size setting makes a smaller picture and smaller file size. Depending on your camera, there may be different sizes available.


File size: This is the amount of space that the image file takes up on your memory card, or internal memory if your camera has one. It is measured in megabytes. The actual file size depends on the image size and image quality settings selected on the camera.


Image quality: This dictates how much compression is used to record the file information. Some digital cameras have a Fine and Standard setting where the Fine setting uses less compression than the Standard setting. Therefore, the detail of a picture taken with the Fine setting is a sharper than one taken with the Standard setting. Similar to the image size setting discussed above, this also affects the file size. Since the Fine setting uses less compression and records more detail, the file size will be larger than one recorded with the standard setting.
Compression is the process of reducing the size of a file. It is achieved by encoding the file in an efficient way, allowing it to be smaller.

If each pixel is defined using 8 bits of color information, then the file is eight times bigger than a black-and-white bitmap. Similarly, a 24-bit file is a full three times bigger than the 8-bit image, and a 48-bit file is twice the size of a 24-bit one.

Color depth is the number of colors that can be used for each pixel on the display. This can range from 8- bit color, 16-bit high color to 24-bit true color. The range of color is determined by how many bits of red, green and blue (RGB) each pixel is assigned to the frame buffer.
report_en: File size changes even when the resolution (pixel count) is fixed because what matters is how much information is stored for each pixel and how efficiently that information is encoded: selecting a higher image-quality setting applies less compression, so more data are kept and the resulting file is larger, while a lower quality setting applies stronger compression and yields a smaller file [1]; compression itself is the process of encoding the same data more efficiently to reduce size [2]; moreover, the color depth assigned to each pixel strongly affects size—an image stored with 24-bit color is three times larger than the same image stored with 8-bit color because each pixel carries three times more information [3].
all_claims: File size changes even when the resolution (pixel count) is fixed because what matters is how much information is stored for each pixel and how efficiently that information is encoded: selecting a higher image-quality setting applies less compression, so more data are kept and the resulting file is larger, while a lower quality setting applies stronger compression and yields a smaller file [1]; compression itself is the process of encoding the same data more efficiently to reduce size [2]; moreover, the color depth assigned to each pixel strongly affects size—an image stored with 24-bit color is three times larger than the same image stored with 8-bit color because each pixel carries three times more information [3].

question_en: Why am I unstable on my bike when it's stationary but not when it's moving?
pos_context_title_en: Why Does A Moving Bicycle Stay Up? (www.science20.com)
Balancing on a Bicycle: The Phenomena (www.mentalfloss.com)
pos_context_en:
Since the bicycle was invented, s cientists have postulated various reasons as to why a bicycle is self stable above a certain speed. The consensus has been that a bicycle's stability is related to two factors: First, the rotating wheels of the bicycle provide stability through gyroscopic effects; secondly, that the ‘trail’, the distance by which the contact point of the front wheel trails behind the steering axis, plays an important part.

A new study in Science claims to have settled the issue - gyroscopic effects and trail help, says researcher Dr Arend Schwab of the 3mE faculty at TU Delft, but are not necessary above a certain speed . In a 2007 Proceedings of the Royal Society article (doi:10.1098/rspa.2007.1857), a mathematical model with around 25 physical parameters was developed at the time which appeared to predict whether, and at what speeds, a particular design of bicycle would be stable.

A bicycle, on the other hand, is statically unstable because it only has two contact points with the ground (whatever portion of the front and back wheels happen to be touching the ground) and its base of support is a line segment. A good base of support needs at least three contact points with the ground, so bikes are hard to keep upright when they're still. Bikes are, however, dynamically stable, or stable when moving forward, because steering allows a rider to move the bike's points of support around under the center of gravity and keep it balanced, often with steering adjustments small enough that the rider may not even realize they're making them. It's sort of like standing on one foot. If you don't hop around a little, and you start falling sideways, you can't recover and you fall over. If you do hop, though, you can move your foot around to keep your center of gravity above it and keep your balance.


A bike has two features that help this dynamic stability immensely: its wheels. Spinning wheels have angular momentum, and when you're sitting on a bike, you and it and its wheels make up a system that obeys the principle of conservation of angular momentum. Unless torque, or twisting force, is applied from outside the system to change the wheels' angular momentum, that momentum and the direction of the momentum remain constant. In a nutshell, once the wheels line up a certain way, they want to stay lined up like that. It's easy for you to move them, but hard for an outside force to do the same, and so the bike is easy to keep balanced but doesn't topple easily. A non-moving bike has wheels that aren't spinning and zero angular momentum, which makes it very easy for external torque to change the wheels' direction, making the bike harder to balance.
report_en: Bikes tip over when stationary because they are statically unstable: with only two small patches of tyre touching the ground their base of support is just a narrow line, whereas at least three contact points are needed for passive balance, so any sideways deviation lets gravity rotate the frame and you fall [2]. Once you start rolling, several dynamic mechanisms take over [2]. First, the spinning wheels carry angular momentum; by conservation, they resist changes to their orientation, so small gusts or bumps cannot quickly twist them and topple the bike [2]. Second, forward motion lets you steer—consciously or subconsciously—so the front wheel continually moves the contact line back under the combined centre of gravity in much the same way that hopping keeps a person upright on one foot [2]. Finally, typical bicycle geometry (trail of the front wheel and, to a lesser extent, gyroscopic effects) naturally generates a restoring steer that points the wheel into a lean and straightens the bike, giving most designs self-stability above a modest speed of only a few metres per second [1]. Hence a moving bike is dynamically stable, while a stationary one is not.
all_claims: Bikes tip over when stationary because they are statically unstable: with only two small patches of tyre touching the ground their base of support is just a narrow line, whereas at least three contact points are needed for passive balance, so any sideways deviation lets gravity rotate the frame and you fall [2].
Once you start rolling, several dynamic mechanisms take over [2].
First, the spinning wheels carry angular momentum; by conservation, they resist changes to their orientation, so small gusts or bumps cannot quickly twist them and topple the bike [2].

Second, forward motion lets you steer—consciously or subconsciously—so the front wheel continually moves the contact line back under the combined centre of gravity in much the same way that hopping keeps a person upright on one foot [2].

Finally, typical bicycle geometry (trail of the front wheel and, to a lesser extent, gyroscopic effects) naturally generates a restoring steer that points the wheel into a lean and straightens the bike, giving most designs self-stability above a modest speed of only a few metres per second [1].
Hence a moving bike is dynamically stable, while a stationary one is not.

Once you start rolling, several dynamic mechanisms take over [2].
First, the spinning wheels carry angular momentum; by conservation, they resist changes to their orientation, so small gusts or bumps cannot quickly twist them and topple the bike [2].

Second, forward motion lets you steer—consciously or subconsciously—so the front wheel continually moves the contact line back under the combined centre of gravity in much the same way that hopping keeps a person upright on one foot [2].

Finally, typical bicycle geometry (trail of the front wheel and, to a lesser extent, gyroscopic effects) naturally generates a restoring steer that points the wheel into a lean and straightens the bike, giving most designs self-stability above a modest speed of only a few metres per second [1].

question_en: Why is it that a fully buffered YouTube video will buffer again from where you click on the progress bar when you skip a few seconds ahead?
pos_context_title_en: How to Stop Buffering When Streaming | SatelliteInternet.com (www.satelliteinternet.com)
YouTube Keeps Buffering? - Best Way to Fix It (www.istarapps.com)
pos_context_en: Your streaming service is buffering either because your internet connection can’t keep up with the amount of data coming in or your streaming provider can’t push the data to your device fast enough.

Interestingly, YouTube buffering can happen even if you have a high-speed internet connection. That can happen due to slower servers from their end, and your connection speed doesn’t affect that.


As we already know, YouTube is equipped with the most powerful internet connections in the world. Also, their servers and other infrastructure come with cutting edge technology. However, that doesn’t prevent YouTube from experiencing occasional hiccups, particularly when there is heavy traffic.


In fact, when plenty of users visit YouTube and watch videos simultaneously, the performance of the servers is tested. In that case, the servers have to communicate with all the clients and transfer data constantly. If something goes wrong, the users will experience various issues, and YouTube keeps buffering is one of those issues.
report_en: What appears to be a “fully buffered” YouTube video is actually only a series of short data segments stored ahead of the playhead; when you click farther along the progress bar, the player discards those stored segments and must request new ones that start at the new timestamp, so playback halts until fresh data arrives—this pause is the new buffering event. If your connection cannot pull the next segment fast enough, or if YouTube’s servers are momentarily strained by heavy traffic, the data flow stalls and the wheel spins even though you had no trouble seconds earlier [1]. In fact, YouTube’s servers can slow down under peak demand, triggering buffering for many users regardless of their own internet speed, so the problem may lie at YouTube’s end rather than yours [2].

If your connection cannot pull the next segment fast enough, or if YouTube’s servers are momentarily strained by heavy traffic, the data flow stalls and the wheel spins even though you had no trouble seconds earlier [1].
In fact, YouTube’s servers can slow down under peak demand, triggering buffering for many users regardless of their own internet speed, so the problem may lie at YouTube’s end rather than yours [2].

question_en: why was the Federal Tort Claims Act needed, I thought the Bill of Rights gave us the right to go to court against the US Government?
pos_context_title_en: VA.gov | Veterans Affairs (www.va.gov)
The Bill of Rights: What Does it Say? (www.archives.gov)
Federal Tort Claims Act (www.opm.gov)
pos_context_en: The Federal Tort Claims Act prescribes a uniform procedure for handling of claims against the United States, for money damages only, on account of damage to or loss of property, or personal injury or death, caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of a Government employee while acting within the scope of his or her office or employment, under circumstances where the United States, if a private person, would be liable in accordance with the law of the place where the act or omission occurred.

The Bill of Rights is the first 10 Amendments to the Constitution. It spells out Americans’ rights in relation to their government. It guarantees civil rights and liberties to the individual—like freedom of speech, press, and religion

The Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) sets forth procedures for presenting and resolving administrative monetary claims for personal injury, property damage, or death arising from the alleged negligence of officers and employees of the Office of Personnel Management acting in the scope of their official duties.
report_en: The Bill of Rights guarantees fundamental freedoms—such as speech, press, and religion—but it does not waive the long-standing doctrine of “sovereign immunity,” under which the United States could not be sued for damages without its own consent [2].  To give that consent in an orderly way, Congress enacted the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) in 1946, creating a uniform administrative and judicial process that lets people seek money damages when they are injured or their property is damaged by the negligent or wrongful acts of federal employees acting within the scope of their employment, under circumstances where a private person would be liable [1].  In short, the Constitution recognizes individual rights, but the FTCA was needed to translate those rights into a practical, nationwide mechanism for holding the federal government financially accountable in tort, replacing the cumbersome practice of seeking private bills in Congress and ensuring that claims are handled through the courts under state law principles rather than by legislative grace.
all_claims: The Bill of Rights guarantees fundamental freedoms—such as speech, press, and religion—but it does not waive the long-standing doctrine of “sovereign immunity,” under which the United States could not be sued for damages without its own consent [2].

To give that consent in an orderly way, Congress enacted the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) in 1946, creating a uniform administrative and judicial process that lets people seek money damages when they are injured or their property is damaged by the negligent or wrongful acts of federal employees acting within the scope of their employment, under circumstances where a private person would be liable [1].

In short, the Constitution recognizes individual rights, but the FTCA was needed to translate those rights into a practical, nationwide mechanism for holding the federal government financially accountable in tort, replacing the cumbersome practice of seeking private bills in Congress and ensuring that claims are handled through the courts under state law principles rather than by legislative grace.

To give that consent in an orderly way, Congress enacted the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) in 1946, creating a uniform administrative and judicial process that lets people seek money damages when they are injured or their property is damaged by the negligent or wrongful acts of federal employees acting within the scope of their employment, under circumstances where a private person would be liable [1].

question_en: How were continents, countries and coastlines mapped out prior to the invention of satellites?
pos_context_title_en: How did cartographers map out shores before modern times? (outdoors.stackexchange.com)
How did cartographers map out shores before modern times? (outdoors.stackexchange.com)
How did cartographers map out shores before modern times? (outdoors.stackexchange.com)
The Mystery of Extraordinarily Accurate Medieval Maps (www.discovermagazine.com)
pos_context_en:
"piloting". With piloting, you are determining your location using bearings from reference points on accurate maps. Here, we are using the bearing to objects to determine position of points along the coastline. Still, it works much the same way.


Maps - especially of shorelines - were almost certainly made from observations taken from boats. Naval navigation is much more accurate than navigation on land (especially without good maps!).

Prior to the mid-1700's, the primary means of navigation was dead reckoning (DR). This requires that you iteratively advance your position on the map from your last known position using direction and time/distance. Of course, over time, errors will compound resulting in reduced accuracy. You must have a way of measuring your direction of travel and a (somewhat) accurate value for your speed.


Later in the 1700's, it was possible to navigate more accurately using celestial navigation. This allowed a skilled navigator to determine his position rather accurately (typically within a few miles) at any point on the globe. The position was typically found once each day and advanced using DR as necessary.

The topics of navigation and cartography are two sides of the same coin, and there are entire books written about each. It is interesting to study the history of cartography because it very graphically shows the corresponding improvements in navigation over time.


In order to make an accurate map, you need to know first where you are making your observations from. Making the observations from a previously known position will result in much greater accuracy. This position may have been established by an earlier survey (eg, working from a known point on an existing map) or by being able to independently figure out your position with good certainty on the position of the globe.

The problem was the portolan mapmakers’ lack of a systematic way of reducing the spherical Earth to a flat map. That was of little consequence for short journeys but mattered much more when sailing longer distances. In 1569, the Belgian geographer and cartographer Gerardus Mercator created his method for presenting a spherical world on a flat map, the one familiar to us today. This mapmaking technique, though it stretched and compressed landmarks and distances between them, had the great advantage that a straight compass course was represented by a straight line on the map.


Mercator’s projections began to be used to sail the open seas by the early 1800s, by which time portolan charts had pretty much disappeared. But their importance is undeniable. “The development of these maps revolutionized how people perceived space, much like Google Earth has done in our lifetimes,” Hessler says. “Understanding how the technology was developed gives us insight into how we got here, and perhaps into where we’re going.”
report_en: Before satellites, cartographers relied on practical navigation and geometric surveying: mariners mapped coasts by “piloting,” taking compass bearings to known shore landmarks and intersecting these lines to plot new points on the chart [1]; when land disappeared, they advanced their position by dead-reckoning, estimating course, speed and time, though errors accumulated with distance [2]. From the mid-1700s onward, daily celestial sightings of the Sun, Moon or stars fixed latitude and longitude “within a few miles,” providing accurate control points to which fresh coastline sketches could be tied [2]. Surveyors, working from ships or stations on land, then sketched the intervening shore and, journey by journey, transferred these observations to master charts. Because accuracy depended on knowing the observer’s own location, surveys typically began from previously established points or sites whose positions could be independently verified, chaining measurements outward until whole countries were outlined [3]. Finally, Mercator’s 1569 cylindrical projection, adopted for ocean navigation by the early 1800s, let mapmakers convert their accumulated spherical coordinates into a flat, standardized world map for long-distance voyaging [4].
all_claims: Before satellites, cartographers relied on practical navigation and geometric surveying: mariners mapped coasts by “piloting,” taking compass bearings to known shore landmarks and intersecting these lines to plot new points on the chart [1]; when land disappeared, they advanced their position by dead-reckoning, estimating course, speed and time, though errors accumulated with distance [2].

From the mid-1700s onward, daily celestial sightings of the Sun, Moon or stars fixed latitude and longitude “within a few miles,” providing accurate control points to which fresh coastline sketches could be tied [2].
Surveyors, working from ships or stations on land, then sketched the intervening shore and, journey by journey, transferred these observations to master charts.

Because accuracy depended on knowing the observer’s own location, surveys typically began from previously established points or sites whose positions could be independently verified, chaining measurements outward until whole countries were outlined [3].

Finally, Mercator’s 1569 cylindrical projection, adopted for ocean navigation by the early 1800s, let mapmakers convert their accumulated spherical coordinates into a flat, standardized world map for long-distance voyaging [4].

question_en: Why is wearing a swastika considered taboo but every biker I see wears an iron cross on his shirt, jacket, skin or motorcycle?
pos_context_title_en: Swastika (en.wikipedia.org)
History of the Swastika (encyclopedia.ushmm.org)
Iron Cross (www.adl.org)
Iron Cross (www.adl.org)
pos_context_en: In the Western world, it was a symbol of auspiciousness and good luck until the 1930s[4] when the right-facing tilted form became a feature of Nazi symbolism as an emblem of the Aryan race. As a result of World War II and the Holocaust, many people in the West still strongly associate it with Nazism and antisemitism.

The Nazi Party was not the only party to use the swastika in Germany. After World War I, a number of far-right nationalist movements adopted the swastika. As a symbol, it became associated with the idea of a racially “pure” state. By the time the Nazis gained control of Germany, the connotations of the swastika had forever changed.

The Iron Cross is a famous German military medal dating back to the 19th century. During the 1930s, the Nazi regime in Germany superimposed a swastika on the traditional medal, turning it into a Nazi symbol. After World War II, the medal was discontinued but neo-Nazis and other white supremacists subsequently adopted it as a hate symbol and it has been a commonly-used hate symbol ever since.

In the United States, however, the Iron Cross also became one of several Nazi-era symbols adopted by outlaw bikers, more to signify rebellion or to shock than for any white supremacist ideology. By the early 2000s, this other use of the Iron Cross had spread from bikers to skateboarders and many extreme sports enthusiasts and became part of the logo of several different companies producing equipment and clothing for this audience. Consequently, the use of the Iron Cross in a non-racist context has greatly proliferated in the United States, to the point that an Iron Cross in isolation (i.e., without a superimposed swastika or without other accompanying hate symbols) cannot be determined to be a hate symbol.
report_en: In the West, the swastika was once a good-luck symbol, but after the Nazi Party adopted its right-facing tilted form in the 1930s as an emblem of the “Aryan race,” it became indelibly tied to World War II, the Holocaust, and antisemitism, so most Westerners now view it strictly as a Nazi hate symbol [1]. Because of this direct association, wearing a swastika is considered socially taboo and provocative rather than merely decorative [1]. The Iron Cross, however, originated as a Prussian (later German) military medal in the 19th century, and although the Nazis later superimposed a swastika on it, the underlying cross design predates Nazi rule and survived after their defeat [3]. Post-war U.S. outlaw bikers adopted the plain Iron Cross chiefly to signal rebellion or shock value, and by the early 2000s it had migrated to skateboard and extreme-sports fashion brands [4]. Thanks to this widespread non-racist usage, an Iron Cross shown alone—without a swastika or other hate markings—is generally not presumed to endorse white supremacy, making it far more socially acceptable than the swastika [4].

question_en: How does CRISPR work in a practical sense?
pos_context_title_en: Explainer: How CRISPR works (www.sciencenewsforstudents.org)
Explainer: How CRISPR works (www.sciencenewsforstudents.org)
Explainer: How CRISPR works (www.sciencenewsforstudents.org)
The Xenobot Future Is Coming—Start Planning Now (www.wired.com)
A New Technique That Lets Scientists Edit DNA Is Transforming Science—and Raising Difficult Questions (time.com)
pos_context_en: CRISPR stands for “clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.”
This CRISPR/Cas9 tool was first described in 2012 and 2013. Science labs around the world soon started using it to alter an organism’s genome — the entire set of its DNA instructions.

This tool can quickly and efficiently tweak almost any gene in any plant or animal. Researchers already have used it to fix genetic diseases in animals, to combat viruses and to sterilize mosquitoes. They have also used it to prepare pig organs for human transplants and to beef up the muscles in beagles.

Crispr might be new, but the key points of our conversation were hardly original. We focused on the scientists’ concerns—regulatory uncertainties, access to research funding, intellectual property ownership—and on the government officials’ concerns—national security and public backlash to engineered “designer babies.” The same conversation happened in 1991 when the first gene therapy trials started on humans, and again in 1996 with the birth of Dolly, a cloned sheep. A few years later, in 2003, the sequencing of the first human genome raised the same concerns. The questions were always narrow and reductive, in part because those asking the questions only imagined a future in which we cut, copied, and pasted existing genetic material. They failed to see a future in which anyone could create life from scratch.

It was. Zhang’s work demonstrated that CRISPR could be used to precisely and efficiently edit the DNA of human cells. And with that, the revolution was under way.


Today you can go online to any number of biological-supply companies and order your own CRISPR kit for as little as $130.
report_en: CRISPR stands for “clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats” [1]. In practical use, it is paired with the Cas9 protein, and since its 2012–2013 debut laboratories worldwide have employed the CRISPR/Cas9 system to edit an organism’s genome—the complete set of DNA instructions [2]. By programming the tool to target a specific gene, researchers can quickly and efficiently tweak almost any gene in plants or animals, letting them fix genetic diseases in animals, fight viruses, sterilize mosquitoes, ready pig organs for human transplants, and bulk up beagle muscles [3]. The method’s accessibility is evident in do-it-yourself kits that can be ordered online for about $130 [5]. Together, these features make CRISPR a fast, precise and widely available genome-editing toolkit with applications ranging from basic research to potential medical therapies.

question_en: Year counting in ancient Greece
pos_context_title_en: The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
pos_context_en:
The Athenians seem to have taken a rather casual attitude towards their calendar. It appears they used neither a regular formula nor continuous direct observation to determine the length of the months. Most likely, they followed a general rule of alternating months (29 and 30 days long), subject to periodic correction by observation.

In addition to this calendar, which has been called the festival calendar, Athenians maintained a second calendar for the political year. This "conciliar" year divided the year into "prytanies," one for each of the "phylai," the subdivisions of Athenian citizens. The number of phylai, and hence the number of prytanies, varies over time. Until 307 BCE, there were 10 phylai.

After that the number varies between 11 and 13 (usually 12). Even more confusing, while the conciliar and festival years were basically the same length in the 4th century BCE, such was not regularly the case earlier or later. Thus documents dated by prytany are frequently very difficult to assign to a particular equivalent in the Julian calendar, although we are usually secure in assigning an approximate date

Ancient historians date by Olympiad by giving both the number of the Olympiad and the year within the cycle, 1-4 (the Olympiad itself was held on year 1). Additionally, lists of Olympic winners were maintained, and the 3rd c. BCE writer Timaios compiled a synchronic list comparing Olympic winners, Athenian archons, Spartan kings, and the priests of Hera from Argos.

Olympiad 1,1 correlates to 776 BCE. We do not actually need to believe an actual festival was held on this date, but when Greek historians are writing in later times, they date their own events using this as the epoch. We can establish a precise correlation to the common era from a variety of different sources, but the most definitive comes from a passage in Diodorus, where he dates the year of a total solar eclipse to the reign of the Athenian archon Hieromnemon, which he also gives as Ol. 117,3. The only astronomically possible date for this event is August 15, 310 BCE, which fixes our epoch
report_en: Ancient Greeks did not share a universal era; instead they expressed a date by naming the local year and month together with a political or athletic marker, most notably the Athenian civic calendar and the pan-Hellenic Olympiad cycle.  In Athens the ordinary “festival” year was lunisolar: months were nominally alternated 30 days (full) and 29 days (hollow) and length was adjusted ad hoc by observation, so the sequence could drift until an extra day or month was inserted [1].  Parallel to it ran a “conciliar” or prytany calendar used for official documents; the political year was divided into prytanies, one for each phylē (tribe), originally 10 but fluctuating between 11 and 13 after 307 BCE, making conversion to modern dating difficult when prytany lengths changed [1].  For events of pan-Greek importance historians instead cited the Olympiad: a four-year cycle numbered by Olympiad and by year 1-4, with the epoch fixed at Olympiad 1, year 1 = 776 BCE; correlation with the Common Era is secured because Diodorus links a total solar eclipse in the archonship of Hieromnemon to Olympiad 117,3, identifiable as 15 August 310 BCE [2].
all_claims: Ancient Greeks did not share a universal era; instead they expressed a date by naming the local year and month together with a political or athletic marker, most notably the Athenian civic calendar and the pan-Hellenic Olympiad cycle.

In Athens the ordinary “festival” year was lunisolar: months were nominally alternated 30 days (full) and 29 days (hollow) and length was adjusted ad hoc by observation, so the sequence could drift until an extra day or month was inserted [1].

Parallel to it ran a “conciliar” or prytany calendar used for official documents; the political year was divided into prytanies, one for each phylē (tribe), originally 10 but fluctuating between 11 and 13 after 307 BCE, making conversion to modern dating difficult when prytany lengths changed [1].

For events of pan-Greek importance historians instead cited the Olympiad: a four-year cycle numbered by Olympiad and by year 1-4, with the epoch fixed at Olympiad 1, year 1 = 776 BCE; correlation with the Common Era is secured because Diodorus links a total solar eclipse in the archonship of Hieromnemon to Olympiad 117,3, identifiable as 15 August 310 BCE [2].

For events of pan-Greek importance historians instead cited the Olympiad: a four-year cycle numbered by Olympiad and by year 1-4, with the epoch fixed at Olympiad 1, year 1 = 776 BCE; correlation with the Common Era is secured because Diodorus links a total solar eclipse in the archonship of Hieromnemon to Olympiad 117,3, identifiable as 15 August 310 BCE [2].

question_en: How does a song get transported across an aux cable from a phone and get played in the car?
pos_context_title_en: Plugging in: differences between optical and aux audio (www.orbitsound.com)
Aux Inputs vs. USB Connections (www.lifewire.com)
The Physics of How Your Earphone Jack Works (Just in Time to Say Goodbye) (www.wired.com)
pos_context_en: In the timeline of these two formats, aux came first, in the 1960s. It’s an analogue medium, meaning it can only transmit sound. In addition to this aux cables are made of copper, and the data transmitted through it do so via the continuous waveform of electrical information.

The main difference between a USB (Universal Serial Bus) connection and an auxiliary input is that USB cords send digital information while aux cables send analog signals. USB cords transfer data as you would to a computer, while aux cables transmit audio as you would to an amplifier or pair of headphones.

At the most basic level, an earphone is a loop of wire with current running through it. This electric current in the loop then interacts with a permanent magnet which in turn pushes the air---that's sound.
report_en: When you press play on your phone, its audio circuitry converts the stored digital music file into an analog voltage that varies exactly with the original sound wave; this continuously changing electrical signal is delivered to the car through the auxiliary (3.5 mm) cable’s copper conductors, which simply carry the waveform like any other piece of wire [1]. Because an aux line transports analog rather than digital data, no file formatting or decoding takes place in the cable itself— it is just the raw sound information represented as varying current and voltage [2]. Inside the car stereo, the same signal is fed to an amplifier, where higher-power current flows through coils attached to each loudspeaker; the interaction of this current loop with a permanent magnet pushes and pulls the speaker cone, compressing the air so you hear the music [3].

Because an aux line transports analog rather than digital data, no file formatting or decoding takes place in the cable itself— it is just the raw sound information represented as varying current and voltage [2].

Inside the car stereo, the same signal is fed to an amplifier, where higher-power current flows through coils attached to each loudspeaker; the interaction of this current loop with a permanent magnet pushes and pulls the speaker cone, compressing the air so you hear the music [3].

question_en: Why don't general physicians cover teeth?
pos_context_title_en: The Reason Your Dental Work Isn't Covered by Medical Insurance (www.nbcnews.com)
Why Doesn’t Health Insurance Cover Dental and Vision, Too? (melmagazine.com)
Why Doesn’t Health Insurance Cover Dental and Vision, Too? (melmagazine.com)
pos_context_en:
We may have since greatly evolved in how we regard and understand dentistry, but we haven’t embraced it as a primarily medical issue; if we had, it would be covered under medical insurance, or at least, things like a root canal would be, because if you need a root canal and don’t get one, you could end up with all kinds of lethal problems that lead to hospitalization. It is rumored that Queen Elizabeth died from blood poisoning as a result of an untreated tooth infection. That was a long time ago, but hey, it happens.

Why isn’t a health problem so serious it can be deadly, not considered medical? To an extent, it’s because it’s not that common to end up in the hospital as a result of a tooth or gum problem — not if you’re keeping up with preventative dental care.

That aside, one of the main reasons why our eyes and teeth are ignored by most health-care plans has to do with history and stigma. For one, dentistry and medicine have long been considered to be distinctly different practices. Until the 1800s, barbers served as unsophisticated dentists, pulling teeth and piercing abscesses after giving you a nice, close shave. As time went on, dentistry (and ophthalmology, to some degree) was regarded as less advanced than medicine, which seeped into the minds of Congress while they formulated public health insurance policies in the 1960s. As just one example of the general sentiment during those times, in 1940, an appellate court in New York decided that dentists weren’t doctors, and thus not deserving of the same prestige.

This same stigma has also led to a perception that dental and vision problems are perhaps less serious than “medical” ones, and therefore should be kept separate. (Some people may also mistakenly feel like dental problems are a personal problem that has to do with your own lapses in dental hygiene, whereas medical problems can affect everyone.) But this is a questionable stance: More than 50,000 people will be diagnosed with oral cancer this year. Research has demonstrated links between periodontal infections and chronic conditions, like diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Surely, tons of people end up in the ER because of accidents caused by them not being able to see well enough. And what about all the people who lose out on opportunities because they have a missing tooth?
report_en: General physicians typically do not “cover” teeth because, historically, dentistry evolved as a trade separate from medicine—barbers once pulled teeth and lanced abscesses, so lawmakers and the public came to view oral care as less sophisticated than other medical practice areas [2]; this attitude persisted into the 20th century, exemplified by a 1940 New York appellate court decision that dentists were not doctors and therefore did not merit the same professional status or inclusion in mainstream health-care plans [2]. When Congress built public and private insurance systems in the 1960s, that stigma translated into policies that carved dental benefits out of standard medical coverage [2]. The enduring perception that tooth and gum problems rarely lead to hospitalization if people maintain routine care further reinforces their separation from general health services, even though neglected infections can in fact become life-threatening [1].

When Congress built public and private insurance systems in the 1960s, that stigma translated into policies that carved dental benefits out of standard medical coverage [2].

The enduring perception that tooth and gum problems rarely lead to hospitalization if people maintain routine care further reinforces their separation from general health services, even though neglected infections can in fact become life-threatening [1].

question_en: How can someone put me in to jail if i am not guilty?
pos_context_title_en: Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
pos_context_en: The rate of wrongful convictions in the United States is estimated to be somewhere between 2 percent and 10 percent. That may sound low, but when applied to an estimated prison population of 2.3 million, the numbers become staggering. Can there really be 46,000 to 230,000 innocent people locked away? Those of us who are involved in exoneration work firmly believe so.

Bad police work. Most cops are honest, hard-working professionals. But some have been known to hide, alter or fabricate evidence; lie on the stand; cut deals in return for bogus testimony; intimidate and threaten witnesses; coerce confessions; or manipulate eyewitness identifications.

Prosecutorial misconduct. Most prosecutors are also honest, hard-working professionals. But some have been known to hide exculpatory evidence; encourage witnesses to commit perjury; lie to jurors, judges and defense lawyers; use the testimony of bogus experts; or ignore relevant evidence beneficial to the accused.

False confessions. Most jurors find it impossible to believe that a suspect would confess to a serious crime he didn't commit. Yet the average citizen, if taken to a basement room and subjected to 10 consecutive hours of abusive interrogation tactics by experienced cops, might be surprised at what they would say. Of the 330 people who were exonerated by DNA evidence between 1989 to 2015, about 25 percent gave bogus confessions after lengthy interrogations
report_en: Even if you have done nothing wrong, systemic flaws can still lead to your imprisonment: studies suggest that 2-10 % of U.S. convictions are wrongful, meaning as many as 46,000-230,000 innocent people may currently be incarcerated [1]; this can begin with bad police work, where an officer fabricates or alters evidence, coerces eyewitness identifications or confessions, or trades favors for false testimony, all of which can mislead jurors and judges [2]; the problem can be compounded by prosecutorial misconduct, such as hiding exculpatory material, encouraging witnesses to lie, or presenting bogus expert opinions, thereby depriving the defense and the court of information that would prove your innocence [3]; finally, sustained, high-pressure interrogations—sometimes lasting ten hours or more—can push a suspect to confess to a crime they did not commit, a phenomenon seen in about 25 % of the first 330 DNA exonerations in the U.S. between 1989 and 2015 [4].

question_en: Scientifically speaking , how likely is it that our existence is extremely small?
pos_context_title_en: Rare Earth hypothesis (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en: The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that the evolution of biological complexity anywhere in the universe requires the coincidence of a large number of fortuitous circumstances, including, among others, a galactic habitable zone; a central star and planetary system having the requisite character (i.e. a circumstellar habitable zone); a terrestrial planet of the right mass; the advantage of one or more gas giant guardians like Jupiter and possibly a large natural satellite to shield the planet from frequent impact events; conditions needed to ensure the planet has a magnetosphere and plate tectonics; a chemistry similar to that present in the Earth's lithosphere, atmosphere, and oceans; the influence of periodic "evolutionary pumps" such as massive glaciations and bolide impacts; and whatever factors may have led to the emergence of eukaryotic cells, sexual reproduction, and the Cambrian explosion of animal, plant, and fungi phyla. The evolution of human beings and of human intelligence may have required yet further specific events and circumstances, all of which are extremely unlikely to have happened
report_en: Scientific assessments grounded in the Rare Earth hypothesis conclude that the probability of a planet evolving complex, intelligent life is extremely low, because it requires the simultaneous occurrence of many independent, rare conditions: location in a galactic habitable zone, orbit around a suitably calm star within a circumstellar habitable zone, a terrestrial mass that can sustain plate tectonics and a magnetosphere, the protective presence of gas-giant “guardians,” a large stabilizing moon, Earth-like surface chemistry, and a sequence of evolutionary “pumps” (e.g., global glaciations and major impacts) that ultimately yield eukaryotes and events like the Cambrian explosion [1]. Multiplying such low-probability factors suggests that the expected number of civilizations in our galaxy could be well below one, meaning our existence may be an extremely rare statistical outlier; however, the precise likelihood remains uncertain because most of these probabilities are still observationally unconstrained [1].
all_claims: Scientific assessments grounded in the Rare Earth hypothesis conclude that the probability of a planet evolving complex, intelligent life is extremely low, because it requires the simultaneous occurrence of many independent, rare conditions: location in a galactic habitable zone, orbit around a suitably calm star within a circumstellar habitable zone, a terrestrial mass that can sustain plate tectonics and a magnetosphere, the protective presence of gas-giant “guardians,” a large stabilizing moon, Earth-like surface chemistry, and a sequence of evolutionary “pumps” (e.g., global glaciations and major impacts) that ultimately yield eukaryotes and events like the Cambrian explosion [1].

Multiplying such low-probability factors suggests that the expected number of civilizations in our galaxy could be well below one, meaning our existence may be an extremely rare statistical outlier; however, the precise likelihood remains uncertain because most of these probabilities are still observationally unconstrained [1].

question_en: How do birds know which way is South when migrating for winter?
pos_context_title_en: How Do Birds Know Which Way is South? (www.wonderopolis.org)
How Do Birds Navigate? (www.nationalgeographic.org)
How do migratory birds find their way ? - News - EducaPoles (www.educapoles.org)
pos_context_en:
One thing birds definitely rely upon is the Sun. The Sun rises in the east and sets in the west. Birds flying south for the winter can stay on track by using the Sun's position in the sky throughout the day as a guide.


Of course, once the Sun sets, it isn't much help as a guide. Luckily, many birds can also navigate by the position of the stars in the sky once night rolls around. Constellations guided many sailors at night before modern technology came along. Birds can use the stars as navigational aids in the same way.


Birds also have the benefit of a bird's eye view. Human hikers lost in the woods sometimes must climb to the top of the nearest mountain to be able to see natural or man-made landscape features, like roads or coastlines, to find their way home. Birds just take to the sky where they get an awesome view of everything below them. Sometimes traveling south is as simple as following the path of a river that travels south to warmer temperatures.


Finally, some scientists believe some birds may also get some of their guidance from Earth's magnetic field. Some species of birds have a highly-magnetic mineral called magnetite in their brains. Experts believe this mineral may help birds detect Earth's magnetic field and use it to guide them south.

The flight paths used by birds in their annual migrations are called flyway s.


Scientists are not entirely sure how birds navigate their flyways. They seem to have an internal global positioning system (GPS) that allows them to follow the same pattern every year. A young bird imprint s on the sun and stars to help orient it. Some researchers think a bird may also recognize landmark s.


Individual organ s also contribute to a bird’s remarkable navigational ability. A bird’s eyes interact with its brain in a region called “cluster N”, which probably helps the bird determine which way is north. Tiny amounts of iron in the neurons of a bird’s inner ear also help in this determination.

nother tool is the earth's magnetic field (earth's north and south magnetic poles). Some birds, like pigeons, have a small zone in their brain made of magnetite (magnetic mineral), just like a small compass. But other scientists think it's rather in their eyes that some birds have a system which indicates them where the magnetic north is...


Of course, birds also use their knowledge of the landscape: they follow rivers, valleys or roads, or locate themselves with particular mountain peaks.


Other tracks are still to be explored. For example it seems that some birds could find their way by following their sense of smell...
report_en: During daylight birds use the Sun, keeping a constant angle between its east-to-west path and their own flight direction to maintain a southerly course [1]. When darkness falls, many species switch to the night sky, steering by memorized constellations much as ancient sailors once did [1]. A specialized brain region called cluster N interacts with the eyes, and tiny amounts of iron in the inner ear provide directional signals, giving birds an internal “GPS” that indicates north and therefore south [2]. In addition, magnetite crystals embedded in some birds’ brains act like miniature compasses that align with Earth’s magnetic field to refine their heading [1]. Finally, with a bird’s-eye view they can trace obvious landscape cues—long rivers, coastlines or valleys—that lead toward warmer latitudes, further reinforcing the route during migration [1].
all_claims: During daylight birds use the Sun, keeping a constant angle between its east-to-west path and their own flight direction to maintain a southerly course [1].
When darkness falls, many species switch to the night sky, steering by memorized constellations much as ancient sailors once did [1].

A specialized brain region called cluster N interacts with the eyes, and tiny amounts of iron in the inner ear provide directional signals, giving birds an internal “GPS” that indicates north and therefore south [2].
In addition, magnetite crystals embedded in some birds’ brains act like miniature compasses that align with Earth’s magnetic field to refine their heading [1].
Finally, with a bird’s-eye view they can trace obvious landscape cues—long rivers, coastlines or valleys—that lead toward warmer latitudes, further reinforcing the route during migration [1].

A specialized brain region called cluster N interacts with the eyes, and tiny amounts of iron in the inner ear provide directional signals, giving birds an internal “GPS” that indicates north and therefore south [2].
In addition, magnetite crystals embedded in some birds’ brains act like miniature compasses that align with Earth’s magnetic field to refine their heading [1].
Finally, with a bird’s-eye view they can trace obvious landscape cues—long rivers, coastlines or valleys—that lead toward warmer latitudes, further reinforcing the route during migration [1].
