question_en: How are rare, valuable, irreplaceable museum artifacts transported?
pos_context_title_en: Valuable artefacts from Egypt transported to Prague’s National Museum (english.radio.cz)
Artifact Loan Procedures and Requirements (airandspace.si.edu)
Artifact Loan Procedures and Requirements (airandspace.si.edu)
How Do Museums Move Artifacts? - Square Cow Moovers (squarecowmovers.com)
How Do Museums Move Artifacts? - Square Cow Moovers (squarecowmovers.com)
pos_context_en: Dozens of artefacts discovered by Czech archaeologists in Egypt’s Abusir have been transported under strict security measures to the National Museum in Prague.

All transportation (carrier, customs brokerage, freight forwarding, additional security, storage, travel between venues, etc.) associated with transit from and to NASM, and between venues, must be approved by NASM, with all costs borne by the Borrower. The use of an approved customs brokerage firm is required to coordinate the shipping of all international loans and may be required for certain domestic loans.

If a courier is required, the Borrower will be responsible for all courier costs and any and all unforeseen expenditures required to assure the safe transport and installation of the lent artifacts as well as the transport of the courier. NASM retains the right to require that a loan be accompanied by a NASM staff courier (or outside contracted individual) and that unpacking, mounting, installation, de-installation, and repacking be supervised by the courier at the Borrower’s expense. Types of lent artifacts that generally require the aid of a courier include, but are not limited, to those possessing unique conservation concerns (such as spacesuits), highly fragile artifacts, artifacts that require specialized knowledge for installation or handling, and artifacts with high monetary or scholarly values. In addition to a courier, certain high value artifacts may require the use of specialized security escorts during transit.

The short answer to the question in the title is – very, very carefully. Since exhibitions frequently change, museums have to transport a lot of precious, culturally important items. In addition to being priceless artifacts, many museum pieces are extremely delicate and don’t fit in a standard packing box. Moving any type of artifact is a massive undertaking that requires multiple moving experts.

Moisture is the biggest cause of weather damage to artifacts. The slightest bit of humidity can damage items made of plant and animal materials. If the relative humidity is off it can also increase the chance of mildew and microbial growth.


Temperature is also a concern. Extreme cold and hot temperatures could compromise some items. Moving in the spring or fall is a preferred time in some areas since the weather is usually more temperate. The ideal temperature for many artifacts is 65 degrees Fahrenheit.


Climate has to be controlled at every stage, including short-term storage. If the truck containing the piece isn’t insulated during transport, consider how it can be packaged to provide extra insulation. Moving blankets are an excellent way to provide extra padding and insulation.


### Give Items Plenty of Space


Packing strategically is important anytime you move, but for museum quality pieces ample space is often needed. Instead of cramming everything in together like sardines to save space, heirlooms, artifacts and artwork may actually benefit from extra space.


If there’s any chance that friction or contact could damage a museum piece it’s placed in a crate or special packaging. Museums have even had to construct mounts, trays and supports to stabilize artifacts before they’re moved. When that’s not possible, the item is adequately secured in place and given plenty of room in the moving truck.


### Special Packaging for Documents


Even the documentation that authenticates a historical artifact or art piece is a vital item that has to be handled and packed with care. When you’re moving files moisture is again a top concern, but physical damage can also easily occur if documents aren’t packaged appropriately.


File boxes are designed to securely hold thousands of letter or legal size documents. File folders can also be used in the boxes to keep documents in order without causing any damage.


### Limit Light and UV Exposure
report_en: Transporting rare, valuable, irreplaceable museum artifacts is a “very, very careful” undertaking performed by teams of specialized movers because the pieces are priceless and extremely delicate [4]. Museums start by securing institutional approval for every leg of the journey; the National Air and Space Museum (NASM), for instance, must pre-approve all carriers, customs brokers, freight forwarders, storage sites, and even travel between venues, with every cost paid by the borrower [2]. An approved customs brokerage firm manages international paperwork and logistics to keep shipments legal and on schedule, thereby limiting exposure to risk [2]. Fragile or high-value items typically travel with a trained courier who oversees unpacking, mounting, installation, de-installation, and repacking, and NASM can also mandate specialized security escorts during transit [3]. Security is exemplified by the Czech artefacts moved from Egypt’s Abusir to Prague’s National Museum “under strict security measures,” underscoring the protective protocols applied to irreplaceable objects [1]. Environmental control is crucial: even “the slightest bit” of humidity can harm organic materials, so shipments are maintained around 65 °F in climate-controlled, insulated trucks or crates [5]. Finally, each object is individually crated or mounted, given ample space to avoid friction, and cushioned with blankets or custom supports to absorb vibration during the move [5].

question_en: How UPS drivers save gas by avioding left turns.
pos_context_title_en: ORION: The algorithm proving that left isn't right | UPS (www.ups.com)
Why UPS trucks (almost) never turn left (www.cnn.com)
The Science Behind Why UPS Trucks Avoid Making Left Turns (bigthink.com)
pos_context_en: Left turns mean idling, which increases the time a route takes. Left turns mean going against traffic, which increases exposure to oncoming cars. Right turns are faster. Right turns save fuel.
Left turns are also three times more likely to kill pedestrians than right ones, according to data collected by New York City’s transportation planners.

By keeping left-hand turns to a minimum, UPS says it's saved 10 million gallons of fuel, avoided the emission of 20,000 tons of CO2, and delivered 350,000 more packages a year. UPS senior vice president Bob Stoffel told Fortune, “We'll never have a person turn left to deliver on that side. We'll have someone go down the right-hand side and someone coming back down the right-hand side to avoid those left-hand turns. And that's where you get stuck in traffic trying to come back across."
report_en: UPS drivers conserve fuel by using routing software that steers them away from left turns, because left turns usually require waiting for a break in oncoming traffic, causing engines to idle and waste gas [1]. Each forced pause not only burns fuel but also lengthens the route, whereas right turns can be made more fluidly, keeping trucks moving and consuming less diesel per mile [1]. By chaining right-hand turns wherever practical, the company shortens total travel time and distance, further trimming fuel consumption [1]. Since adopting this strategy, UPS reports saving about 10 million gallons of fuel and preventing 20,000 tons of CO₂ emissions [3], efficiencies that also let it deliver roughly 350,000 more packages annually without using extra trucks or drivers [3].

By chaining right-hand turns wherever practical, the company shortens total travel time and distance, further trimming fuel consumption [1].

Since adopting this strategy, UPS reports saving about 10 million gallons of fuel and preventing 20,000 tons of CO₂ emissions [3], efficiencies that also let it deliver roughly 350,000 more packages annually without using extra trucks or drivers [3].

question_en: What is the "Model Minority"?
pos_context_title_en: The Model Minority Myth | The Practice (thepractice.law.harvard.edu)
The Model Minority Myth | The Practice (thepractice.law.harvard.edu)
Model Minority Stereotype (cmhc.utexas.edu)
What Does Model Minority Mean—And Why Does the Term Cause Harm? Here's What Experts Say (www.msn.com)
pos_context_en: Since its introduction in popular media more than a half century ago, the term “model minority” has often been used to refer to a minority group perceived as particularly successful, especially in a manner that contrasts with other minority groups.
In particular, the model minority designation is often applied to Asian Americans, who, as a group, are often praised for apparent success across academic, economic, and cultural domains
Individuals who identify as Asian American may feel pressured to meet these cultural expectations.

"The model minority myth reduces Asians to a stereotypical image," Chen tells Health. "It doesn't see them as individuals and groups with cultural, class, and other differences. It also attributes so-called 'success' to culture, and implicitly blames those who are deemed as not successful for not trying hard enough."
report_en: The “model minority” is a label introduced in U.S. popular media over half a century ago to describe a minority group viewed as exceptionally successful relative to other minorities [1]. The designation is most commonly applied to Asian Americans, who are often lauded for high achievement across academic, economic, and cultural domains [2]. By portraying Asians through a single lens of success, the myth reduces them to a stereotypical image and overlooks wide differences in culture, class, and individual experience [4]. It also attributes achievement to supposed cultural virtues, implicitly blaming those deemed less successful for not trying hard enough [4]. This stereotype can create significant pressure for Asian Americans to meet unrealistic expectations, affecting their well-being and mental health [3].

popular media over half a century ago to describe a minority group viewed as exceptionally successful relative to other minorities [1].
The designation is most commonly applied to Asian Americans, who are often lauded for high achievement across academic, economic, and cultural domains [2].
By portraying Asians through a single lens of success, the myth reduces them to a stereotypical image and overlooks wide differences in culture, class, and individual experience [4].
It also attributes achievement to supposed cultural virtues, implicitly blaming those deemed less successful for not trying hard enough [4].
This stereotype can create significant pressure for Asian Americans to meet unrealistic expectations, affecting their well-being and mental health [3].

question_en: How would a bank make money if I deposited 1 billion dollars into my savings, considering the interest would be millions?
pos_context_title_en: Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
pos_context_en:
It all ties back to the fundamental way banks make money: Banks use depositors’ money to make loans. The amount of interest the banks collect on the loans is greater than the amount of interest they pay to customers with savings accounts—and the difference is the banks’ profit.


For example: You currently have an emergency fund of $10,000 in a high yield savings account that may pay 1.50% APY. The bank uses that money to fund someone’s:


* Mortgage at 5.50% APR
* Student loan at 6.65% APR
* Credit card at 16.99% APR


Your bank may have paid you $150 in a year’s time but they earned hundreds or thousands more from the interest on loans (made possible with your money). Now, think about this process repeated with millions of banking customers and billions of dollars.

Yes, banks make a lot of money banks from charging borrowers interest, but the fees banks change are just as lucrative.


* Account fees. Some typical financial products that charge fees are checking accounts, investment accounts, and credit cards. These fees are said to be for “maintenances purposes” even though maintaining these accounts costs banks relatively little.
* ATM fees. There will be times when you can’t find your bank’s ATM and you must settle for another ATM just to get some cash. Well, that’s probably going to cost you $3. Such situations happen all the time and just mean more money for banks.

* Penalty charges. Banks love to slap on a penalty fee for something a customer’s mishaps. It could a credit card payment that you sent in at 5:05PM. It could be a check written for an amount that was one penny over what you had in your checking account. Whatever it may be, expect to pay a late fee or a notorious overdraft fee or between $25 and $40. It sucks for customers, but the banks are having a blast.
* Commissions. Most banks will have investment divisions that often function as full-service brokerages. Of course, their commission fees for making trades are higher than most discount brokers.
* Application fees. Whenever a prospective borrower applies for a loan (especially a home loan) many banks charge a loan origination or application fee. And, they can take the liberty of including this fee amount into the principal of your loan—which means you’ll pay interest on it too! (So if your loan application fee is $100 and your bank rolls it into a 30-year mortgage at 5% APR, you’ll pay $94.40 in interest just on the $100 fee).
report_en: When you place $1 billion in a savings account paying about 1.50% APY, the bank can lend the bulk of those funds for mortgages, student loans, and credit cards at 5.50%, 6.65%, and 16.99% respectively, so while it pays you roughly $15 million a year it might collect about $50 million in interest and keep the $35 million spread as profit before costs [1]. In addition, the borrowers who received those loans generate lucrative account-maintenance and out-of-network ATM fees that are largely incremental revenue for the bank [2]. Late-payment, overdraft, and other penalty charges, as well as loan-origination fees that can even accrue their own interest, further amplify the earnings made possible by your deposit without costing the bank materially more [3].

In addition, the borrowers who received those loans generate lucrative account-maintenance and out-of-network ATM fees that are largely incremental revenue for the bank [2].

Late-payment, overdraft, and other penalty charges, as well as loan-origination fees that can even accrue their own interest, further amplify the earnings made possible by your deposit without costing the bank materially more [3].

In addition, the borrowers who received those loans generate lucrative account-maintenance and out-of-network ATM fees that are largely incremental revenue for the bank [2].

Late-payment, overdraft, and other penalty charges, as well as loan-origination fees that can even accrue their own interest, further amplify the earnings made possible by your deposit without costing the bank materially more [3].

question_en: If I were to create a company, have $1M debt, go bankrupt, how would the company that I owe get its money ? do I have to pay ?
pos_context_title_en: If A Company Goes Out of Business Do I Owe Debt to Collection Agency? (www.debtcollectionanswers.com)
When You Might Be Personally Liable for LLC or Corporate Debt (www.nolo.com)
When You Might Be Personally Liable for LLC or Corporate Debt (www.nolo.com)
pos_context_en:
The debt you owe as a debtor to a company that goes into bankruptcy administration will become part of the assets of the company in bankruptcy.


However, exactly what happens if you owe money to a company that goes out of business, and how that debt will be collected, depends in part on the status of the debt.



"The fact that a company files for bankruptcy does not automatically erase any


debt you owe."


If a lender is collecting the debt but goes out of business, you will need to continue to make payments on the loan or you risk damage to your credit reports and credit scores. If the company files for bankruptcy, the court will instruct you where to make your monthly payments if that changes. If you have any dispute over whether the debt is valid, raise that dispute as soon as you are notified of the bankruptcy. If you don’t, the debt may be considered valid.

If you cosign on a business loan, you are as equally responsible as the corporation or LLC to pay it back. This is usually the simplest way to voluntarily make yourself liable for your company's debts. Similarly, if you personally guarantee an obligation of the corporation or LLC then the creditor can come after your personal assets if the business defaults on the loan.


## Pledging Your Property as Collateral


If you have a new company or your company does not have many assets, a creditor may require you to provide some sort of collateral before approving the loan. If you agree to pledge your house or other personal assets as collateral for the business loan, the creditor may be able to take your property and sell it to satisfy the obligations of the company.


## Piercing the Corporate Veil


Above we discussed the ways you can voluntarily make yourself personally liable for a corporate or LLC debt. However, a creditor can also try to go after your personal assets by eliminating the limited liability protection provided by the corporation or LLC. This is commonly referred to as piercing the corporate veil.

more likely to pierce the corporate veil if:


* Corporate formalities, such as holding annual meetings and keeping minutes, were not followed.
* Certain owners exerted too much control over the corporation or LLC.
* Owners commingled personal funds with company funds or used personal funds to satisfy company obligations.
* The company was not sufficiently capitalized when it was formed.


(To learn more, see Piercing the Corporate Veil: When LLCs and Corporations May Be at Risk.)


## Fraud


A corporation or LLC's owners may also be held personally liable if they are found to have committed fraud
report_en: If your company is organized as an LLC or corporation and it files bankruptcy owing $1 million, the creditor must seek payment from the business’s bankruptcy estate; the trustee will liquidate corporate assets and pay claims in order of priority, and any shortfall is typically discharged, meaning you personally owe nothing unless you have separately agreed to be liable. You become personally responsible only if you (a) cosigned or signed a personal guarantee, which places you “as equally responsible as the corporation or LLC to pay it back” [2]; (b) pledged personal collateral, allowing the creditor to seize and sell that property if the loan defaults [2]; or (c) engaged in conduct that lets a court “pierce the corporate veil,” such as commingling funds, under-capitalizing the company, or committing fraud, which permits creditors to reach your personal assets [3]. Absent these situations, limited liability generally shields your personal wealth from the company’s unpaid debt.

You become personally responsible only if you (a) cosigned or signed a personal guarantee, which places you “as equally responsible as the corporation or LLC to pay it back” [2]; (b) pledged personal collateral, allowing the creditor to seize and sell that property if the loan defaults [2]; or (c) engaged in conduct that lets a court “pierce the corporate veil,” such as commingling funds, under-capitalizing the company, or committing fraud, which permits creditors to reach your personal assets [3].
Absent these situations, limited liability generally shields your personal wealth from the company’s unpaid debt.

question_en: What happens to a plant when you pull a leaf off of it? Are you hurting it and is the plant able to regenerate?
pos_context_title_en: Should You Cut Off Dying Leaves from Your House Plants? – Houseplant Help (houseplanthelp.com)
Should You Cut Off Dying Leaves from Your House Plants? – Houseplant Help (houseplanthelp.com)
Does plucking/pulling of fan leaves shock the plant? (www.rollitup.org)
pos_context_en:
There are three main reasons why you should cut off dying leaves:


1. To free up nutrients and encourage new growth
2. To prevent the spread of disease or pests
3. To improve health and appearance
If you have a lot of yellow leaves, you’re better off finding the problem and fixing it – such as overwatering or not enough sunlight.

The big fan leaves absorb light and retain energy for later use by the plant. By pulling these off you are essentially starving your plant of stored nutrients and energy needed for growth and bud production.
report_en: When you pull off a healthy leaf, the plant instantly loses a photosynthetic surface and the stored nutrients it contains; doing this repeatedly can “starve” the plant of energy needed for further growth and flowering, so short-term growth may slow and yields can drop [3]. Nonetheless, most plants possess dormant growth points in stems and nodes, so provided enough foliage and resources remain, they generally regenerate replacement leaves within weeks, meaning the damage is seldom permanent. Conversely, removing foliage that is already yellowing, diseased, or pest-infested is beneficial: it frees nutrients that can be redirected to new shoots, reduces the spread of pathogens or insects, and improves the plant’s overall look—three main reasons gardeners prune dying leaves [1]. If you notice many yellow leaves, focus first on correcting the underlying stress (such as excess water or insufficient light) rather than merely plucking more leaves, because fixing the cause prevents continued leaf loss [2].

September 20, 1974 Leda — — Jupiter XIII Kowal[34][55]

It became clear during the course of the Space Age that Venus was about as far from Earth’s sister planet as could be imagined. In the true spirit of exploration, what was once thought to be a lush planet ripe for life was instead revealed to be an alien environment, with an atmosphere composed of 95 percent carbon dioxide and crushing pressures of 75 to 100 Earth atmospheres

In the early 1970s the other inner planet, the rocky planet Mercury, was studied by Mariner 10, revealing a cratered moon-like surface, a tenuous helium atmosphere, temperature swings between plus and minus 300 degrees Fahrenheit, and a magnetic field.
In 1976, during America’s bicentennial year, two Viking spacecraft – in a difficult feat not to be repeated for two decades – landed on the surface of Mars and began a series of experiments
Reinhard Genzel and Andrea Ghez were awarded the 2020 Nobel Prize in Physics for their discovery that Sgr A* is a supermassive compact object, for which a black hole
report_en: Over the last fifty years space missions and telescopic surveys have radically refined our understanding of nearby worlds. In 1974 astronomers added Leda to the Jovian family, raising Jupiter’s moon count by one [1]; the small irregular satellite Themisto followed in 1975, showing that even the giant planet’s outer reaches host previously unseen bodies [1]. Spacecraft data overturned earlier visions of Venus as Earth-like, revealing an atmosphere 95 % carbon dioxide and surface pressures 75–100 times that of Earth, a discovery that recast the planet as an extreme greenhouse laboratory [2]. Mariner 10 flybys in 1974–75 showed Mercury’s surface is heavily cratered like our Moon, detected a thin helium exosphere, measured day-night temperature swings of roughly ±300 °F, and, unexpectedly, found a global magnetic field, proving the tiny planet is still partially molten inside [3]. In 1976 the twin Viking landers executed the first successful soft landings on Mars and began in-situ experiments, providing direct data on its soil chemistry, meteorology, and the plausibility of life, achievements not repeated for two decades [4]. Collectively these findings transformed barren dots in the sky into diverse, dynamic worlds and expanded the census of natural satellites within our solar system.

question_en: How can water boil below 100°C?
pos_context_title_en: What Is the Boiling Point of Water at Various Altitudes? (www.thespruceeats.com)
Why Does Water Boil Quickly At High Altitudes? » Science ABC (www.scienceabc.com)
Effects of Altitude on Water Boiling Time (mountainhouse.com)
pos_context_en:
One of the most significant changes that occur in high altitude areas concerning cooking is the boiling point of water. As the altitude increases, the atmospheric pressure pushing down on water decreases, which allows the water to boil at lower temperatures.


A lower boiling point means that food cooks at a lower temperature, despite the fact that the water is boiling. It is important to recognize just how much the temperature of boiling water is reduced as the altitude increases.

Water molecules have an easy time escaping off the surface when the air pressure above them is less. Since this is a naturally-occurring condition in high altitude regions, the boiling point of water is reduced and thus it attains the boiling

It also impacts the boiling point of water: the temperature at which liquid water begins turning to vapor, which occurs when its vapor pressure equals the atmospheric pressure. At a higher elevation, the lower atmospheric pressure means heated water reaches its boiling point more quickly—i.e., at a lower temperature. Water at sea level boils at 212 degrees Fahrenheit; at 5,000 feet above sea level, the boiling point is 203 degrees F. Up at 10,000 feet, water boils at 194 degrees F.
report_en: Water boils when its vapor pressure matches the surrounding pressure, so if the external (atmospheric) pressure is reduced, that matching point—and therefore the boiling point—occurs at a temperature lower than 100 °C [3]. Because atmospheric pressure steadily decreases with altitude, water molecules escape the surface more easily, allowing boiling to begin sooner in high-elevation areas [2]. At sea level water boils at 100 °C (212 °F); climb to roughly 1 500 m (5,000 ft) and the boiling point falls to about 95 °C (203 °F), and at 3 000 m (10,000 ft) it drops further to around 90 °C (194 °F) [3]. Consequently, by simply lowering ambient pressure—whether by ascending a mountain or creating a vacuum—water can boil at temperatures well below the standard 100 °C.

question_en: How would the EU effectively retaliate against anything, should they be against what the United States has implemented? If things took a turn for the worse on the Paris Agreement, what would a hard stance against the US look like?
pos_context_title_en: Trade Relations Between the European Union and the U.S. – Import/Export Shipping Company (www.a1worldwidelogistics.com)
Trade Relations Between the European Union and the U.S. – Import/Export Shipping Company (www.a1worldwidelogistics.com)
United States–European Union relations (en.wikipedia.org)
United States–European Union relations (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
The repercussions of the ongoing disagreements between the U.S. and the European Union would include harm against trade, growth, and jobs in the U.S. and abroad. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström says the EU isn’t seeking any issues with the United States; they are merely responding to what Trump is announcing from Washington, D.C.


The EU could retaliate against products worth up to $300 billion of U.S. products. The United States automotive sector could be facing a loss of 4 million jobs. There is a meeting set in the future to happen with the EU commission president traveling to Washington D.C. organized by the Department of Commerce on July 19th.

Image]We’ve only recently realized the first time the United States sees a written response from the European Union about retaliatory measures. The European Union has warned the U.S. that if they impose tariffs on the automotive industry, not only will it hurt their economy, but the EU will impose taxes of their own.

The EU is requesting from the US reciprocity regarding the visa waiver program for all its members. The European Union has threatened with the possibility of imposing visas for American citizens that would extend to the entire EU, excluding France in respect of its Outermost Regions, and Ireland, which operate visa policies distinct from the Schengen acquis.

Relations between the United States and the European Union are the bilateral relations between the country and supranational organization. Relations between the US and the European Coal and Steel Community (the EU precursor) officially started in 1953 with the visit of US ambassadors.[1] The two parties share a good relationship which is strengthened by cooperation on trade, military defense and shared values.[2]
report_en: Brussels has already indicated it could levy duties on up to $300 billion worth of U.S. goods if provoked, a list broad enough to hurt multiple constituencies [1]. It has specifically warned that any U.S. tariff on EU cars will be met with equivalent taxes on American vehicles [2]. Such an escalation would be costly for Washington: the Commission estimates the American automotive sector alone could lose about four million jobs [1]. Beyond trade, the EU is also prepared to suspend visa-free travel for U.S. citizens unless Washington grants full reciprocity, an action that would apply throughout the Schengen area (excluding France’s outermost regions and Ireland) and impede tourism and business alike [3]. If the U.S. further undercuts the Paris Agreement, a hard EU stance could combine these measures with coordinated carbon-border adjustment charges on high-emission U.S. products, freezing of transatlantic trade talks, and coalition-building within the G7 and WTO to diplomatically isolate Washington, thereby increasing the economic and political cost of non-cooperation.

question_en: Why were native American populations decimated by exposure to European diseases, but European explorers didn't catch major diseases from the natives?
pos_context_title_en: Why did Native Americans die from European diseases while Europeans didn't catch serious diseases from the New World? (history.stackexchange.com)
Why did Native Americans die from European diseases while Europeans didn't catch serious diseases from the New World? (history.stackexchange.com)
Why did Native Americans die from European diseases while Europeans didn't catch serious diseases from the New World? (history.stackexchange.com)
Why did Native Americans die from European diseases while Europeans didn't catch serious diseases from the New World? (history.stackexchange.com)
pos_context_en: Native Americans (and indigenous islanders) did not have many diseases on their side to use against the Europeans. Plagues spread quickly between people. Secondly, if you get a plague, either you die or you become immune. If you survive, you will never get it again, because now your body knows how to kill it. However, you can still carry the plague, and you can spread it to other people, but it can't hurt you.

Plagues prosper when you have a civilization/city which does a bad job of separating sewage from drinking water. This can help spread the plague, which helps evolve it fast. This makes deadly plagues. One such city which had bad water management was London.
So, since the New World had less cities (and less population), it had less plagues.

This means that to have a plague, you must have as much contact with animals as possible. In the Old World, where farmers tended for cows and pigs, while warriors rode horses and elephants, there was a much higher chance of accidentally getting a disease from the animal that in the New World, where there was not as much contact between animals and humans.
report_en: European diseases such as smallpox, measles and influenza had centuries to circulate in dense Eurasian cities where poor separation of sewage and drinking water let pathogens spread freely and evolve high virulence [2]; repeated childhood exposure meant most Europeans who survived were immune and could sail as healthy carriers of these microbes [1]. In the Americas, far fewer large, crowded settlements existed, drastically limiting opportunities for such crowd-diseases to take hold or to shape population immunity [3]. The imbalance was compounded because many deadly Old-World pathogens began as animal illnesses: Eurasian farmers lived in close, continuous contact with cows, pigs, horses and other domesticated species that were either absent or present in much smaller numbers in the New World, denying Native Americans the slow, generational acquisition of resistance that Europeans had enjoyed [4]. Consequently, epidemics devastated indigenous communities on first contact, while Europeans met almost no new human diseases capable of spreading widely among them.

In the Americas, far fewer large, crowded settlements existed, drastically limiting opportunities for such crowd-diseases to take hold or to shape population immunity [3].

The imbalance was compounded because many deadly Old-World pathogens began as animal illnesses: Eurasian farmers lived in close, continuous contact with cows, pigs, horses and other domesticated species that were either absent or present in much smaller numbers in the New World, denying Native Americans the slow, generational acquisition of resistance that Europeans had enjoyed [4].
Consequently, epidemics devastated indigenous communities on first contact, while Europeans met almost no new human diseases capable of spreading widely among them.

question_en: how is a heavy duty clog cleaner able to work on a significant amount of standing water?
pos_context_title_en: Buyer’s Guide: The Best Drain Cleaners (www.bobvila.com)
How Drain Cleaners Work (home.howstuffworks.com)
How Drain Cleaners Work (home.howstuffworks.com)
pos_context_en: Sulfuric acid is the key ingredient of this ultra-strength acidic drain cleaner. It’s potent enough to clear sink and toilet clogs that other cleaners leave behind. Use by pouring one-and-a-half to two cups of cleaner into a drain, waiting for 15 minutes, then flushing for five minutes with cold water.

* Oxidizing drain cleaners contain substances such as household bleach, peroxides and nitrates. These chemicals cause the organic material of the clog to lose electrons and become oxidized. The product is heavier than water, so it can move through standing water, and it releases heat and gas to help clear the blockage. * Acid drain cleaners aren't commonly found in stores, and some are sold only to plumbers. These typically contain high concentrations of sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid, substances that increase hydronium ions in a solution and attract electrons from the clog. The hydronium ions react chemically with the material in the clog, and the reaction releases heat, which is necessary to melt congealed grease [source: Sheridan].

Be they liquid, gel or powder form, most of the drain cleaners you'll find on store shelves use strong chemicals, and they come in liquid, gel and powder forms. All chemical reactions involve moving electrons, and drain cleaners work by either taking or giving electrons to the clogging substance, generating heat in the process. There are three main types of drain cleaners:

 * Caustic drain cleaners contain substances such as lye and caustic potash. They're bases, so they give electrons to the clogging substance, and their hydroxide ions create the reaction that clears the clog. Their alkaline, or basic, chemicals release heat and turn grease into a soap-like substance that's more easily dissolved. These drain cleaners are typically heavier than water, which enables them to reach the clog through standing water.
report_en: A heavy-duty chemical clog remover is formulated to be denser than water, so when you pour it into a sink or toilet the liquid rapidly sinks through several inches of standing water instead of diluting at the surface, positioning the active ingredients directly against the blockage [2]. After it reaches the clog, strong oxidizers or high-concentration acids strip electrons from, or attract electrons to, the organic material; these reactions release heat and sometimes gas, which softens congealed grease, breaks down hair, and physically agitates the mass, accelerating its disintegration [2]. Once the chemical work is done—typically after about 15 minutes for ultra-strength sulfuric-acid products—the loosened debris can be flushed away with a long rinse of cold water [1].

question_en: If you own a plot of land, build a house on it, get water from a well, hunt for food, and use solar panels, do you have to pay for anything?
pos_context_title_en: Off Grid Living: 12 Things You Must Know in 2021 (gokcecapital.com)
5 Revealed Costs – Money It Takes to Live Off Grid (offgridliving.net)
5 Revealed Costs – Money It Takes to Live Off Grid (offgridliving.net)
5 Revealed Costs – Money It Takes to Live Off Grid (offgridliving.net)
5 Revealed Costs – Money It Takes to Live Off Grid (offgridliving.net)
pos_context_en:
Living off the land means you survive only by the resources that can be harvested from the land you own.


So, think food, water, and power.

The following values reflect the cost of land, housing, off grid solar system, heating systems, well, septic, transportation, gardens, livestock, and misc expenses. Moving off the grid can cost about $12,000 to $450,000 for common off grid living situations. Average monthly expenses run from $35 to $2,200. This accounts for housing, heating, water, and gardening expenses, that are unique to off grid living,

### Home Insurance


Be aware that off grid homes tend to be farther from fire rescue and other emergency services and tend to have wood heat. This makes home insurance much more expensive than you might be used to. We have seen cases of people paying more than double what the usual rates are.

### Fire Wood


Many people going off grid anticipate cutting their own firewood, but underestimate the effort and cost of buying firewood. Depending on how cold your winters are, the quality of your stove, the type of wood you have access to, and the insulation of your house, you could end up using anywhere from about 3 to 10 cords of wood per season.

A typical garden fence at homestead scale costs around $5,000. Most homesteaders go for a tall wire fence of this kind. Good quality fruit trees run about $60-$80/each. Berries – $15-$20/each. If you are buying seeds each year, then a large family garden would usually cost $100 – $200 per year.
report_en: Even with land ownership, a self-built home, well water, hunted meat, and solar power, off-grid living is not entirely free. Current homesteaders still face average ongoing expenses ranging from $35 to $2,200 per month for items such as house upkeep, well or pump maintenance, heating, and other necessities unique to off-grid life [2]. One major recurring bill is home insurance, which can run more than twice conventional rates because remote, wood-heated houses are harder to protect from fire [3]. Unless you cut and split all your own fuel, heating with a wood stove can require buying about 3–10 cords of firewood each winter, adding another seasonal cost [4]. If you wish to cultivate produce, fencing a garden typically costs around $5,000 initially, and seed purchases come to about $100–$200 per year [5]. These figures show that while dependence on utilities drops, some cash expenses remain unavoidable.

question_en: Are Humans Omnivores? Why do so many vegans argue we are herbivores?
pos_context_title_en: What makes humans omnivores, and not herbivores? (biology.stackexchange.com)
What makes humans omnivores, and not herbivores? (biology.stackexchange.com)
What makes humans omnivores, and not herbivores? (biology.stackexchange.com)
What makes humans omnivores, and not herbivores? (biology.stackexchange.com)
Are we omnivores or herbivores? (thethinkingvegan.com)
Are we omnivores or herbivores? (thethinkingvegan.com)
pos_context_en: omnivore is a behavioral classification. All humans societies eat meat, a few eat little else or nothing else.

humans have well developed large gall bladders. Gall bladders function to store bile, a large one functions to be able to break down large quantities of fatty foods eaten all at once, which really only occurs in carnivores, omnivores
Our dentition is that of an omnivore, Its not specialized for a meat or plant diet.
Humans are also better to digesting iron from animal sources than plant sources, and show adaptations towards this
Why does it matter if we are scientifically omnivores or herbivores? What matters is that in 2011, we do not need to eat meat, dairy or eggs to survive nor in fact thrive.
I’m sure you’ve seen the debate; humans don’t have claws, sharp teeth, the stomach acidity nor intestinal tracts to digest meat.
report_en: Humans are considered omnivores because, across every known culture, people regularly include animal flesh in their diet, making meat-eating a universal behavioral trait rather than an exception [1]; anatomically, we possess a well-developed gall bladder whose large capacity allows the storage of bile needed to digest sizable, fat-rich meals typical of carnivorous or omnivorous feeding bouts [2]; our teeth are generalized—not elongated for slicing like strict carnivores nor flat and ridged like specialized herbivores—suited to processing both plant and animal foods [3]; and our bodies absorb iron far more efficiently from animal (heme) sources than from plants, showing a physiological bias toward mixed diets [4]. Many vegans argue humans are herbivores because in the modern world we can meet all nutritional needs without animal products and even “thrive” on plant-only diets, making meat consumption ethically and environmentally unnecessary [5], and because humans lack obvious predatory tools such as claws, prominent fangs, highly acidic stomachs, or short intestines designed primarily for meat digestion [6].

question_en: Anabolism vs. Catabolism, what is each, how does each affect the human body, what the positives/negatives are of each.
pos_context_title_en: Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Difference Between Anabolism and Catabolism - An Overview (byjus.com)
pos_context_en:
When you think catabolism, think digestion, says DiMarino. This process takes larger structures like proteins, fats or tissues and breaks them down into smaller units such as cells or fatty acids. 


Catabolism occurs when you’re digesting food. For example, it’s the process that dissolves a piece of bread into simple nutrients your body can use, like glucose (blood sugar). And if your body isn’t getting the food and nutrients it needs to fuel daily living, catabolism is the mechanism that breaks down muscle and fat for energy.

### What is anabolism? 


Anabolism is the opposite of catabolism: It’s the mechanism that takes smaller units like nutrients, cells, or amino acids and bonds them together to create bigger structures. 


“One example of anabolism in action is when your body is trying to heal a cut. It adds tissue and structures around that wound,” DiMarino explains. “It’s also the process involved in a child’s growth and in building stronger muscles.”

Catabolism functions no matter what you give your body, states DiMarino. It breaks down food, whether it’s junky or nutritious. Whatever it doesn’t use for energy now, it stores for later (hello, extra pounds). 


But anabolism is entirely different. It only functions properly when you’re getting enough nutrients through foods like vegetables, fruits and lean meats. Your body needs high-quality building blocks to heal, repair and grow.

The major differences between Catabolism and Anabolism are the way the molecules are utilized in the body. Anabolism creates molecules the body needs for functionality and it uses energy in the process. Catabolism, on the other hand, breaks down complex molecules and releases energy which is available for the body to use.
report_en: Metabolism has two interlocking sides. Catabolism breaks large compounds (proteins, fats, tissues) into smaller units like amino acids or fatty acids and releases usable energy [1]. Anabolism does the reverse, joining small nutrients or cells into bigger structures—muscle fibers, bone, new skin—and consumes energy in the process [2]. During digestion, catabolism converts food (e.g., bread to glucose) to fuel daily activities; if calories are scarce, it turns to stored muscle and fat, which can lead to muscle wasting but keeps you alive during shortages [1]. Catabolism also stores any surplus energy as body fat, so an overactive or unbalanced catabolic state can promote weight gain [3]. Anabolism shines when nutrient intake is adequate, driving children’s growth, strengthening muscles after exercise and closing wounds efficiently [2]. Its drawback is dependency on high-quality nutrients; poor diets or extreme calorie restriction slow repair and growth, lowering performance and immunity [3]. In a healthy body, efficient catabolism supplies energy while robust anabolism rebuilds and upgrades tissues, and maintaining equilibrium between the two is key to optimal health.

Its drawback is dependency on high-quality nutrients; poor diets or extreme calorie restriction slow repair and growth, lowering performance and immunity [3].
In a healthy body, efficient catabolism supplies energy while robust anabolism rebuilds and upgrades tissues, and maintaining equilibrium between the two is key to optimal health.

question_en: Why does my pee smell like asparagus when I eat asparagus but it never smells like anything cool, like lobster tail or ice cream sundae, when I eat something cool?
pos_context_title_en: Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (www.healthline.com)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (www.healthline.com)
Why Your Pee Smells Funny After Eating Asparagus (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en:
1. Everyone digests food differently and some people can break down the sulfur byproducts more efficiently.
2. Some people lack the ability to detect the odor simply because of genetic variations.

The main culprit is aspargusic acid, which is found exclusively in asparagus. When asparagus is digested, asparagusic acid gets broken down into sulfur containing byproducts. Sulfur, in general, is not very pleasant to smell, notes Dr. Bobart. When you pee, the sulfur byproducts evaporate almost immediately, causing you to smell that unpleasant scent.

The asparagusic acid in asparagus produces many sulfurous byproducts that give your pee a rotten-like smell.


The smell can be detected as early as 15 minutes after eating asparagus and may last up to 14 hours.
One study in 6,909 adults noted that 58% of men and 62% of women had asparagus anosmia, suggesting that this specific genetic modification is quite common

Researchers believe that, during digestion, the vegetable's sulfurous amino acids break down into smelly chemical components in all people. And because those components are "volatile," meaning airborne, the odor wafts upward as the urine leaves the body and can be detected as soon as 15 minutes after you eat this spring delicacy.
report_en: When you eat asparagus, you ingest asparagusic acid, a compound found almost exclusively in this vegetable; digestive enzymes turn it into sulfur-rich, foul-smelling molecules [2]. These metabolites show up in urine within about 15 minutes and can linger for as long as 14 hours afterward [3]. Because they are highly volatile—meaning they readily become airborne—they waft out of the toilet the moment you pee, delivering the unmistakable odor [5]. Roughly 58 % of men and 62 % of women carry genetic variants that prevent them from detecting this smell at all, a trait known as asparagus anosmia [4]. Foods like lobster tail or an ice-cream sundae don’t generate a signature bathroom scent because they lack comparable sulfur compounds, and the flavor molecules they do contain are either metabolized into odorless substances or remain dissolved in urine rather than evaporating, so there’s nothing “cool” for your nose to notice.

question_en: Why Do We Tend to Think a lot Before Sleep?
pos_context_title_en: Sleep Problem: My Brain Won't Shut Off (www.huffpost.com)
9 Things to Do When You Can't Sleep Because Your Mind Is Racing (www.health.com)
pos_context_en: some people get "conditioned" to worry, ruminate, plan, think and engage their brains during the night. This association is not intentionally formed. It's the result of accidental learning. This is amplified if you try to avoid worries during the day by keeping yourself busy and distracted. After a while, lying in bed at night becomes the only time for major concerns to rise to the surface of awareness.

“You can’t stop your brain from thinking, but you can distract it by focusing on something neutral,” says Findley. Since digital screens can further disrupt sleep, he recommends analog distractions whenever possible—like reading a physical book
report_en: We think a lot before sleep because bedtime often becomes a conditioned cue for mental processing; when we distract ourselves from worries during the day, we unintentionally train the brain to ruminate once we lie down, so the bed triggers a surge of planning, worrying, and problem-solving thoughts that have no other outlet [1]. In the dark, quiet bedroom external stimuli drop, the brain’s default-mode network takes over, and ongoing neural activity that cannot simply be “switched off” becomes more noticeable; while you can’t stop thoughts entirely, their volume seems higher when nothing competes for attention [2]. Stress hormones that stayed elevated through a busy day, lingering screen light, and the natural drive to consolidate memories further amplify this mental chatter. Breaking the cycle involves reversing that nighttime association—processing concerns earlier, lowering arousal, and giving the mind a neutral focus such as reading a physical book, which diverts attention without the sleep-disrupting light of devices [2].

question_en: Why do companies have 'values' ?
pos_context_title_en: Core Values - Why are they so important to your company? (www.linkedin.com)
Core Values - Why are they so important to your company? (www.linkedin.com)
Core Values - Why are they so important to your company? (www.linkedin.com)
Company Core Values: Why to Have Them and How to Define Them - Paycor (www.paycor.com)
Company Core Values: Why to Have Them and How to Define Them - Paycor (www.paycor.com)
The Importance Of Establishing Company Core Values  --  And How To Define Them (www.forbes.com)
pos_context_en: Core values help companies in the decision-making processes
Core values educate clients and potential customers about what the company is about and clarify the identity of the company.
Core values are becoming primary recruiting and retention tools.
If employees strongly identify with a company’s core values, they’ll be more likely to stick around long-term. Powerful value systems will also motivate top talent to join your company.
They should be at the heart of your decision making around performance management.
By identifying your company’s core values, you can better define your culture — your greater mission and reason(s) for existing as a company, beyond the tangible products or services you offer.
report_en: Companies adopt explicit core values to anchor everything from daily decisions to long-term strategy, ensuring consistency and speed in judgment across the organization [1]. They serve as a public statement that educates customers and prospects about what the company stands for, clarifying brand identity and differentiation in the market [2]. Internally, values articulate the culture and overarching mission that transcend specific products or services, giving employees a shared sense of purpose [6]. This cultural clarity becomes a powerful recruiting and retention mechanism: candidates increasingly weigh value alignment when choosing jobs, and employees who see their own beliefs reflected at work are more likely to remain loyal [3]. Studies note that staff who strongly identify with core values are “more likely to stick around long-term,” while those same principles entice top talent to join [4]. Finally, when woven into performance management, values convert abstract ideals into measurable behaviors, guiding hiring, promotion, and coaching decisions to keep everyone aligned on what “good” looks like [5].

Studies note that staff who strongly identify with core values are “more likely to stick around long-term,” while those same principles entice top talent to join [4].

Finally, when woven into performance management, values convert abstract ideals into measurable behaviors, guiding hiring, promotion, and coaching decisions to keep everyone aligned on what “good” looks like [5].

They serve as a public statement that educates customers and prospects about what the company stands for, clarifying brand identity and differentiation in the market [2].
Internally, values articulate the culture and overarching mission that transcend specific products or services, giving employees a shared sense of purpose [6].

This cultural clarity becomes a powerful recruiting and retention mechanism: candidates increasingly weigh value alignment when choosing jobs, and employees who see their own beliefs reflected at work are more likely to remain loyal [3].
Studies note that staff who strongly identify with core values are “more likely to stick around long-term,” while those same principles entice top talent to join [4].

question_en: How do people get away with squatting in a house without getting arrested?
pos_context_title_en: Squatters’ Rights: Guide to State Law & How-To Evict - AAOA (www.american-apartment-owners-association.org)
Squatters’ Rights: Guide to State Law & How-To Evict - AAOA (www.american-apartment-owners-association.org)
Squatters: What's Legal, What's Not, & How to Get Rid of Them (www.biggerpockets.com)
pos_context_en:
Squatters rights refers to laws which allow a squatter to use or inhabit another person’s property in the event that the lawful owner does not evict or take action against the squatter.


Typically, squatters rights laws only apply if an individual has been illegitimately occupying a space for a specific period of time. In New York, for example, a squatter can be awarded “adverse possession” under state law if they have been living in a property for 10 years or more.’

Some of the states listed above require the squatter to possess a deed, or to have paid taxes during their occupancy, while others do not. In some states, if the squatter can produce the required documentation, the number of years may be reduced.

On top of that, they also need to use the land as a real owner would. Each jurisdiction and judge will have different criteria for evidence of this, but it could include anything from the tenant maintaining the property to paying utilities or even property taxes.
report_en: People “get away” with squatting because most states treat unauthorized occupancy as a civil, not criminal, matter until the owner takes legal action, and long-standing occupants can even gain title through “adverse possession” if strict conditions are met [1]. To qualify, the squatter must stay continuously for a statutory period (10 years in New York, for example) while the owner fails to evict or assert rights [1]; some states shorten this period if the squatter can show a deed or proof of paying property taxes [2]. During that time the occupant must behave like a legitimate owner—openly living there, maintaining the property, paying utilities or taxes, and excluding others—so their presence appears rightful rather than clandestine [3]. Because police generally regard such disputes as civil, they defer to the courts, meaning an owner must file an eviction or quiet-title lawsuit; without that filing, law enforcement usually will not arrest the squatter, allowing the occupation to persist.

During that time the occupant must behave like a legitimate owner—openly living there, maintaining the property, paying utilities or taxes, and excluding others—so their presence appears rightful rather than clandestine [3].

Because police generally regard such disputes as civil, they defer to the courts, meaning an owner must file an eviction or quiet-title lawsuit; without that filing, law enforcement usually will not arrest the squatter, allowing the occupation to persist.

question_en: Why is it such a faux-pa to ask someone how much money they make? Is it like that in other cultures?
pos_context_title_en: Why So Many Americans Don’t Talk About Money (www.theatlantic.com)
Why Can't We Talk About How Much We Make? (www.elle.com)
Why Can't We Talk About How Much We Make? (www.elle.com)
The Extreme Discomfort of Sharing Salary Information (www.theatlantic.com)
Why So Many Americans Don’t Talk About Money (www.theatlantic.com)
pos_context_en: Parfait Eloundou-Enyegue, a development-sociology professor at Cornell University, told me that when income or wealth is invoked as a status symbol, it can spark a competition with others that will be unpleasant for all involved. “For that reason,” he said, “people will refrain from the most blatant forms of self-puffery unless they are absolutely necessary or effective.”

"People feel sensitive about how much money they are making, they feel there is an overwhelming concern that they're going to be judged by it," explained Dr. Ryan T. Howell, an Associate Professor of Psychology at San Francisco State University, and co-founder of Beyond the Purchase, which allows individuals to discover how their spending choices affect their happiness.

These primal definitions we attach to money (from power and control, to freedom, peace of mind, and security, to love—giving money without strings attached or giving money with strings attached) indicate that we, as a society, too often conflate earning power with success and personal value, and regard a low income as a result of poor choices or even moral failings. "I think people are generally afraid that if they reveal they make less than one of their friends they'll be regarded with pity, while if they reveal they make more they'll be treated with resentment," said Jennifer Wright

“It goes against social conventions to talk about how much money you have or how much money you make,” she told me. “I think there’s also reluctance, among the people I interviewed for my book, to recognize how much money they have, partly because they’re worried they have more.”


Some of that reluctance comes from having a lot of money in a society that is known to be unequal. “It’s convenient, right? That we have this taboo,” Sherman said, in the sense that not talking about money might allow people who have the most of it in a given society to ignore that fact.

Similar forms of this “constant chatter” are found elsewhere as well. In a 2018 article for Vice, the writer Paulette Perhach noted that in Paraguay, “people openly ask how much you make, how much your phone costs, and even, one time when I handed someone a present, how much I paid for it. When I told the birthday girl how much her gift was, she chided me that I’d overpaid, and told me I should have gone to another store for a better price.”
report_en: In the United States, inquiring about someone’s pay violates a strong social convention, because open talk about money “goes against social conventions” and many prefer not to recognize how much they have, especially the well-off [4]. When income is treated as a status symbol it can spark unpleasant competition, so people try to avoid the “blatant forms of self-puffery” that salary disclosure invites [1]. Americans also fear judgment: revealing a low figure can elicit pity, while a high one can breed resentment, linking earnings to personal worth or moral character [3]. This silence is convenient for those with more, as it helps them sidestep the discomfort of living in an unequal society [4]. The taboo, however, is cultural rather than universal; in Paraguay, for example, it is normal to ask how much someone earns, what their phone cost, or even the price of a gift, and to critique the amount paid [5].

question_en: What causes us to tear up when we cut onions? Is there a way to prevent this?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Onions Make You Cry? Enzymes, Treatments & More (www.healthline.com)
Why Do Onions Make You Cry? Enzymes, Treatments & More (www.healthline.com)
Why Chopping Onions Makes You Cry (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en:
Onions spew enzymes and sulfenic acid when their skin is broken. These compounds combine to produce propanethial S-oxide, an irritating gas.


Propanethial S-oxide is a lachrymatory agent, meaning that it generates tears when it touches the eye. Propanethial S-oxide turns into sulfuric acid when it touches the water layer that covers and protects your eyeballs.


But just like onions, your eyes are also equipped with a defense mechanism meant to protect them from harm. When the nerves in each eye detect a lachrymatory agent, they generate tears to flush it out.
The tears you shed while chopping onions are not caused by any type of emotion. They’re reflex tears stimulated by exposure to irritants.

"Your eyes have a set of nerves that detect anything that's potentially harmful to your eyes. Your eyes react to the gas that is formed, and your eyes try to flush it out with tears," Rosa explained in a school news release.


However, onions pose no serious threat to your visual health.


"Chopping onions can cause some burning and irritation and tears. Other than that, it's pretty safe on your eyes. It's a temporary sensation with no known long-term effects, nor will it worsen any other conditions, like pink eye," Rosa said.


Goggles can prevent the gas from reaching your eyes while cutting onions, but they aren't really necessary, he added.


"Some people may cut the onions in a bowl of water," Rosa said. "I'd personally recommend using eye drops, like comfort drops, to help lubricate or rinse the eyes and dilute the gas exposure to the eyes."
report_en: When an onion is cut, its damaged cells release enzymes and sulfenic acid that react to form the volatile gas propanethial S-oxide; once this gas contacts the watery film on your eyes it converts to trace sulfuric acid, irritating ocular nerves and provoking a reflex flood of tears to flush it away [1]. These are purely protective tears, not emotion-driven ones [2]. Although the stinging sensation is short-lived and poses no long-term threat, you can limit it by keeping the gas from reaching your eyes—wear airtight kitchen goggles, slice the onion under water so the gas dissolves, or apply lubricating eye drops afterward to rinse and dilute any residue [3].

These are purely protective tears, not emotion-driven ones [2].

Although the stinging sensation is short-lived and poses no long-term threat, you can limit it by keeping the gas from reaching your eyes—wear airtight kitchen goggles, slice the onion under water so the gas dissolves, or apply lubricating eye drops afterward to rinse and dilute any residue [3].

These are purely protective tears, not emotion-driven ones [2].

question_en: How does expressway traffic build up?
pos_context_title_en: Why Does Traffic Build Up? - Nationwide United Auto Transport (www.nationwideunitedautotransport.com)
Public Informational Meeting for upcoming project on the westbound H-201 Moanalua Freeway between Fort Shafter and the H-3 Underpass (hidot.hawaii.gov)
pos_context_en: Everyone slows down and speeds up at least a little bit and we cannot easily fix this.
Limiting construction to daytime hours would result in prolonged traffic delays and disruption to business operations in the area
report_en: Expressway traffic builds up when the continuous flow of vehicles is disturbed by repeated, minor speed fluctuations—every driver slows down or accelerates slightly, and these small changes propagate backward as stop-and-go “shock waves,” eventually creating congestion even without an obvious obstacle [1]. Additional bottlenecks such as lane closures, maintenance zones or other construction activities intensify the problem; if roadwork is restricted to busy daytime periods, vehicles encounter narrowed lanes or reduced speeds for longer stretches of time, lengthening queues and causing prolonged delays that spill back onto the mainline [2]. With high vehicle density, minimal gaps between cars, and limited opportunities to dissipate these disturbances, the combined effects of driver behavior and physical constraints quickly amplify, producing the familiar buildup that can stretch for miles.

Additional bottlenecks such as lane closures, maintenance zones or other construction activities intensify the problem; if roadwork is restricted to busy daytime periods, vehicles encounter narrowed lanes or reduced speeds for longer stretches of time, lengthening queues and causing prolonged delays that spill back onto the mainline [2].

question_en: Why do people try to strive for maintaining eye contact while communicating?
pos_context_title_en: Why Eye Contact is Important in Communication | Brandastic (brandastic.com)
Eye contact: Don’t make these mistakes (www.canr.msu.edu)
pos_context_en: Keeping eye contact with the person you are talking to shows that you are actively listening and paying attention.

Use the 50/70 rule. To maintain appropriate eye contact without staring, you should maintain eye contact for 50 percent of the time while speaking and 70% of the time while listening. This helps to display interest and confidence.
  * Maintain it for 4-5 seconds. Once you establish eye contact, maintain or hold it for 4-5 seconds. After this time passes, you can slowly glance to the side and then go back to establishing eye contact.
report_en: People aim to maintain eye contact in conversation because it signals that they are actively listening and focusing on the speaker, which strengthens rapport and mutual understanding [1]; moreover, appropriate eye contact communicates interest and self-assurance, enhancing the speaker’s perceived credibility [2]. Communication experts recommend the “50/70 rule,” suggesting you look at your partner roughly half the time while talking and about 70 % while listening to balance attentiveness with comfort [2]. Practically, holding a gaze for 4–5 seconds before briefly glancing away prevents the interaction from feeling like a stare, keeping both parties at ease and sustaining positive non-verbal feedback [2]. Thus, people strive for well-timed eye contact because it conveys engagement, confidence, and respect, making conversations clearer and more persuasive.

Communication experts recommend the “50/70 rule,” suggesting you look at your partner roughly half the time while talking and about 70 % while listening to balance attentiveness with comfort [2].

question_en: Why do we say "pair of pants/jeans/shorts" when talking about one item of clothing when they are clearly not multiples?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do We Say “A Pair of Pants”? (www.britannica.com)
Why Do We Say “A Pair of Pants”? (www.britannica.com)
Why do we refer to "a pair of pants" when referring to one garment? (deep.mastersfamily.org)
pos_context_en: According to some, the phrase “pair of pants” harkens back to the days when what constituted pants—or pantaloons, as they were originally known—consisted of two separate items, one for each leg. They were put on one at a time and then secured around the waist.

The Oxford English Dictionary defines plurale tantum, which is Latin for “plural only,” as a “noun which is used only in plural form, or which is used only in plural form in a particular sense or senses.”

pants in the plural form is an Americanism first recorded in 1840. The word is short for pantaloons, a term that originated with a character in Italian commedia dell’arte who wore both stockings and breeches.
report_en: We still say “a pair of pants/jeans/shorts” because the earliest version of the garment—17th- and 18th-century pantaloons—was literally made as two separate pieces, one for each leg, that were pulled on individually and then tied together at the waist; people naturally spoke of this two-part outfit as a “pair,” and the expression stuck even after the two legs were sewn into a single unit [1].  Linguistically, pants belongs to a small class of “plurale tantum” nouns, words that exist only in a plural form (like scissors or binoculars), a status recognized by the Oxford English Dictionary, so English speakers keep the plural grammar and the word pair to signal the two leg elements implicit in the design [2].  The shortened term “pants” itself is an Americanism first noted in 1840, descended from “pantaloons” worn by a stock character in Italian commedia dell’arte [3].

question_en: How long would it take to see the stars when you take light pollution away?
pos_context_title_en: EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
Globe at Night - What is Light Pollution? (www.globeatnight.org)
light pollution | Definition, Causes, & Facts | Britannica (www.britannica.com)
pos_context_en:
What if you were far away from city lights, on a night with no moon and no clouds or haze. How many stars could you see with your unaided eye?


There’s really no definitive answer to this question. No one has counted all the stars in the night sky, and astronomers use different numbers as theoretical estimates.

Considering all the stars visible in all directions around Earth, the upper end on the estimates seems to be about 10,000 visible stars. Other estimates place the number of stars visible to the eye alone – surrounding the entire Earth – at more like 5,000. At any given time, half of Earth is in daylight. So only half the estimated number – say, between 5,000 and 2,500 stars – would be visible from Earth’s night side.


Plus, another fraction of those visible stars would be lost in the haze all around your horizon. That could bring you down to around 2,000, the number commonly used for these estimates. Just know that it varies depending on a number of factors.

You also have to take into account the brightness of your night sky. Even on a moonless night, the glow of lights from Earth’s surface brightens the sky.


Still, far from city lights – under absolutely perfect conditions of darkness and sky clarity – a young to middle-aged person with normal vision should be able to see thousands of stars.

Light pollution is excessive, misdirected, or obtrusive artificial (usually outdoor) light. Too much light pollution has consequences: it washes out starlight in the night sky, interferes with astronomical research, disrupts ecosystems, has adverse health effects and wastes energy.

Light pollution adversely affects professional and amateur astronomers, as well as casual observers of the night sky, because it severely reduces the visibility of stars and other celestial objects. The reduction in night sky visibility is a result of “skyglow,” upward-directed light emanating from poorly designed or directed lamps and security floodlights. This wasted light is scattered and reflected by solid or liquid particles in the atmosphere and then returned to the eyes of people on the ground, obliterating their view of the night sky.
report_en: Human-made light produces “skyglow,” upward-scattered illumination that obliterates the natural view of the night sky [5]. Because the stars are always shining, once those artificial lights are switched off or you reach a location free of light pollution, the skyglow disappears and stars become visible virtually at once. With the sky fully dark, an observer can usually see about 2,000 stars at any moment, since only half the celestial sphere is above the horizon and some stars near the horizon are lost in haze [2]. Under absolutely perfect darkness and clarity, a young to middle-aged person may perceive several thousand stars during the course of the night, far more than are visible from light-polluted areas [3].
all_claims: Human-made light produces “skyglow,” upward-scattered illumination that obliterates the natural view of the night sky [5].
Because the stars are always shining, once those artificial lights are switched off or you reach a location free of light pollution, the skyglow disappears and stars become visible virtually at once.
With the sky fully dark, an observer can usually see about 2,000 stars at any moment, since only half the celestial sphere is above the horizon and some stars near the horizon are lost in haze [2].

Under absolutely perfect darkness and clarity, a young to middle-aged person may perceive several thousand stars during the course of the night, far more than are visible from light-polluted areas [3].

question_en: Is there a biological reason that human beings are attracted to certain facial characteristics (such as a defined jawline) or is it just cultural preferences?
pos_context_title_en: Human (Homo sapiens) facial attractiveness in relation to skin texture and color - PubMed (pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov)
Facial Symmetry and Attractiveness | The Evolution of Human Sexuality (sites.psu.edu)
Why is a Jawline Considered Attractive? (thejawline.net)
pos_context_en: Attractiveness ratings of the images made by male participants relate positively to parameters of skin homogeneity. The authors propose that skin texture is a cue to fertility and health. In contrast to some previous studies, the authors found that dark skin, not light skin, was rated as most attractive.

The Evolutionary Advantage theory proposed that symmetrical faces are perceived as more attractive because the symmetry indicates good health in an individual. Everyone’s genes are designed to develop a face perfectly symmetrical, but as we grow, develop, and then age, disease, infections, and parasites cause imperfection in our appearance (asymmetry). Thus, those that have less asymmetry and imperfections, are perceived as having better and stronger immune systems to withstand the infections and parasites that occur naturally. So, symmetry is a good indicator of a person having good genes to pass on their offspring.

A strong Jawline is attractive to the opposite sex


This is a well documented fact, right from an evolutionary perspective. A strong jawline in men is considered to be a sign of high testosterone levels which translates into greater virility. High testosterone levels are a sign of a strong immune system which means greater strength and stamina; therefore a strong jawline in men is considered a trait that is attractive to women.


Women with sharp jawlines are equally attractive to men and a well defined jawline in women is considered a sign of strength, grace and responsibility; traits that are extremely attractive to men. Some of the most beautiful actresses and models are observed to have an extremely chiseled jawline.
report_en: Evolutionary psychology suggests many facial features are attractive because they signal health and reproductive fitness rather than mere cultural fashion. For example, facial symmetry is preferred because deviations can arise from disease or developmental stress, so a symmetrical face advertises robust genes and a strong immune system [2]. Similarly, smoother, evenly colored skin was rated more attractive by men, and researchers linked this to cues of fertility and general health [1]. In men, a pronounced jawline correlates with higher testosterone, which in turn is associated with virility and immune competence, making it appealing to women; sharp jawlines in women are likewise read as strength and reliability [3]. These consistent preferences across populations point to a biological basis. Nevertheless, culture modulates the details: the same study that tied skin homogeneity to attractiveness also found darker, not lighter, skin preferred, contradicting some previous Western findings and illustrating that social or cultural norms can shift specific ideals [1]. Overall, biology provides broad rules—symmetry, clear skin, markers of hormonal health—while culture fine-tunes which exact expressions of those cues are most valued in a given society.

Similarly, smoother, evenly colored skin was rated more attractive by men, and researchers linked this to cues of fertility and general health [1].

These consistent preferences across populations point to a biological basis.
