question_en: Why do we prefer cold pillows to warm pillows?
pos_context_title_en: While You Are Sleeping (www.webmd.com)
Learn How to Sleep All Night Naturally and Not Wake Up (amerisleep.com)
Too Hot to Sleep? Lots of Cooling Tips Here (bebrainfit.com)
Here Are The Effects Of Sleeping In A Cold Room | Sleep Advisor (www.sleepadvisor.org)
Here Are The Effects Of Sleeping In A Cold Room | Sleep Advisor (www.sleepadvisor.org)
pos_context_en: It tends to go up and down a little during the day, and the same is true at night, although while you’re sleeping it can be 1 to 2 degrees lower than in the daytime. Body temperature starts to fall as bedtime approaches, paving the way for a good night’s sleep. Your body also tends to lose heat, which helps you fall and stay asleep. That’s one of the reasons experts say you shouldn’t exercise close to bedtime: Exercise heats you up. We sleep better when we’re cooler. Your temperature starts to rise toward morning, preparing your body for wakefulness.
Keep it cool. The ideal temperature for sleep is around 65°, so set your thermostat accordingly. If that seems too chilly for comfort, experiment to find the temperature that’s right for you.

During this part of the sleep cycle, you lose some of your ability to thermoregulate, i.e., adjust your inner temperature to the surrounding air temperature.


So when the room temperature is too warm, your body starts to heat up which can wake you and make it hard to get back to sleep.

A stressful day and an overactive brain aren’t the only things keeping you awake at night. Studies show that people who suffer from insomnia tend to have a warmer core body temperature before falling asleep than so-called normal people.


Remember that our bodies cool off at night in anticipation of sleep. But if your body automatically runs hot, you’ll have to alter your environment to cool your temperature down enough to signal that it’s time for bed.

Sleeping barefoot and sticking one or both feet out from under the covers will help keep you cooler. We lose a lot of body heat through our head, hands, and feet, so allowing your feet to breathe has a cooling effect.
report_en: As bedtime approaches your core temperature drops by about 1–2 °F to pave the way for sleep [1]. One way the body accomplishes this is by releasing heat through exposed areas such as the head, hands and feet [5]. A cool pillow absorbs that excess heat, reinforcing the cooling that “helps you fall and stay asleep” [1]. When the surface around your head becomes warm, your body temperature rises instead, which can wake you and make it difficult to drift back to sleep [3]. Cooling the head is particularly helpful for people whose cores stay slightly hotter before bed, a trait often seen in insomnia sufferers [4]. For the same reason, experts suggest keeping the bedroom near 65 °F, because cooler conditions promote deeper, uninterrupted sleep [2]. Thus we instinctively prefer a cold pillow to a warm one: it supports the body’s nightly temperature drop, keeps us asleep, and simply feels more comfortable.

question_en: Shutter Speed and Aperture.
pos_context_title_en: Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed and Aperture - A Beginner's Guide (photographylife.com)
Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed and Aperture - A Beginner's Guide (photographylife.com)
Nikon | Imaging Products | DSLR Camera Basics (imaging.nikon.com)
pos_context_en: Shutter Speed – the length of time a camera shutter is open to expose light into the camera sensor. Shutter speeds are typically measured in fractions of a second, when they are under a second. Slow shutter speeds allow more light into the camera sensor and are used for low-light and night photography, while fast shutter speeds help to freeze motion.

Aperture – a hole within a lens, through which light travels into the camera body. The larger the hole, the more light passes to the camera sensor. Aperture also controls the depth of field, which is the portion of a scene that appears to be sharp. If the aperture is very small, the depth of field is large

changing aperture also changes depth of field, while changing shutter speed alters the appearance of moving objects. In other words, you can also adjust aperture for depth of field or shutter speed to produce the effect of motion.
report_en: Shutter speed is the length of time the camera’s shutter remains open, typically measured in fractions of a second; longer (slow) speeds admit more light for low-light or night scenes, while shorter (fast) speeds minimize the time light hits the sensor to freeze motion such as sports action [1]. Aperture is the adjustable hole in a lens through which light enters the camera body; widening it allows more light to reach the sensor, whereas narrowing it reduces light but increases the depth of field—the zone that appears acceptably sharp—so a very small aperture keeps more of the scene in focus [2]. In practice, photographers vary aperture mainly to control depth of field and vary shutter speed to influence how movement is rendered, balancing both settings for the desired creative effect [3].

Aperture is the adjustable hole in a lens through which light enters the camera body; widening it allows more light to reach the sensor, whereas narrowing it reduces light but increases the depth of field—the zone that appears acceptably sharp—so a very small aperture keeps more of the scene in focus [2].
In practice, photographers vary aperture mainly to control depth of field and vary shutter speed to influence how movement is rendered, balancing both settings for the desired creative effect [3].

question_en: Why sp@m Ema1ls are typed l1ke this?
pos_context_title_en: How To Avoid Email Spam Filters | Subject Lines, Trigger Words (www.yesware.com)
The 6 Most Common Subject Line Mistakes to Avoid (blog.aweber.com)
Overview of the Junk Email Filter (support.microsoft.com)
Overview of the Junk Email Filter (support.microsoft.com)
pos_context_en:
Sometimes the words you choose are what’s keeping you from reaching your prospect.


This applies most to your email subject line. Words like “free,” “money,” “help” and “reminder” all trigger content-based email spam filters. Especially if you’re not added as a contact in your recipient’s email database.
Special characters such as * % & # and ^, have been known to trigger spam filters, so be sure to use them sparingly as well.

The Junk Email Filter evaluates each incoming message to assess whether it might be spam, based on several factors. These can include the time when the message was sent and the content of the message.
Any message that is suspected to be junk is moved to the Junk E-mail folder.
report_en: Spammers disguise words with numbers or symbols (“sp@m,” “m0ney,” “fr€e”) because modern junk-mail filters automatically scan every incoming message for suspicious content and assign it a spam score [3]. A key element in that score is the direct appearance of “trigger” terms such as “free,” “money,” and “help,” which are statistically linked to unsolicited pitches and therefore raise the likelihood of the email being diverted to the Junk folder [1]. By substituting look-alike characters—an “@” for “a” or “1” for “l”—the sender breaks the exact keyword that the filter is programmed to flag, so the message can reach the inbox even though a human reader still recognizes the word. The tactic is essentially a simple form of obfuscation intended to fool pattern-matching algorithms while preserving readability. Although excessive punctuation (* % & #) can itself alert filters, clever spammers use just enough distortion to dodge automated detection without triggering the character-based rules explicitly called out in best-practice guides [2].

A key element in that score is the direct appearance of “trigger” terms such as “free,” “money,” and “help,” which are statistically linked to unsolicited pitches and therefore raise the likelihood of the email being diverted to the Junk folder [1].

question_en: Seismologists: How do you determine whether an earthquake was naturally occurring or if it was human induced?
pos_context_title_en: Human-Induced and Natural Earthquakes are 'Inherently Similar,' According to LSA Researcher | U-M LSA U-M College of LSA (lsa.umich.edu)
Natural or manmade quakes? New Stanford technique can tell the difference (news.stanford.edu)
Manmade and natural earthquakes not so different after all (earth.stanford.edu)
pos_context_en:
Huang's work discovered that stresses released by natural and human-caused earthquakes are similar, which means that the same tools might be used to predict both.


"Our study shows that induced earthquakes and natural earthquakes in the central U.S. are inherently similar, and we can predict the damaging effects of induced earthquakes using the same framework as natural earthquakes," said Huang.

A new study by Stanford researchers suggests that earthquakes triggered by human activity follow several indicative patterns that could help scientists distinguish them from naturally occurring temblors.

The research concludes that human-induced and naturally occurring earthquakes in the central U.S. share the same shaking potential and can thus cause similar damage.


The finding contradicts previous observations suggesting that induced earthquakes exhibit weaker shaking than natural ones. The work could help scientists make predictions about future earthquakes and mitigate their potential damage.
report_en: To decide whether an earthquake is natural or human-induced, seismologists combine seismological signatures with contextual evidence: (1) they map epicenters and depths—induced quakes usually occur within a few kilometers of injection wells or mines and are often shallower than tectonic events; (2) they analyze timing, looking for sharp increases in seismicity that begin soon after changes in industrial operations such as wastewater disposal, hydraulic fracturing, reservoir filling, or underground mining; (3) they perform statistical tests that compare event rates before and after industrial activity to quantify the likelihood of a causal link; and (4) they inspect waveform features—Stanford researchers showed that triggered quakes tend to follow “indicative patterns” in their frequency content and source characteristics, allowing machine-learning algorithms to classify them reliably [2]. Although recent work finds that once initiated, induced and natural quakes release stress and shake the ground in essentially the same way, making them equally hazardous [1], identifying their origin remains critical for mitigation and regulation.

Although recent work finds that once initiated, induced and natural quakes release stress and shake the ground in essentially the same way, making them equally hazardous [1], identifying their origin remains critical for mitigation and regulation.

question_en: How do we synchronize our pace when walking next to someone?
pos_context_title_en: Walking Together May Resolve Conflicts During the Pandemic (www.psychologytoday.com)
Mirror neuron system (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov)
In sync and in control? (newsroom.ucla.edu)
In sync and in control? (newsroom.ucla.edu)
pos_context_en:
Social walking is one way to activate "mirror-neuron networks."


We mimic each other’s pace and gait, swinging our arms and legs in unison. This entrains other physical processes: Our breathing becomes more synchronized and our heart rates increase and decrease (as we walk faster or slower, up-hill or down) at similar times. Walking together also elicits social-cognitive processing to help us understand the other person’s intentions and plans and process their social cues (speech, expression, gesture) in order to anticipate their movements and predict their trajectory.

Mirror neuron system is a group of specialized neurons that “mirrors” the actions and behaviour of others. The involvement of mirror neuron system (MNS) is implicated in neurocognitive functions (social cognition, language, empathy, theory of mind) and neuropsychiatric disorders.

We have found that when men are walking in step with other men, they think that a potential foe is smaller and less physically formidable and less intimidating than when they’re just walking in no particularly coordinated manner with other men

Even though each participant was accompanied only by a single companion, those who walked in unison with their partners judged the angry man as significantly less physically imposing than did the study subjects who had not walked in unison with their confederate: On average, they estimated that the man in the photo was about an inch shorter than the other participants did.
report_en: When two people walk side by side, visual and auditory cues from a companion’s footsteps automatically engage the brain’s mirror neuron system, a network that reproduces observed movements in our own motor circuits [2]; this neural mirroring makes us unconsciously adjust stride length, arm swing and tempo until our limbs move in unison [1]. As cadence aligns, physiological rhythms such as breathing and heart rate also synchronize, rising or falling together when the route slopes or speed changes [1]. Simultaneously, the brain’s social-cognitive processing monitors the partner’s speech, facial expressions and gestures, enabling rapid micro-corrections that keep steps matched and trajectories predictable [1].

As cadence aligns, physiological rhythms such as breathing and heart rate also synchronize, rising or falling together when the route slopes or speed changes [1].

Simultaneously, the brain’s social-cognitive processing monitors the partner’s speech, facial expressions and gestures, enabling rapid micro-corrections that keep steps matched and trajectories predictable [1].

question_en: Why are Video game QA jobs so terrible?
pos_context_title_en: The Class Of Quality Assurance (www.gamesindustry.biz)
The Horrible World Of Video Game Crunch (kotaku.com)
Quality Assured: What It’s Really Like To Test Games For A Living (kotaku.com)
The Tough Life of a Games Tester - IGN (www.ign.com)
The Tough Life of a Games Tester - IGN (www.ign.com)
pos_context_en: Quality Assurance, or game testing, has a bad reputation in the games industry. In some ways it's justified: the working conditions can be grim and the pay incredulously low. But, more damaging and dangerous, the bad reputation is often promoted and propagated by in-house attitudes towards QA that brands staff "minions"; low-level, disposable work-horses who'll do the most mundane of tasks for hours on end.

. Crunch, as it’s called, has become status quo for the video game industry, as routine to game developers’ lives as daily commutes or lunch breaks. From multimillion-dollar blockbusters like Call of Duty to niche RPGs like Trails, just about every video game in history is the net result of countless overtime hours, extra weekends, and free time sacrificed for the almighty deadline

QA testers also have to deal with game development’s other systemic issues—particularly, mandatory crunch and frequent layoffs. Big developers tend to hire dozens of QA testers toward the end of big projects only to let them all go once the game ships. Instead of partying with the rest of the developers, they’re out looking for new jobs.
Because playing videogames all day as a career has been heavily glamorized, companies are never at a loss for willing recruits. "Everyone in QA is expendable,
Once the product ships, you're out of a job. There are no benefits, no perks and definitely no promise of being hired full time.
report_en: Video-game QA roles are notorious because the working conditions are often “grim” and the pay “incredulously low,” giving the job an immediate stigma within studios [1]. Management frequently brands testers as low-level “minions,” treating them as disposable labor assigned the most monotonous tasks for hours on end [1]. The broader industry norm of “crunch” forces staff into routine, mandatory overtime, extra weekends, and sacrificed personal time to hit deadlines [2]. QA staff feel this pressure acutely, enduring crunch alongside threats of frequent layoffs and other systemic problems [3]. Big publishers typically hire dozens of temporary testers late in development only to terminate them once the game ships, leaving them to job-hunt while the rest of the team celebrates [3]. As a result, testers often finish projects with no benefits, no perks, and no promise of permanent employment [5]. Because playing games for a living sounds glamorous, studios can easily replace departing workers, reinforcing the view that “everyone in QA is expendable” [4].

question_en: How does a motorcycle "wobble" happen, and is it as hard to correct as it seems?
pos_context_title_en: What Causes Death Wobble Motorcycle | Sporty Journal (sportyjournal.com)
What Causes Death Wobble Motorcycle | Sporty Journal (sportyjournal.com)
What Causes Death Wobble Motorcycle | Sporty Journal (sportyjournal.com)
How to Prevent Speed Wobbles on a Motorcycle: Tricks, Tips, & More (www.nadaguides.com)
What’s A Speed Wobble and What Do You Do When You Get One - I Love Bicycling (ilovebicycling.com)
pos_context_en:
Death wobble occurs when there is a shaking movement of the front tires making it harder for the rider to control the sudden movement.


This sudden movement causes the front of the motorcycle tire to shake from side-to-side violently, resulting in the tires ‘wobble’ during the ride.

This happens when the front wheel rotation becomes imbalanced during the ride. Not handling the imbalance of the bike would result in a crash.


Speed and other physical forces put the burden on the tires, making it harder for them to control the pressure during a high-speed ride
Wearing of tires, loosening of pivots, and changes in loading would result in weaving which is dangerous as it can lower the frequency tempts that cause an imbalanced movement.

A speed wobble, also called a tank slapper or motorcycle headshake refers to when your handlebars oscillate rapidly from side to side. A speed wobble typically starts when the front wheel elevates from the ground when you accelerate, do a wheelie, or run into a pothole.
Distribution of weight centered more toward the rear of the bike causes the front end of the bike to loose stability at speed.
report_en: A motorcycle wobble—often called a speed wobble or tank-slapper—starts when the front wheel loses directional stability and the handlebars swing rapidly from side to side [4]. Triggers include an imbalance in the front-wheel’s rotation or momentary wheel lift during hard acceleration, wheelies, or after striking a pothole, which upsets the wheel’s gyroscopic stability [2]. Mechanical factors magnify the risk: worn tires, loosened steering pivots, or a shift in loading lower the machine’s natural stability frequency, making oscillations easier to start and harder to damp out [3], while rear-biased weight distribution further unloads the front tire, reducing its grip and stability at speed [5]. If the rider does nothing, the violent side-to-side motion can intensify quickly and lead to a crash [2]. Correcting it isn’t impossible, but it demands calm, immediate actions—relaxing the grip so the fork can self-center, smoothly rolling off the throttle, and shifting weight forward—combined with preventive maintenance such as keeping tires, suspension, and steering components in good condition and ensuring balanced loading.

If the rider does nothing, the violent side-to-side motion can intensify quickly and lead to a crash [2].

question_en: how a shark can detect blood from kilometres away. Do some molecules of the blood have to 'reach' the shark?
pos_context_title_en: Can A Shark Really Smell A Drop Of Blood From A Mile Away? (www.ripleys.com)
Shark Senses - Shark Facts and Information (www.sharks-world.com)
pos_context_en:
Even though there’s just a 1 in 3.7 million chance of being killed by a shark, people are so fearful of the predators that they’ve developed myths about them—such as their ability to smell a tiny drop of blood from miles away.


While sharks do have a strong sense of smell, this statement is largely overblown. Some sharks can identify blood a quarter-mile away, but the scent doesn’t reach them instantaneously or necessarily cause them to attack.


[Image: blue shark nostrils]


Sharks have a heightened sense of smell and olfactory system that is hundreds of times stronger than a human’s. Their nostrils, located beneath their snouts, are used only for smelling and not for breathing. They do have the capacity to detect tiny amounts of various compounds in the water. Some types of sharks, such as the lemon shark, can even detect a scent in a large swimming pool or a substance that is several hundred meters away.


But a shark more than a quarter-mile away won’t smell your blood and decide to make you into a yummy snack. Smells reach a shark through the currents, and it would take time for the scent to travel that distance to a shark’s nostrils. The motion of the ocean carries smell molecules with it, so, the more motion, the faster the smell will travel.


If you do start to bleed while swimming in the ocean, there is some time to get safely to shore in case a rogue shark decides to attack.

Sharks have nostrils that they only use to smell. When they swim, water flows through the nostrils, is introduced into the nasal duct and moves the last folds of the skin that has sensory cells. Some sharks, such as the lemon shark (Negaprion brevirostris), can detect a small amount of blood in the water.


The sense of smell is directional, this means that if the aroma comes from the left side of the shark, the shark first perceives it precisely in the left fossa rather than the right and can detect the location of the source of the smelling.


It is necessary to emphasize that they are very sensitive to odors and can differentiate a prey from another shark and even from a predator and respond in a decisive way to the smell produced by a wounded or fearful prey.
report_en: The popular claim that a shark can smell a single drop of blood from kilometres away is exaggerated; laboratory and field data show most species, even those with exceptional noses, detect blood at roughly a quarter-mile (about 400 m) under favourable conditions [1]. Odour molecules released by an injured animal must be physically transported by water currents to the shark’s nostrils, so detection is neither instantaneous nor possible until the plume reaches the fish [1]. As the shark swims, water streams into its paired nostrils, flows through a nasal duct and over folded skin rich in sensory cells that bind those molecules, converting chemical concentration into nerve signals [2]. Consequently, at least some of the blood’s chemical components have to contact these receptors before the shark “smells” anything, and the time this takes depends on current speed and dilution [1]. Experiments show lemon sharks can recognize minute traces in a large swimming pool or several hundred metres away, illustrating sensitivity, but still far short of multi-kilometre distances [1]. The shark then compares signal strength between left and right fossae to determine the direction of the source [2].

Odour molecules released by an injured animal must be physically transported by water currents to the shark’s nostrils, so detection is neither instantaneous nor possible until the plume reaches the fish [1].

As the shark swims, water streams into its paired nostrils, flows through a nasal duct and over folded skin rich in sensory cells that bind those molecules, converting chemical concentration into nerve signals [2].
Consequently, at least some of the blood’s chemical components have to contact these receptors before the shark “smells” anything, and the time this takes depends on current speed and dilution [1].

The shark then compares signal strength between left and right fossae to determine the direction of the source [2].

question_en: If Muslims commit murder like we saw in France, why is the media so quick to label it terrorism? If a Christian did it while screaming "Praise be to Jesus", would that also be labeled terrorism or would we just call him crazy? Is this biased Journalism?
pos_context_title_en: When Is It 'Terrorism'? How The Media Cover Attacks By Muslim Perpetrators (www.npr.org)
When Is It 'Terrorism'? How The Media Cover Attacks By Muslim Perpetrators (www.npr.org)
When Is It 'Terrorism'? How The Media Cover Attacks By Muslim Perpetrators (www.npr.org)
When Is It 'Terrorism'? How The Media Cover Attacks By Muslim Perpetrators (www.npr.org)
pos_context_en: Sometimes it can feel like there is a terrorist attack on the news every other week. But how much attention an attack receives has a lot to do with one factor: the religion of the perpetrator.
There is a systematic bias in the way terrorism is covered
Kearns says the "terrorism" label is often only applied to cases where the perpetrator is Muslim. And, those cases also receive significantly more news coverage.

"When the perpetrator is Muslim, you can expect that attack to receive about four and a half times more media coverage than if the perpetrator was not Muslim," Kearns says. Put another way, "a perpetrator who is not Muslim would have to kill on average about seven more people to receive the same amount of coverage as a perpetrator who's Muslim."
report_en: Studies of U.S. news coverage show a systematic bias in which violent acts by Muslim perpetrators are far more likely to be labeled “terrorism” than comparable acts by non-Muslims [2]; political scientist Erin Kearns finds the terrorism label is “often only applied to cases where the perpetrator is Muslim” [3]. This labeling also drives volume: attacks by Muslims receive about 4.5 times more coverage, and a non-Muslim would need to kill roughly seven additional victims to draw the same attention [4]. Because editors disproportionately reserve the word “terrorism” for Muslims, a hypothetical Christian attacker shouting “Praise be to Jesus” is statistically less likely to be tagged as a terrorist and more likely to be framed as mentally unstable or a lone wolf, even though both incidents could meet the standard definition of terrorism—violence intended to intimidate a population for ideological reasons. Therefore, the pattern reflects bias in journalistic practice rather than a neutral application of the term.

news coverage show a systematic bias in which violent acts by Muslim perpetrators are far more likely to be labeled “terrorism” than comparable acts by non-Muslims [2]; political scientist Erin Kearns finds the terrorism label is “often only applied to cases where the perpetrator is Muslim” [3].
This labeling also drives volume: attacks by Muslims receive about 4.5 times more coverage, and a non-Muslim would need to kill roughly seven additional victims to draw the same attention [4].

Because editors disproportionately reserve the word “terrorism” for Muslims, a hypothetical Christian attacker shouting “Praise be to Jesus” is statistically less likely to be tagged as a terrorist and more likely to be framed as mentally unstable or a lone wolf, even though both incidents could meet the standard definition of terrorism—violence intended to intimidate a population for ideological reasons.
Therefore, the pattern reflects bias in journalistic practice rather than a neutral application of the term.

question_en: How do firewalls work?
pos_context_title_en: How do firewalls work? Firewall technology explained (cybersecurity.att.com)
How do firewalls work? Firewall technology explained (cybersecurity.att.com)
How do firewalls work? Firewall technology explained (cybersecurity.att.com)
How do firewalls work? Firewall technology explained (cybersecurity.att.com)
pos_context_en:
Firewalls filter network traffic so that you only receive data that you should be getting. No firewall works perfectly, and a lot of a firewall's effectiveness depends on how you configure it.


To get a basic grasp of how firewalls work, it's important to understand how TCP packets work.


The data that your computer sends and receives over the internet or an internal network is comprised of TCP packets and UDP packets. TCP packets can be more effectively filtered by firewalls because they contain more information in their headers.


[Image]


TCP packets contain information such as source and destination addresses, packet sequence information, and payload. That information allows your network interface to deliver data properly, and a firewall can compare that information to the rules you configured it with. For example, all HTTPS data is transmitted through TCP packets. When HTTPS data is sent to your computer through your network interface while you surf the web, your operating system will know that it's data that's supposed to go to your web browser. The same applies if you are surfing the web - on your phone, on your PC, or even on a server machine in your datacenter. With the proliferation of the Internet of Things, you might even be surfing the web from a touchscreen embedded in your refrigerator. Your HTTPS data is used the same way regardless.
UDP packets can be filtered by port, but their headers lack the information that TCP packets have for more sophisticated filtering.
Stateless or packet filtering firewalls inspect each packet individually, without considering the trends of the data you're receiving.

Stateful firewalls do what stateless firewalls do, and they also consider the connection states of streams of data. This is the bouncer who may see one high school kid and then reject the whole group of high school kids, rather than asking each of them to prove their age. Stateful firewalls will collect a series of packets before it determines their connection state, and then compares those findings to the firewall rules, rather than applying the rules to each individual packet of data.
3. Application firewalls generally do everything that stateful firewalls do, and they also analyze the actual data content of the packets, not just the headers.
report_en: Firewalls are security devices or software placed at network boundaries to filter traffic so you only receive the data you should get [1]. Basic models do this by inspecting packet headers, while application firewalls go further and examine the actual payload data to spot malicious content [4]. TCP headers expose source, destination, sequence and payload information that rules can match against, making its traffic easier to filter accurately [1]. By contrast, UDP headers lack this detail, so filtering is typically limited to blocking or allowing specific ports [2]. Stateless (packet-filtering) firewalls apply the rules to each packet individually without tracking ongoing sessions, potentially missing patterns [3]. Stateful firewalls maintain awareness of connection states, assessing sequences of packets before deciding, much like a bouncer evaluating the whole group after noticing one underage visitor [4]. No firewall is flawless, and their overall effectiveness hinges on how well administrators craft and update the rule set [1].

question_en: Why do many people enjoy messing with others to a certain extent?
pos_context_title_en: Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
Why do People Bully? The Scientific Reasons - Ditch the Label (us.ditchthelabel.org)
pos_context_en:
Our data shows that those who bully are far more likely than average to have experienced a stressful or traumatic situation in the past 5 years. Examples include their parents/guardians splitting up, the death of a relative or the gaining of a little brother or sister.


It makes sense because we all respond to stress in very different ways. Some of us use positive behaviours, such as meditation, exercise and talking therapy – all designed to relieve the stress.


Others use negative behaviours such as bullying, violence and alcohol abuse, which temporarily mask the issues but usually make them worse in the long-term.


The research shows that some people simply do not know how to positively respond to stress and so default to bullying others as a coping mechanism.

66% of the people who had admitted to bullying somebody else were male. Take a minute to think about how guys are raised in our culture and compare that to the ways in which girls are raised. The moment a guy starts to show any sign of emotion, he’s told to man up and to stop being a girl.
In order to mask how they actually feel about themselves, some people who bully focus attention on someone else.
Our research shows that those who have experienced bullying are twice as likely to go on and bully others. Maybe they were bullied as kids in the past, or maybe they are being bullied now.

Without access to education, hate-based conversation directed at others may be the norm. They may not understand what hate speech is and why speaking about people in a derogatory way is not appropriate.

Finally, those who bully are more likely to feel like their friendships and family relationships aren’t very secure. In order to keep friendships, they might be pressured by their peers to behave in a certain way.
report_en: Many people derive a sense of satisfaction from “messing with” others because such behavior can serve as a maladaptive coping strategy, a means of conforming to social expectations, or a way to protect a fragile self-image. Those who have recently faced stressful or traumatic events often default to negative outlets such as bullying because they have not learned healthier stress responses [1]. Cultural norms can also encourage it; 66 % of self-admitted bullies are male, reflecting pressures on boys to suppress vulnerability and display dominance, so teasing becomes a socially sanctioned way to perform masculinity [2]. Additionally, targeting someone else can mask personal insecurities: by focusing attention outward, individuals temporarily distract themselves and observers from how badly they feel about themselves [3]. Prior victimization reinforces the cycle—people who have been bullied are twice as likely to bully others, normalizing the behavior and making it feel acceptable or even enjoyable [4]. In some environments, limited education about respectful communication means hostile banter is perceived as ordinary rather than harmful [5]. Finally, fragile friendships can incentivize group “messing” as a bonding tool, as people fear social exclusion if they do not join in [6].

Finally, fragile friendships can incentivize group “messing” as a bonding tool, as people fear social exclusion if they do not join in [6].

question_en: Why do some colleges send mass emails saying something along the lines of, "You have been selected for a prime selection status! Blah blah blah!" Do they not have enough applicants or are they generally interested?
pos_context_title_en: Is it Worth it to become an Amazon Student? (www.students.org)
Amazon Prime for Students 2021: Cost, Eligibility & Verification Guide (gladreaders.com)
pos_context_en: Amazon Student is a special service offered by Amazon which – you guessed it – caters specifically to students. Available initially as a free six month trial, the service can be extended after the trial for 50% off the price of a regular Amazon Prime account.

1. Have an Amazon.com account.
  2. Be a college student actively enrolled in at least one course at a college geographically located in one of the 50 United States, the District of Columbia, or Puerto Rico.
  3. Be able to provide proof of enrollment upon request, and 
  4. Have a valid e-mail address that contains the domain suffix .edu. If you are an eligible student and do not have a .edu email address, you can still qualify for the membership. (Explained in the verification process below)
report_en: Those “prime selection” notices are usually broad-based marketing messages generated when an organization (often Amazon promoting its discounted Prime Student plan) detects or purchases a list of active “.edu” addresses; any enrolled student with such an address is technically “eligible,” so the company blasts the same flattering language to thousands of recipients instead of hand-picking a small group [2]. The goal is not to fill an undersubscribed program but to maximize sign-ups: sending one mass message costs almost nothing and can convert a predictable fraction of students into paying members once the six-month free trial ends and the fee rises to 50 % of normal Prime pricing [1]. Thus, the email’s tone of exclusivity is a marketing tactic, not evidence that applicants are scarce or that the sender has evaluated you individually.

The goal is not to fill an undersubscribed program but to maximize sign-ups: sending one mass message costs almost nothing and can convert a predictable fraction of students into paying members once the six-month free trial ends and the fee rises to 50 % of normal Prime pricing [1].
Thus, the email’s tone of exclusivity is a marketing tactic, not evidence that applicants are scarce or that the sender has evaluated you individually.

question_en: If people can build their own computers, what is stopping people from building their own smartphones?
pos_context_title_en: Yes, you can build your own smartphone (www.zdnet.com)
I want to build my own smartphone (forums.tomsguide.com)
Make Your Own Cellphone From Scratch. (www.instructables.com)
pos_context_en:
A number of people have asked me whether it possible to build a smartphone out of easily available parts. Absolutely. It won't be as sleek or as powerful as one you could pick up, and you will have to assemble it yourself, but it's one of those projects that's very doable.


Here's one example built around a Raspberry Pi board, and Adafruit Fona GSM board, a 5-megapixel camera, 802.11n Wi-Fi, and a 3.5-inch display. You'll have to shop around for some of these parts, but the last time I looked they were all still available.


Now, this might not be a device that you want to carry around with you as a daily smartphone, but it's something that you could integrate into a bigger project, such as an IoT hub or maybe a rugged handset for use in an off-road vehicle or boat.

It's probably near impossible to build your own smartphone. It's not just that simple that you need the motherboard, and the processor. There are much more things you need to worry about as well. storage chip, accelerometer, compass, two cameras, radio chip (incorporating GPS, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and cellular), USB controller chip, Micro-USB port, LCD panel, capacitive touchscreen, battery, slider, keyboard, case, etc.... Most of the suppliers are from china. And I don't think you live in China. Even if you live in China, you probably have to contact all the suppliers in china (possibly over 100) to get the individual parts of a smartphone.

n fact, you can make a cellphone in much the same way you'd make anything else: find the right parts, figure out how to connect them together, and try to do it in a way that's attractive and robust. Because of the ubiquity of cellphones, there are companies making the components they're made of; with some digging, I was able to find versions of these parts that are possible to buy in small quantities and that are possible to assemble by hand. This wasn't necessarily easy, but it's a very different problem than trying to learn the physics needed to understand how a cellphone tower works
report_en: Unlike a PC, a modern smartphone packs dozens of tiny, specialized parts—storage, motion sensors, two cameras, a multi-band radio module with GPS/Wi-Fi/Bluetooth/cellular, USB controller, capacitive touchscreen, battery, case, etc.—that usually come from “possibly over 100” different suppliers, most of them in China, so a hobbyist must locate and negotiate with each one [2].  While it is technically possible to cobble together a DIY phone around boards such as a Raspberry Pi plus a GSM module, 3.5-inch display and camera, the result is bulkier and less powerful than any commercial handset and requires hand assembly of all subsystems [1].  Sourcing the right versions of these components in small quantities is “not necessarily easy,” demanding significant digging and electronics skill before you even start soldering and writing drivers [3].  Therefore, although enthusiasts occasionally succeed, the supply-chain complexity, tight integration and miniaturization requirements, and lack of consumer-grade economies of scale deter most people who might otherwise build phones as casually as they build desktop PCs.

question_en: Who are the Kurdish people?
pos_context_title_en: Kurds (en.wikipedia.org)
Kurds (en.wikipedia.org)
Kurds (en.wikipedia.org)
Today, the Kurds are spread across four nations. Who are they? (www.nationalgeographic.com)
pos_context_en: Kurds (Kurdish: کورد ,Kurd‎) or Kurdish people are an Iranian[28][29][30] ethnic group native to a mountainous region of Western Asia known as Kurdistan, which spans southeastern Turkey, northwestern Iran, northern Iraq, and northern Syria.[31] There are exclaves of Kurds in Central Anatolia, Khorasan, and the Caucasus, as well as significant Kurdish diaspora communities in the cities of western Turkey (in particular Istanbul) and Western Europe (primarily in Germany). The Kurdish population is estimated to be between 30 and 45 million.[2][32]

The term gained the characteristic of an ethnonym following the Muslim conquest of Persia, as it was adopted into Arabic and gradually became associated with an amalgamation of Iranian and Iranicised tribes and groups in the region.[41][42]

Many Kurds consider themselves descended from the Medes, an ancient Iranian people,[83] and even use a calendar dating from 612 BC, when the Assyrian capital of Nineveh was conquered by the Medes.[84] The claimed Median descent is reflected in the words of the Kurdish national anthem: "We are the children of the Medes and Kai Khosrow."

If you can’t point to Kurdistan on a map, you’re not alone: It’s not a sovereign country. But for Kurds, an ethnic group of roughly 30 million people, it is very real indeed. Nestled on the margins of Turkey, Iran, Iraq, and Syria, Kurdistan is one of the planet’s most volatile regions, and its people are the world’s largest stateless group.


The Kurds are indigenous to the Middle East, but scholars and Kurdish people alike disagree as to the group’s origin. Nor do all Kurds share a religious identity: Though the majority of Kurds are Sunni Muslims, other religions are practiced as well.


What is clear is a Kurdish ethnic identity and common language. Those commonalities emerged around the Middle Ages. Since then, Kurds have played roles in the histories of what are now Iran, Iraq, Syria, and Turkey.


But while they flourished and wielded influence in the region, Kurds lost their lands when the Ottoman Empire took over most Kurdish-held territory in the 1500s.
report_en: The Kurds are an Iranian ethnic group native to the mountainous region of Kurdistan, which spans southeastern Turkey, northwestern Iran, northern Iraq, and northern Syria [1]. Estimated at between 30 and 45 million people, they constitute one of the world’s largest stateless nations [1]. Significant Kurdish communities also exist in central Anatolia, Khorasan, the Caucasus, the western Turkish metropolis of Istanbul, and in Western Europe—particularly Germany—due to migration and diaspora formation [1]. The word “Kurd” became a distinct ethnonym after the Muslim conquest of Persia, when it was applied to an amalgam of Iranian and Iranicised tribes in the area [2]. Many Kurds claim descent from the ancient Medes, a tradition echoed in their national anthem and in a calendar dated from 612 BC, the year the Medes captured Nineveh [3]. While most Kurds are Sunni Muslims, the population encompasses multiple religions, underscoring their internal diversity [4].

Many Kurds claim descent from the ancient Medes, a tradition echoed in their national anthem and in a calendar dated from 612 BC, the year the Medes captured Nineveh [3].
While most Kurds are Sunni Muslims, the population encompasses multiple religions, underscoring their internal diversity [4].

question_en: Dictionary tells me agnostic means "I think it can't be proven" but commonly in North America people seem to use it to mean "kinda don't believe in God". Why is that?
pos_context_title_en: What Is The Difference Between Agnosticism And Atheism? (www.worldatlas.com)
What Does "Agnostic" Mean? (www.psychologytoday.com)
pos_context_en: Agnostic people believe that the existence of God or a supernatural being is unknown and beyond human reason. The phrase “agnosticism” was first used by Thomas Henry Huxley against religious people who accused him of denouncing the role of God in the creation of the universe. Huxley supported the theories of evolution by Charles Darwin and did not subscribe to religious beliefs. He believed that nature was too diverse to have been created and that natural selection provided a better explanation provable by evidence. Huxley thought that agnosticism was a principle and not a belief. He reiterated that it is wrong for one to claim a phenomenon is a definite truth unless logical evidence is provided. The word was coined as the antagonist of the phrase “Gnosticism,” meaning “knowledge.” Gnosticism was a religious ideology in the first and second centuries that suggested that the material world was ungodly while the spirit world was the better choice. Although agnosticism was not intended to raise the question of whether God exists or not, it found its way to the religious world. Huxley justified his stand by claiming that he did not deny or affirm the mortality or human and therefore, did not see the reason to believe or disprove the existence of God. He challenged the religious and atheists to prove or disprove the presence of God.

“Maybe there is a God, but maybe not. I’m just not sure. I mean, who can really say?”


If you’ve ever uttered such words or heard someone else utter them, you’re dealing with agnosticism.


“Agnostic” is a label people often use to indicate that they embrace an orientation somewhere between the serene surety of knowing that there is a God and the conviction that there isn’t.


That is, while a theist is someone who believes in God, and an atheist is someone who does not believe in God, an agnostic is someone who isn’t convinced that God exists, but at the same time, can’t be totally sure that God doesn’t exist. And given a lack of knowledge concerning the question of God’s existence – or the lack of any possibility of such knowledge -- an agnostic simply sighs and shrugs, offering an unapologetic “Who knows?” to the whole matter.


In the words of philosopher Julian Baggini, an agnostic “claims we cannot know whether God exists and so the only rational option is to reserve judgment.”
report_en: Thomas Huxley coined “agnostic” for the claim that no one should affirm God’s existence (or non-existence) without evidence, making it a position about knowledge rather than belief [1].  In everyday North American speech, however, “atheist” is often heard as an emphatic “There is no God,” so many non-believers avoid the word’s perceived militancy and instead pick “agnostic” to signal uncertainty or modest disbelief; surveys such as Pew’s regularly separate “atheist” and the less confrontational “agnostic,” reinforcing this softer usage.  Because an agnostic “isn’t convinced that God exists, but at the same time, can’t be totally sure that God doesn’t exist” [2], the term sits halfway between faith and denial, and popular culture shortens this nuanced stance to “kinda don’t believe.”  Over time the public conflated “not knowing” with “not really believing,” so “agnostic” drifted from Huxley’s epistemic caution to a colloquial synonym for weak atheism, especially in regions where openly rejecting God can carry social stigma; the word lets speakers distance themselves from religion without declaring outright atheism, explaining the North American tendency you’ve noticed.

In everyday North American speech, however, “atheist” is often heard as an emphatic “There is no God,” so many non-believers avoid the word’s perceived militancy and instead pick “agnostic” to signal uncertainty or modest disbelief; surveys such as Pew’s regularly separate “atheist” and the less confrontational “agnostic,” reinforcing this softer usage.

question_en: when anticipating pain, such as a rubber band snapping skin, why do we feel a tingling sensation in our legs?
pos_context_title_en: Paresthesia: Causes of Pins and Needles, Numbness, and "Skin Crawling" (www.webmd.com)
Causes of Tingling Sensations in the Body - You are Mom (youaremom.com)
Causes of Tingling Sensations in the Body - You are Mom (youaremom.com)
pos_context_en: Paresthesia happens because of pressure on a nerve. When that pressure is gone -- you uncross your legs, for example -- the feeling goes away.

Temporary paresthesia, also known as tingling, is a fairly uncomfortable sensation that can be experienced in any part of the body. However, it usually occurs in our extremities, which is to say our arms, hands, legs, and feet.


When this happens, it’s understood that the central and peripheral nervous systems are involved. To put it in simple terms, this occurs when some kind of pressure is exerted on the nerve terminals, generally in the extremities.

Now, you may be wondering why this sensation happens mainly in the arms and legs. The reason is that it’s quite common for us to exert pressure on these areas by sitting, leaning, or holding a certain position for a long period of time.


When this happens, we put pressure on the nerves in the area in question, which are responsible for transmitting information between the body and the brain.


Additionally, the pressure involved in the posture cuts off the blood vessels that bring oxygen to the nerves. As such, these cannot send information to the brain.


[Image: Causes of Tingling Sensations in the Body]


Tingling begins when the pressure is relieved and the nerves resume transmitting their signals, albeit in a delayed manner.
report_en: When you brace for an expected snap, you instinctively tense and keep your legs rigid or in an awkward position; this sustained posture presses on the peripheral nerves and the small blood vessels that supply them, especially in the thighs and calves, interrupting normal nerve signaling and oxygen delivery, so the moment you relax those nerves fire erratically and create the characteristic “pins-and-needles” sensation in your legs, a transient form of paresthesia [2], which fades quickly once the pressure is removed, just like the tingling that stops after you uncross your legs [1].
all_claims: When you brace for an expected snap, you instinctively tense and keep your legs rigid or in an awkward position; this sustained posture presses on the peripheral nerves and the small blood vessels that supply them, especially in the thighs and calves, interrupting normal nerve signaling and oxygen delivery, so the moment you relax those nerves fire erratically and create the characteristic “pins-and-needles” sensation in your legs, a transient form of paresthesia [2], which fades quickly once the pressure is removed, just like the tingling that stops after you uncross your legs [1].

When you brace for an expected snap, you instinctively tense and keep your legs rigid or in an awkward position; this sustained posture presses on the peripheral nerves and the small blood vessels that supply them, especially in the thighs and calves, interrupting normal nerve signaling and oxygen delivery, so the moment you relax those nerves fire erratically and create the characteristic “pins-and-needles” sensation in your legs, a transient form of paresthesia [2], which fades quickly once the pressure is removed, just like the tingling that stops after you uncross your legs [1].

question_en: Explain: Having a "stone" in your saliva gland.
pos_context_title_en: Salivary Stones (www.hopkinsmedicine.org)
Salivary Stones (www.hopkinsmedicine.org)
Salivary Gland Stones: Symptoms, Causes, and Treatment (www.webmd.com)
Salivary Gland Stones: Symptoms, Causes, and Treatment (www.webmd.com)
Salivary stones: Symptoms, causes, and how to get rid of them (www.medicalnewstoday.com)
pos_context_en: Salivary stones, also called sialolithiasis, are hardened mineral deposits that form in the salivary glands. The condition is more likely to affect people age 30 to 60 and men are more likely to get salivary stones than women.

The cause is not known, but several factors are associated with salivary stone formation:


* Dehydration, due to inadequate fluid intake, illness, or medications such as diuretics (water pills) and anticholinergic drugs


* Trauma to the inside of the mouth


* Smoking


* Gum disease

A salivary gland stone -- also called salivary duct stone -- is a calcified structure that may form inside a salivary gland or duct. It can block the flow of saliva into the mouth.


The majority of stones affect the submandibular glands located at the floor of the mouth. Less commonly, the stones affect the parotid glands, located on the inside of the cheeks, or the sublingual glands, which are under the tongue. Many people with the condition have multiple stones.

Salivary stones form when chemicals in the saliva accumulate in the duct or gland. They mostly contain calcium. The exact cause is not known. But factors contributing to less saliva production and/or thickened saliva may be risk factors for salivary stones. These factors include: dehydration, poor eating, and use of certain medications including some antihistamines, blood pressure drugs, psychiatric drugs, and bladder control drugs. Trauma to the salivary glands may also raise the risk for salivary stones.

Salivary stones are rarely serious, and a person can often treat them at home.


Home remedies for getting rid of salivary stones include:


* Sucking on citrus fruits or hard candies. Sucking on a wedge of lemon or orange increases the flow of saliva, which can help dislodge the stone. A person can also try sucking on sugar-free gum or hard, sour candies, such as lemon drops.
* Drinking plenty of fluids. Regular fluid intake helps keep the mouth hydrated and can increase saliva flow.
* Gentle massage. Gently massaging the affected area may relieve pain and encourage the stone to pass through the salivary duct. The Sjogren’s Syndrome Foundation have an illustrated guide on how to do this on their website.
* Medications. Some over-the-counter drugs, such as ibuprofen and acetaminophen, can help relieve pain and swelling.
* Sucking on ice cubes. Sucking on something cold, such as an ice cube or ice pop, may also help reduce pain and swelling resulting from salivary stones.
report_en: A salivary gland stone, or sialolithiasis, is a hardened mineral deposit that develops inside a salivary gland or its duct [1]. It is a calcified structure that can obstruct the normal flow of saliva into the mouth [3]. The majority of stones involve the submandibular glands on the floor of the mouth, whereas the parotid or sublingual glands are less often affected, and many patients have multiple stones [3]. The condition is seen most often in adults aged 30–60 years, with men affected more frequently than women [1]. Stones arise when calcium-rich chemicals in saliva precipitate, but the exact cause remains unknown [4]. Factors that diminish saliva volume or increase its thickness—such as dehydration, poor eating, and certain antihistamines, blood-pressure, psychiatric, or bladder control medications—can increase risk [4]. Additional associations include dehydration from inadequate fluid intake or diuretics, trauma inside the mouth, smoking, and gum disease [2]. Salivary stones are rarely serious and are often treatable at home [5]. Effective self-care measures include sucking on citrus wedges or sour candy, drinking plenty of fluids, gentle gland massage, using over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, and sucking on ice to relieve discomfort [5].

question_en: Do people who hear for the first time, after something like getting hearing implants, know what the other people are saying?
pos_context_title_en: What’s It Like for a Deaf Person to Hear for the First Time? (slate.com)
Cochlear implants - Mayo Clinic (www.mayoclinic.org)
Cochlear Implant: Cost, Pros, Cons, Risks, How It Works (www.healthline.com)
pos_context_en:
Most children will require at least some speech therapy, depending what age they received their implants. Training time ranges from a year to 12 (I clocked in at 11) and varies in terms of intensity. As they learn how to listen, their brains are doing heavy lifting by burning new neural pathways. Some of them will never listen or speak like someone born hearing due to various factors out of people’s control.


Hearing—or, rather, the perception of it—isn’t a light switch you flip on and off. It’s serious business.

Cochlear implants use a sound processor that fits behind the ear. The processor captures sound signals and sends them to a receiver implanted under the skin behind the ear. The receiver sends the signals to electrodes implanted in the snail-shaped inner ear (cochlea).


The signals stimulate the auditory nerve, which then directs them to the brain. The brain interprets those signals as sounds, though these sounds won't be just like normal hearing.


It takes time and training to learn to interpret the signals received from a cochlear implant. Within a year of use, most people with cochlear implants make considerable gains in understanding speech.
Though the brain will notice the sounds, they’re not the same as normal hearing. Speech therapy and rehabilitation are necessary to learn how to properly interpret these sounds.
report_en: No—when a cochlear implant is first switched on, the new wearer usually hears unfamiliar electronic signals rather than recognizable words, so they do not automatically understand what others are saying; speech comprehension develops only after extensive training because the brain must “burn new neural pathways” to interpret the signals, a process that can take from about 1 to 12 years of speech therapy depending on the age of implantation and other factors [1]. Most recipients make “considerable gains in understanding speech” within the first year, but even then the sound quality “won’t be just like normal hearing,” and some users will never listen or speak like someone born hearing [2].

question_en: Why do people in all old voice recordings have the same "old timey" accents?
pos_context_title_en: Mid-Atlantic accent (en.wikipedia.org)
Transatlantic Accent: Why Did Actors in Old Movies Have Weird Accents? (www.theintrepidguide.com)
Transatlantic Accent: Why Did Actors in Old Movies Have Weird Accents? (www.theintrepidguide.com)
Transatlantic Accent: Why Did Actors in Old Movies Have Weird Accents? (www.theintrepidguide.com)
We found out why all the actors from Hollywood's Golden Age have such a distinct and strange accent (www.thevintagenews.com)
We found out why all the actors from Hollywood's Golden Age have such a distinct and strange accent (www.thevintagenews.com)
pos_context_en: It is also possible that a clipped, nasal, "all-treble" acoustic quality sometimes associated with the Mid-Atlantic accent arose out of technological necessity in the earliest days of radio and sound film, which ineffectively reproduced natural human bass tones.[57] As used by actors, the Mid-Atlantic accent is also known by various other names, including American Theater Standard or American stage speech.[54]

This consciously learned accent was a blend of American English and British English which favoured neither. Its premise was to neutralise strong accents and eliminate Britishisms and Americanisms so that the speaker could be understood on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. Hence its name.

One theory as the origins of the accent comes from the “announcer English” used by radio broadcasters. Due to the poor quality of microphone and loudspeakers at the time, the speaker needed to enunciate very clearly and use a lot of emphases to ensure their audience could understand them.

[blockquote align=”none” author=”William Labov”]teaching of this pronunciation declined sharply after the end of World War II. As a result, this American version of a ‘posh’ accent has all but disappeared even among the American upper classes
YouTube page BrainStuff has a short video that explains why the people in old movies might have that unique accent. It’s called t

BrainStuff explains that according to Professor Jay O’Berski, this nasally, clipped pronunciation is a vestige from the early days of radio. Receivers had very little bass technology at the time, and it was very difficult – if not impossible – to hear bass tones on your home device.
report_en: The identical-sounding “old timey” accent often heard in early 20th-century American recordings is the consciously taught Mid-Atlantic or Transatlantic accent, a blend of British and American pronunciation created so speakers could be clearly understood on both sides of the Atlantic [2]. It was promoted in elite schools and especially in stage and screen training, meaning most actors, announcers and public figures who were recorded in the 1920s-1940s learned the same pronunciation rules, giving surviving clips a striking uniformity [4]. Technical constraints reinforced this choice: early radio and film equipment reproduced high frequencies but lost bass, so a clipped, nasal, “all-treble” delivery cut through the limited bandwidth more effectively than natural speech [1]. Radio “announcer English” therefore stressed precise enunciation and exaggerated emphasis, further entrenching the accent on the airwaves [3]. As instruction waned after World War II and technology improved, the accent quickly faded, leaving it a relic of historic recordings [4].

As instruction waned after World War II and technology improved, the accent quickly faded, leaving it a relic of historic recordings [4].

question_en: Why can't we just dump all our trash in molten lava to rid of it instead of having it seep and pollute the ground water while in the landfill?
pos_context_title_en: Why we can't dump all our trash into volcanoes? (www.scienceabc.com)
Why we can't dump all our trash into volcanoes? (www.scienceabc.com)
Garbage into volcanoes: How safe is it to dump rubbish into volcanoes? (www.scientificmystery.com)
pos_context_en:
Lava lakes are undeniably complex and unpredictable wonders of nature. Being extremely hot, they can melt plenty of things, but not everything. There are thousands of forms of plastic, rubber, fabrics and other such materials that would float atop the viscous lava, rather than sinking into the heated void.


[Image: Lava_Lake_Nyiragongo]


An active Lava Lake (Photo Credit: Cai Tjeenk Willink /Wikimedia Commons)


Secondly, lava lakes are not infinitely deep. All that melted trash would have to end up somewhere, and while most of it might vanish in plumes of smoke and vapour – the smoke emanating from that destruction would be incredibly harmful to breathe or send up into the atmosphere.


As terrifying and wrathful as lava lakes are, in reality, they do have a finite volume, and are often on the move up and out of the vent, due to the incredible pressures building up inside.

Lava lakes are unstable beneath their semi-solid, comparatively cool upper layer. If you pierce their surfaces with a relatively cold object, like a piece of trash, the sudden transfer of heat could trigger a chain reaction of explosions. The upper layer starts melting down, releasing pressurized acidic steam and fumes from the vaporized trash. A single tin can might serve as a trigger to start this chain reaction and invoke the wrath of the previously stagnant lava lake!


[Image: Related image]


A chain reaction in action ( https://africageographic.com/blog/hot-as-hell-at-erta-ale/)


Now, imagine the impact of throwing an entire nation’s garbage in a volcano… unimaginably destructive chain reactions would begin. To put this in perspective, minute rockfalls into lava lakes of Hawaiian volcanoes have forced lava more than 85 m (280 feet) into the air. The scenario with tons of garbage would be far more treacherous and perilous for anyone working on the garbage-disposal task.

There are three types of volcanoes – strato, shield, and dome. Out of these, an ideal volcano to dump the trash would be a shield volcano. It is low profile lava, i.e. it has a slow eruption, with lave slowly spewing out onto the earth. However, the numbers of them are not very common. There are only 600 shield volcanoes, with most of them being inactive. There is the number of stratovolcanoes scattered on the earth, but they are known for their explosive nature. Thus, they are definitely not the spot for the dump.


[Image]


Credit-Tropical-Helicopters


Above all, disposing the trash into the lava would be a very expensive method. We have to have the endless stream of trucks traveling to the nearest active volcano to dispose of the trash. An even bigger problem is that there are not as many active volcanoes in the world; there are only 1500 potentially active volcanoes worldwide. When most of the countries don’t have any active volcano, the problem for those countries would still persist.
report_en: Although lava is scorching, thousands of plastics, rubbers and fabrics would simply float on its viscous surface instead of sinking and vanishing, so much of the trash would not be destroyed at all [1]. Whatever does melt would rise as vast plumes of toxic smoke that are “incredibly harmful to breathe or send up into the atmosphere,” swapping soil contamination for air pollution on a global scale [1]. Introducing relatively cold garbage also destabilizes the lava lake’s semi-solid crust, and even small rockfalls have hurled lava 85 m into the air, meaning truck-loads of waste could trigger far more violent steam-and-gas explosions [2]. Because lava lakes have finite volume, the remaining slag would eventually clog the vent or overflow, creating new hazards rather than eliminating the material [1]. Practicality is worse: Earth hosts only about 1,500 potentially active volcanoes and merely 600 slow-erupting shield volcanoes—most inactive and remote—so shipping everyday refuse to them would be logistically complex and prohibitively expensive [3]. For health, safety, capacity and economic reasons, volcano dumping is neither a clean nor a viable alternative to managing trash on land.

Practicality is worse: Earth hosts only about 1,500 potentially active volcanoes and merely 600 slow-erupting shield volcanoes—most inactive and remote—so shipping everyday refuse to them would be logistically complex and prohibitively expensive [3].
For health, safety, capacity and economic reasons, volcano dumping is neither a clean nor a viable alternative to managing trash on land.

question_en: why do lithium batteries lifetime shortens the more you use them?
pos_context_title_en: Lithium Battery Lifetime | Large Battery (www.large-battery.com)
Lithium Battery Lifetime | Large Battery (www.large-battery.com)
How Long Do Lithium-ion Batteries Last? (www.protoolreviews.com)
How Long Do Lithium-ion Batteries Last? (www.protoolreviews.com)
How Long Do Lithium-ion Batteries Last? (www.protoolreviews.com)
How Long Do Lithium-ion Batteries Last? (www.protoolreviews.com)
How Long Do Lithium-ion Batteries Last? (www.protoolreviews.com)
pos_context_en: Because of material and mechanism features of lithium battery, lifetime of lithium battery has longer than that of other existing rechargeable batteries. Cycle times of LiFePo4 battery can even reach 2000.

A number of external factors affect a battery pack’s lifespan on the shelf. What was the state of the pack’s charge when it was stored? Will the user store the battery in hotter or colder temperatures? Will it be stored on the tool, on the shelf, or on the charger? Who made the internal electronics, and how well do those electronics control the current within the pack?
Of course, if a battery pack drops below a certain charge capacity, the pack will cease charging at all
Blunt force trauma will adversely affect the lifespan of your Li-ion batteries.

Makita tells us that they use a “smart” system that accounts for this. Their chargers and batteries use a communication system that recognizes a battery’s current charge level and temperature. Then, the charger regulates the optimal current, voltage, and temperature to recharge the battery. This process extends the life of the battery.
As far as how many charging cycles to expect, most manufacturers seem to fall into the 1000 to 2000 charge cycles camp.
report_en: Lithium-ion batteries wear out because every charge–discharge cycle leaves a little irreversible damage: lithium ions become trapped, electrode materials fracture, and internal resistance rises, so usable capacity falls progressively with use. Manufacturers therefore rate packs for about 1000–2000 full cycles before noticeable loss of runtime occurs [7]. Stressful operating conditions accelerate this chemical and mechanical fatigue; guidelines recommend keeping cells between roughly 20 % and 80 % state-of-charge and avoiding over-current events because deep cycling or heavy currents hasten degradation [2]. High or low storage temperatures have the same effect, making thermal management critical for longevity [3]. Once capacity sinks below a set threshold, the battery’s protection circuitry will refuse to accept further charge, effectively declaring the pack dead [4]. Physical shocks also shorten life by damaging internal structures and electronics [5]. Chargers that actively monitor temperature, voltage, and current can slow the rate of damage, demonstrating that gentler use directly translates into a longer service life [6].

question_en: Should the average person be concerned about the spread of Ebola as of right now?
pos_context_title_en: Ebola: Should we be worried? (tarrant-tx.tamu.edu)
Ebola Might Be a Chronic Infection – But Here's Why We Shouldn't Panic | Global Biodefense (globalbiodefense.com)
​Ebola: Should we be worried? (www.cbsnews.com)
​Ebola: Should we be worried? (www.cbsnews.com)
pos_context_en:
According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the spread of Ebola in the affected African countries is due to a lack of medical professionals, treatment facilities, and supplies. In addition, not enough people in these countries understand how the disease is spread and how to keep it from spreading to others.

The CDC is trying to make sure that people who appear sick do not get on a plane to come to the US. They are also screening people arriving from countries known to have Ebola. Finally, even if someone does develop Ebola after returning to the US, our public health system has a strong ability to track people and their contacts. Our health care system has plenty of supplies, medicines, doctors, and nurses with the know-how to treat and stop it from spreading.

Eighteen people are reported to have been infected, of which nine have died. Although vaccines against Ebola exist and have been rolled out, there is the fear that these small clusters of infection could ignite into something much, much larger.

What’s unusual about the virus that has caused this new outbreak is that it doesn’t seem to have come from an animal but from a human.

Ebola is spread by direct contact with body fluids. It is not spread through the air the way influenza is. If it were, there would be millions of cases of Ebola throughout Africa, just as there are tens of millions of flu cases in this country every year.
But individual cases will not lead to widespread outbreaks, if healthcare workers make diagnoses quickly and the correct protocols are followed. This will protect healthcare workers from Ebola,
report_en: At present, the average person in the United States or other countries with robust public-health infrastructure faces very little risk from Ebola because multiple containment layers are in place. U.S. authorities screen travelers from affected regions and prevent visibly ill passengers from boarding flights, then use well-established contact-tracing systems should a case appear domestically, all backed by abundant medical staff, supplies and isolation capacity [1]. Even if an imported patient were missed, Ebola spreads only through direct contact with infected body fluids, not through the air, making community transmission inherently harder than with respiratory viruses such as influenza [3]. Experience shows that when healthcare workers recognize cases quickly and follow correct protocols, isolated infections do not escalate into wider outbreaks [4]. While a recent flare-up infected 18 people and caused nine deaths overseas, such small clusters have not translated into sustained global spread [2].

While a recent flare-up infected 18 people and caused nine deaths overseas, such small clusters have not translated into sustained global spread [2].

question_en: What exactly is going on with my computer when it crashes?
pos_context_title_en: Why do computers crash? (www.scientificamerican.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
Why do Computers Crash? Top 5 Reasons Your PC Might Crash | ThrottleNet IT Blog (www.throttlenet.com)
pos_context_en: Computers crash because of errors in the operating system (OS) software or errors in the computer hardware. Software errors are probably more common, but hardware errors can be devastating and harder to diagnose.
Corrupted System Registry Files
Every Windows-based PC has something called a Windows registry. The registry contains several files that are integral to the performance and operation of your computer

#2: Disorganized Files


Windows operating systems handle file organization in a way that isn’t very intuitive. Basically, they break files up and fit them into gaps in the computer’s memory. As time goes by, these disorganized files can prompt frequent crashes

#3: Malicious Software


Malicious software can take many different forms. Sometimes, it’s a virus that is accidentally unleashed after opening a strange email; other times, its adware that tags along with other information that is automatically downloaded from a website.

#4: Too Little Available Memory


When you buy a new computer, it feels like there’s no end to the amount of memory that it has. Of course, this isn’t true at all. As never-ending as the available memory on your PC may initially seem, the fact is that it can be depleted with incredible speed.

#5: Overheating


If you’ve run through all of the preceding possibilities and continue experiencing frequent crashes, a hardware issue could be to blame. An easy one to rule out is overheating. A computer’s CPU, or central processing unit, includes a fan that is designed to keep it running cool. Sometimes, the fan wears down and doesn’t work as efficiently; other
report_en: When your computer “crashes,” the operating system suddenly stops functioning because it encounters an unrecoverable error in its own code or in the hardware it relies on [1]. One frequent culprit is corruption inside the Windows registry—the set of critical configuration files the OS consults every time it boots or launches programs—so if these files are damaged the system may abruptly freeze or reboot [2]. Crashes can also stem from the way Windows scatters pieces of files across the drive; over time this fragmentation leaves data in awkward gaps, and attempts to read these scattered pieces can overwhelm the OS and trigger a halt [4]. Malicious software may intentionally disrupt normal processes, consuming resources or altering system libraries until the kernel can no longer execute safely [5]. Even with healthy software, running out of RAM forces the OS to thrash the hard disk, slowing response and sometimes causing a lock-up [6]. Finally, overheating a CPU—often due to a failing cooling fan—can cause emergency shutdowns to prevent permanent damage [7].

Finally, overheating a CPU—often due to a failing cooling fan—can cause emergency shutdowns to prevent permanent damage [7].
