question_en: Why is photographer Terry Richardson so famous and prevalent.
pos_context_title_en: Terry Richardson | Photography and Biography (www.famousphotographers.net)
26 Sinfully Delicious Terry Richardson Photo Shoots (www.trendhunter.com)
100 Terry Richardson Photos (www.trendhunter.com)
pos_context_en: Terry Richardson’s work revolves around repetitive themes including celebrities, sexual ideas, nudity and unusual humor. Initially, his subjects were photographed with a white background however gradually he began using different backdrops. Apart from photographing his subjects, he poses with them in many pictures as well. In some pictures he lends his glasses to his subjects so they could pose pretending to be him and he could pose like them.

American fashion photographer Terry Richardson is one of the most prolific and acclaimed photographers of today. His trademark snapshot aesthetic and excessively sexual style has brought an appealing edge to mainstream advertising.

Terry Richardson came from a highly artistic family background.

Quintessential Terry Richardson photos are without a doubt some of the most recognizable photos in the world. Famous for his non-nonchalant hipster vibe, Terry Richardson has a serious taste for the unconventional.

Whether it's an ad campaign, an editorial in GQ or simply celebrity photography fun, a Terry Richardson photo is unlike any other style of photography out there. Highly saturated colors, Polaroid-style, white background, goofy faces and sultry poses are a part in most, if not all, of Terry's photography. From Obama, Lindsay Lohan, Kate Upton to Rhianna, Terry has a way of making the subject of his images let loose and feel as if they're having a great time playing around with a friend.

Almost as famous for his signature square glasses as he is for his photography, Terry Richardson photos capture some of this generation's most famous celebrities.
report_en: Terry Richardson’s fame stems from a distinctive snapshot aesthetic—saturated colors, Polaroid-style framing and often a stark white backdrop—that makes his images immediately recognizable in magazines and ad campaigns [3]. He consistently injects overt sexuality, nudity, celebrity presence and off-beat humor into his shoots, pushing boundaries that draw both controversy and attention [1]. This “excessively sexual style” gives mainstream advertising an edgy appeal, keeping major brands and editors eager for his eye-catching work [2]. Richardson’s easygoing manner encourages subjects to “let loose,” attracting high-profile sitters such as Barack Obama, Lindsay Lohan, Kate Upton and Rihanna and ensuring widespread visibility for his photographs [3]. He further amplifies his personal brand by appearing in the pictures himself—often swapping his trademark square glasses with the model—so viewers instantly recognize a “Terry shot” [1]. The sheer volume and online circulation of compilations like “100 Terry Richardson Photos” underline his productivity and the persistent demand for his provocative style [3].

pos_context_title_en: How The Vatican Influences Italy - Italy Chronicles (italychronicles.com)
How The Vatican Influences Italy - Italy Chronicles (italychronicles.com)
GlobalPlus: Religion and politics in Latin America - The ARDA | Global Plus (globalplus.thearda.com)
GlobalPlus: Religion and politics in Latin America - The ARDA | Global Plus (globalplus.thearda.com)
pos_context_en:
The politics of Italy seem to be intertwined with the teachings of the Roman Catholic church and the policies of the Vatican, even if the Roman Catholic church tends to keep rather silent on issues such as corruption and organized crime. Religion lessons in Italy’s state schools reflect the teachings of the Roman Catholic church.


If the Vatican considers an aspect of the Italian government’s policies disagreeable, it will voice an opinion and friendly Italian politicians will leap to its defense and lend their unquestioning support up to and including blocking legislation which is seen to go against the Church’s teachings.

News in Italy on the taxing of church premises issue has been, to say the least, confusing. One day the Roman Catholic church is to pay, the next, it is not, then it is, then it isn’t, and so on.


Publicly, the Roman Catholic church is somewhat mute on the issue, but privately, the impression is that Vatican politicians, read Cardinals, have been liaising with friendly Italian politicians in an attempt to keep commercial premises owned by the Roman Catholic church tax free.

That Catholicism still exerts strong moral influence on other public policy issues in Argentina is evident in the continuing ban on abortion, and in the most-favored legal status provided to Catholicism in the constitution. All non-Catholic groups have to register with the government.

Yet numerous Judeo-Christian categories remain in force, secularized but without losing their sense of origin; to nominate, differentiate, and prioritize symbolic, political, and social spaces.


The democratic presidents of Latin America use narratives abundant with signs, rites, and sacred symbols that resonate with Christians and religious individuals.


The current presence of a pope from Argentina with broad language and gestures originating in Latin American politics revives the old narrative of a Latin America Catholic culture separate from the U.S. White Anglo-Saxon Protestant culture. That helps increase Catholic identification even in more secular countries such as Uruguay or multicultural as Bolivia or communist as Cuba.
report_en: The Pope’s speeches, while not legally binding, can markedly shape public policy in Catholic-majority nations because political elites often translate papal positions into legislative action. In Italy, whenever the Vatican publicly disapproves of a government proposal, “friendly Italian politicians…leap to its defense…up to and including blocking legislation which is seen to go against the Church’s teachings,” illustrating that a single pronouncement can stall or kill parliamentary initiatives [1]. Behind the scenes, Church authorities have similarly persuaded allies to shield ecclesiastical commercial property from taxation, causing repeated governmental U-turns on the issue [2]. In Argentina, Catholicism’s moral authority, reinforced by papal rhetoric, is reflected in the continuing national ban on abortion and the constitutionally privileged status the faith enjoys, despite overall secular trends [3]. Latin American presidents routinely weave sacred imagery into policy narratives, and the presence of an Argentine Pope has renewed Catholic identification across the region, giving his words added electoral weight and policy leverage [4].

In Italy, whenever the Vatican publicly disapproves of a government proposal, “friendly Italian politicians…leap to its defense…up to and including blocking legislation which is seen to go against the Church’s teachings,” illustrating that a single pronouncement can stall or kill parliamentary initiatives [1].
Behind the scenes, Church authorities have similarly persuaded allies to shield ecclesiastical commercial property from taxation, causing repeated governmental U-turns on the issue [2].

In Argentina, Catholicism’s moral authority, reinforced by papal rhetoric, is reflected in the continuing national ban on abortion and the constitutionally privileged status the faith enjoys, despite overall secular trends [3].

Latin American presidents routinely weave sacred imagery into policy narratives, and the presence of an Argentine Pope has renewed Catholic identification across the region, giving his words added electoral weight and policy leverage [4].

question_en: How can a vehicle's air filter effect its gas mileage?
pos_context_title_en: Can Replacing Your Air Filter Improve Gas Mileage? - (www.pgfilters.com)
5 Benefits of Changing Your Air Filter (www.carsdirect.com)
FAQs About Your Car's Fuel and Air Filters (www.firestonecompleteautocare.com)
pos_context_en: Dirty air filters reduce airflow – Air filters trap contaminants in a media made of paper and synthetic fibers. Over time, this media becomes filled with dirt and debris, preventing the engine from breathing properly. As a result, the engine will work harder and use more fuel.

One of the biggest reasons to change your air filter regularly. Some studies indicate that replacing a dirty air filter increases fuel mileage on older, carburated cars by as much as 14 percent if the filter is so dirty it affects driveability. In addition, changing a clogged air filter can potentially increase acceleration by 6 to 11 percent on modern fuel-injected cars. Other studies claim a 10 percent increase in gas mileage and up to 15¢ per gallon fuel savings. Regardless of the exact figures, it is obvious that a clean air filter improves air flow to the engine and increases engine performance and gas mileage.

When your air filter is dirty, your engine is forced to work harder, resulting in poor fuel economy, higher emissions and, possibly, a loss of engine power. In turn, as a worst-case scenario, a clogged cabin air filter can lead to under-performance of the A/C system, causing weak air flow from the cabin vents. It can also lead to unwanted, unfiltered air in the cabin. As for a mucked-up fuel filter, that’ll land you with a weakened fuel supply to injectors, a reduction in engine power, poor acceleration and lousy fuel economy—not to mention a potential breakdown.
report_en: A vehicle’s air filter traps dirt but, once clogged, it restricts intake airflow to the engine [1]. Reduced airflow forces the engine to work harder and burn more fuel, lowering gas mileage [1]. Firestone further notes that this extra strain results in “poor fuel economy” and diminished power output [3]. Quantitatively, research referenced by CarsDirect shows that replacing a severely dirty filter on older carbureted cars can raise fuel mileage by up to 14 %, while other studies report roughly a 10 % gain in typical situations [2]. Even modern fuel-injected cars see performance benefits, with clean filters improving acceleration by 6–11 % and yielding about 15 ¢ per gallon in fuel savings, suggesting better efficiency [2]. Consequently, regularly installing a clean air filter helps the engine maintain an optimal air-fuel mix, consume less gasoline, and achieve better overall mileage.
all_claims: A vehicle’s air filter traps dirt but, once clogged, it restricts intake airflow to the engine [1].
Reduced airflow forces the engine to work harder and burn more fuel, lowering gas mileage [1].
Firestone further notes that this extra strain results in “poor fuel economy” and diminished power output [3].

Quantitatively, research referenced by CarsDirect shows that replacing a severely dirty filter on older carbureted cars can raise fuel mileage by up to 14 %, while other studies report roughly a 10 % gain in typical situations [2].
Even modern fuel-injected cars see performance benefits, with clean filters improving acceleration by 6–11 % and yielding about 15 ¢ per gallon in fuel savings, suggesting better efficiency [2].
Consequently, regularly installing a clean air filter helps the engine maintain an optimal air-fuel mix, consume less gasoline, and achieve better overall mileage.

Reduced airflow forces the engine to work harder and burn more fuel, lowering gas mileage [1].
Firestone further notes that this extra strain results in “poor fuel economy” and diminished power output [3].

Quantitatively, research referenced by CarsDirect shows that replacing a severely dirty filter on older carbureted cars can raise fuel mileage by up to 14 %, while other studies report roughly a 10 % gain in typical situations [2].

question_en: What parts I would need to replace my Cable Box in the UK if I build a HTPC?
pos_context_title_en: How to build a HTPC (Home Theater PC) | Digital Trends (www.digitaltrends.com)
How to build a HTPC (Home Theater PC) | Digital Trends (www.digitaltrends.com)
How to build a HTPC (Home Theater PC) | Digital Trends (www.digitaltrends.com)
pos_context_en:
While there are Raspberry Pi builds less than $100 that can give you respectable H.264 and Blu-ray quality playback, I prefer a full-sized HTPC that provides HDMI 1.4 output, HD audio bit streaming, 7.1 surround sound, DVR functionality, speedy boot times and a significant amount of storage for your personal library of video content.


Personally, I prefer starting with the case over any other component. The components within my home theater are a point of presentation for me when I have friends over and the HTPC is always a topic of conversation when I’m zipping through XBMC searching for something to watch. The size of the case also dictates what type of motherboard is required for your build. Mini-ITX and Micro ATX are popular choices among HTPC enthusiasts that want to make a minimal impact on their home theaters; popular brands include Lian Li and nMEdiaPC.

If you want a showpiece within your setup, consider picking up a regular-sized ATX case. Silverstone, Moneual Labs and Thermaltake all manufacture large ATX cases that look very similar to a standard surround sound receiver. While more expensive than smaller cases, this style can include a digital touchscreen display, a large audio knob for the volume and a variety of programmable buttons. For a less expensive solution in this category, check out APEVIA cases. If you are looking for something truly unique to attract attention, nMEDIAPC makes a fantastic wooden PC case that looks like an old-timey radio that would have been used many decades ago.


Remember that case material and size are factors in cooling the HTPC. A heavier case is often a better choice than a lightweight case in order to cut down on vibration and noise when the fans are running. Larger cases are easier to cool as well, thus allowing for additional hard drives and other components down the line. Be aware that larger fans for an ATX case will usually generate more noise than fans within a Micro ATX case, so look for case fans that are specifically marketed as silent.
4GB of RAM (perfectly fine for video playback) and a 64GB SSD drive for quick booting of the operating system.
report_en: To replace your UK cable box you will need: a purpose-built HTPC chassis (Mini-ITX, Micro-ATX or full-size ATX); the case choice matters because it sets motherboard size and affects presentation, cooling and noise [1]; a motherboard/GPU that provides HDMI 1.4 so you can send HD video and bit-stream 7.1 audio to your TV or AV receiver and enable DVR features [1]; at least 4 GB of RAM, which is ample for smooth video playback [3]; a 64 GB (or larger) SSD to give the operating system very quick boot and wake times [3]; a dual-tuner DVB-T2/C TV card or USB stick to receive and record Freeview HD or Virgin Media channels; a spacious 1–4 TB hard drive for storing recordings and ripped media; silent or low-RPM case fans because cooling requirements rise with extra drives and larger ATX enclosures can be noisier if fans are not chosen carefully [2]; a Windows or Linux OS plus media-centre software such as Kodi with a PVR backend; and an IR/Bluetooth remote or wireless keyboard for living-room control. Together these parts give you live TV, recording, streaming and library playback, letting the HTPC fully replace a conventional set-top cable box.

question_en: Why does smoking tobacco cause cancer, but smoking marijuana does not?
pos_context_title_en: Cancer Risk | NAS | Marijuana (www.cdc.gov)
Tobacco and Cancer | CDC (www.cdc.gov)
pos_context_en:
* Smoked cannabis has many of the same cancer-causing substances as smoked tobacco3. Due to the risks it poses to lung health, experts strongly caution against smoking cannabis and tobacco products.
* More research is needed to know if smoking cannabis increases a person’s risk for lung cancer. However, it is difficult to determine whether there is a link, because cannabis use often overlaps other behaviors related to lung cancer, such as tobacco use.

Tobacco smoke has at least 70 chemicals that cause cancer, also known as carcinogens. Every time you breathe in that smoke, those chemicals get into your bloodstream, which carries the chemicals to all parts of your body. Many of these chemicals can damage your DNA, which controls how your body makes new cells and directs each kind of cell to do what it is made for. Damaged DNA can make cells grow differently from how they are supposed to. These unusual cells can turn into cancer.
report_en: Tobacco is a confirmed human carcinogen because its smoke contains at least 70 chemicals that cause cancer; every inhalation delivers these substances into the bloodstream, where they can damage DNA and trigger the abnormal cell growth that leads to tumors [2]. Cannabis smoke does carry “many of the same cancer-causing substances as smoked tobacco,” yet scientists have not been able to establish a clear, independent link between smoking marijuana and lung cancer, largely because available studies are few, users generally inhale less over a lifetime, and cannabis consumption often overlaps with tobacco use, which obscures results [1]. Thus, the difference lies not in tobacco being uniquely toxic and marijuana benign, but in the weight of evidence: decades of epidemiologic data unequivocally implicate tobacco in cancer, while research on marijuana remains insufficient, leaving its specific cancer risk unproven rather than disproved.
all_claims: Tobacco is a confirmed human carcinogen because its smoke contains at least 70 chemicals that cause cancer; every inhalation delivers these substances into the bloodstream, where they can damage DNA and trigger the abnormal cell growth that leads to tumors [2].

Cannabis smoke does carry “many of the same cancer-causing substances as smoked tobacco,” yet scientists have not been able to establish a clear, independent link between smoking marijuana and lung cancer, largely because available studies are few, users generally inhale less over a lifetime, and cannabis consumption often overlaps with tobacco use, which obscures results [1].

Thus, the difference lies not in tobacco being uniquely toxic and marijuana benign, but in the weight of evidence: decades of epidemiologic data unequivocally implicate tobacco in cancer, while research on marijuana remains insufficient, leaving its specific cancer risk unproven rather than disproved.

Cannabis smoke does carry “many of the same cancer-causing substances as smoked tobacco,” yet scientists have not been able to establish a clear, independent link between smoking marijuana and lung cancer, largely because available studies are few, users generally inhale less over a lifetime, and cannabis consumption often overlaps with tobacco use, which obscures results [1].
claims_retained: Tobacco is a confirmed human carcinogen because its smoke contains at least 70 chemicals that cause cancer; every inhalation delivers these substances into the bloodstream, where they can damage DNA and trigger the abnormal cell growth that leads to tumors [2].

question_en: how does peeing after sex prevent infections when the urethra and vagina are two different holes?
pos_context_title_en: UTIs and urinating after sexual intercourse: What is the link? (www.medicalnewstoday.com)
UTIs and urinating after sexual intercourse: What is the link? (www.medicalnewstoday.com)
Good Hygiene After Sex (www.webmd.com)
What urinating after sex does and does not prevent in women (www.mymed.com)
pos_context_en:
Experts debate whether urinating after sex helps prevent UTIs.


Many health authorities, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), recommend urinating after sex to prevent UTIs. Doing so may help flush away bacteria that are close to the urethra and prevent them from entering the urinary tract.


However, research published in a 2016 edition of American Family Physician suggests that urinating after sex does not have any measurable protective effects. Still, the researchers note, it is a safe and reasonable thing to do.
Bacteria in the genital or anal region can enter the urethra during sex if a person does not wash their hands between touching the anus and genitals.
During sex, bacteria can get into your urethra, the tube that carries urine out of your body. That can raise your chances of an infection. When you pee, you flush those germs out.

When you urinate after immediately after sex, this helps to flush out the harmful bacteria that enters the vagina through penetration and keeps it from spreading to the nearby urethra and causing an infection.
report_en: Although the urethral and vaginal openings are separate, they lie very close on the external genitalia, so thrusting, fingers, or contact with contaminated skin can push bacteria from the vagina, perineum, or anus to the urethral opening [2]. Urinating soon after intercourse creates a rapid outward flow of urine that can wash these microbes back out of the urethra before they migrate up into the bladder, thereby potentially reducing urinary-tract infections [1]. Medical guides explain this flushing action simply: “When you pee, you flush those germs out” [3]. Evidence is mixed—one study found no measurable protective effect—yet clinicians still call the practice a safe, reasonable precaution, because it removes organisms without causing harm [1].
all_claims: Although the urethral and vaginal openings are separate, they lie very close on the external genitalia, so thrusting, fingers, or contact with contaminated skin can push bacteria from the vagina, perineum, or anus to the urethral opening [2].

Urinating soon after intercourse creates a rapid outward flow of urine that can wash these microbes back out of the urethra before they migrate up into the bladder, thereby potentially reducing urinary-tract infections [1].
Medical guides explain this flushing action simply: “When you pee, you flush those germs out” [3].
Evidence is mixed—one study found no measurable protective effect—yet clinicians still call the practice a safe, reasonable precaution, because it removes organisms without causing harm [1].

question_en: When I watch cooking shows it never shows the chefs washing their hands or cleaning anything, how often do chefs wash their hands? What about knives, utensils, etc?
pos_context_title_en: Why Don't TV Chefs Wash Their Hands? — Home Cook World (homecookworld.com)
Don't Eat Food Prepared by a Celebrity Chef on TV (gizmodo.com)
pos_context_en:
TV chefs actually wash their hands before and during filming. Since viewers have a short attention span and these scenes aren’t the most exciting part of an episode, they typically get edited out to shorten the show.


While this helps keep people like you and me engaged, it also sends the wrong season to those just getting started in home cooking, who are probably unaware of how vital kitchen hygiene is to their health.

Only Emeril Lagasse even mentioned washing his hands before cooking, and all but three of the chefs are shown handling meat without washing their hands at least once. Nineteen of the chefs handled completely cooked food barehanded and only a third of the chefs demonstrate safe cutting board use, that is, changing or cleaning the board after chopping raw meat. Only a quarter discussed the temperature of their meat, which is important, say the researchers, because consumers might not know the doneness of the meat they cook.
report_en: Professional food-safety rules require cooks to scrub their hands with soap and warm water before starting work, after handling raw meat or eggs, after touching their hair, face, phones, or garbage, and at least every four hours during continuous food preparation; knives, boards, and utensils should be cleaned or swapped whenever they switch from raw to ready-to-eat foods, and sanitized at the end of each service. On television, however, you rarely see this because the hand-washing and wipe-downs are usually filmed but then edited out so the show flows faster, giving viewers “the wrong lesson” about kitchen hygiene [1]. Researchers who analyzed 39 U.S. cooking programs found that only one chef even mentioned washing hands, and 19 chefs were shown touching fully cooked food with bare, unwashed hands; only a third changed or cleaned cutting boards after raw meat, and just a quarter discussed cooking temperatures, illustrating how much routine safety practice is left off-screen [2].
all_claims: Professional food-safety rules require cooks to scrub their hands with soap and warm water before starting work, after handling raw meat or eggs, after touching their hair, face, phones, or garbage, and at least every four hours during continuous food preparation; knives, boards, and utensils should be cleaned or swapped whenever they switch from raw to ready-to-eat foods, and sanitized at the end of each service.

On television, however, you rarely see this because the hand-washing and wipe-downs are usually filmed but then edited out so the show flows faster, giving viewers “the wrong lesson” about kitchen hygiene [1].
Researchers who analyzed 39 U.S.

cooking programs found that only one chef even mentioned washing hands, and 19 chefs were shown touching fully cooked food with bare, unwashed hands; only a third changed or cleaned cutting boards after raw meat, and just a quarter discussed cooking temperatures, illustrating how much routine safety practice is left off-screen [2].

cooking programs found that only one chef even mentioned washing hands, and 19 chefs were shown touching fully cooked food with bare, unwashed hands; only a third changed or cleaned cutting boards after raw meat, and just a quarter discussed cooking temperatures, illustrating how much routine safety practice is left off-screen [2].

question_en: why are there so many third class levers in our body?
pos_context_title_en: Third-Class Levers in the Human Body | Science project | Education.com (www.education.com)
Levers work to create movement in the human body (us.humankinetics.com)
Levers work to create movement in the human body (us.humankinetics.com)
Basic Biomechanics: Levers (www.aaronswansonpt.com)
pos_context_en:
In a third-class lever, the input force is in between the output force and the fulcrum. An example of this class of lever is a baseball bat. The handle of the bat is the fulcrum, you supply the input force near the middle, and the other end of the bat that pushes the ball with the output forces. In a third-class lever, the input force is greater than the output force but the output load is able to move farther.

[Image: Examples of Levers]

You have several third-class levers in your body. One that is easy to investigate is your forearm.

Bones, ligaments, and muscles are the structures that form levers in the body to create human movement. In simple terms, a joint (where two or more bones join together) forms the axis (or fulcrum), and the muscles crossing the joint apply the force to move a weight or resistance. Levers are typically labeled as first class, second class, or third class. All three types are found in the body, but most levers in the human body are third class.

There are numerous third-class levers in the human body; one example can be illustrated in the elbow joint (figure 1.23b). The joint is the axis (fulcrum). The resistance (weight) is the forearm, wrist, and hand. The force is the biceps muscle when the elbow is flexed.

## Mechanical Advantage in Biomechanics

It may seem confusing that most of the muscles in the human body are 3rd class levers, since these levers are at a mechanical disadvantage in terms of effort versus load. However, this only holds true in terms of resistance. The opposite is true when you consider the distal lever displacement. A small arc of motion proximally at the muscle insertion will create large angular displacement and velocity distally. Since most human movement is aimed at maximizing angular displacement of a distal segment through space, the use of 3rd class levers for is very efficient.

This creates a relationship between the lever arm distance, distal angular displacement/velocity, and torque production. The shorter the lever arm of the effort force (decreased mechanical advantage), the greater angular displacement and angular velocity of the distal end of the lever for a given arc of displacement of the effort force. The larger the lever arm of the effort force (increased mechanical advantage), the increased torque production.

This lever arm and force/torque production relationship needs to be taken into consideration when assessing movement and prescribing interventions. For example, applying a 5 pound weight at the distal end of a lever during a scaption/SLR exercise creates a mechanical disadvantage for the supraspinatus/illiopsoas. This results in the muscle being overloaded in attempt to create the amount of torque necessary for the distal angular displacement.
report_en: Human bones act as levers with joints as fulcrums and muscles as the applied force, and the majority of these levers are third class [2]. In a third-class lever the force is applied between fulcrum and load, so muscles must generate more force than the resistance, yet the load moves through a greater distance [1]. This arrangement sacrifices mechanical advantage but converts small, rapid muscle contractions into wide, fast movements of the hands, feet, and other distal segments, because a short effort arm produces large angular displacement and high velocity at the opposite end of the limb [4]. Since everyday activities such as reaching, running, and throwing depend more on speed and range than on lifting massive weights, evolution favors third-class designs to maximize movement efficiency rather than raw strength, explaining why they dominate our musculoskeletal system [4].

question_en: Explain: Integral Calculus
pos_context_title_en: What Is Integral Calculus? (with pictures) (www.wise-geek.com)
Integral calculus | mathematics (www.britannica.com)
Introduction to Integration (www.mathsisfun.com)
pos_context_en: Integral calculus, also known as integration, is one of the two branches of calculus, with the other being differentiation. Differentiation describes how the value of a function changes with respect to its variables. Integration is the inverse, in that it gives the exact summation of a function between two values. Integral calculus provides an exact means of calculating the area under the curve of a mathematical function. Integration has a wide range of applications in physics and engineering.

Integral calculus, Branch of calculus concerned with the theory and applications of integrals. While differential calculus focuses on rates of change, such as slopes of tangent lines and velocities, integral calculus deals with total size or value, such as lengths, areas, and volumes.
Integration can be used to find areas, volumes, central points and many useful things. But it is easiest to start with finding the area between a function and the x-axis
report_en: Integral calculus, often called integration, is one of the two main branches of calculus alongside differentiation [1]. While differentiation looks at how a function changes at each point, integral calculus performs the inverse operation by summing infinitesimal contributions to find a total between two bounds [1]. In formal terms it studies integrals, mathematical tools that capture cumulative quantities such as length, area, volume or overall value [2]. A classical use is computing the exact area under the curve of a function on a given interval, effectively measuring the space between the graph and the x-axis [1]. The same technique extends to finding volumes of solids, centers of mass and other aggregate properties of physical systems [3]. Because it converts local rates into global totals, integration is indispensable in physics and engineering for tasks ranging from determining displacement from velocity data to calculating electric charge over a surface [1].

question_en: What is Google Fiber and will it grow outside of the US?
pos_context_title_en: 'What is Google Fiber?': Everything you need to know about Google's high-speed internet service (www.businessinsider.com)
Google Fiber Internet: Coverage & Availability Map (broadbandnow.com)
When is Google fibre coming to the uk or are they not bring it to the uk? (support.google.com)
pos_context_en:
Google Fiber is a broadband internet service that Google is currently deploying in 18 cities across the US.
* The service is notable because of its high speed, running up to 1000 Mbps, with a friendly month-to-month, all-inclusive pricing scheme.
* Despite the initial promise of the network, Google has paused expansion of Fiber beyond its current 18 cities, and notably pulled Fiber out of several cities where it attempted to deploy the service.
* Visit Business Insider's Tech Reference library for more stories.


Google Fiber is Google's fiber optic-based broadband internet service, which debuted in 2010. It's built to deliver high-speed connectivity to businesses and individuals in select cities.


At least, that was the goal. While it once appeared that Google intended to roll out Google Fiber across the entire US, the company "paused" most of its expansion plans, adding only one new city in the last four years — they announced in July 2020 that Fiber would be coming to West Des Moines, IA, but it won't be ready for several years.


Currently, Google Fiber services are available in 18 locations across the country.


## Where Google Fiber currently operates


[Image]


You can visit the Google Fiber website to check its availability and sign up for the service. Dave Johnson/Business Insider


The service is currently operating or rolling out operations in 18 cities, including Atlanta, Georgia; Austin, Texas; Charlotte, North Carolina; Chicago, Illinois; Denver, Colorado; San Francisco, California; and Seattle, Washington.

Google Fiber mainly focuses on urban areas where existing fiber and city regulations make it possible to install FTTH (Fiber to the Home) rapidly. The Google Fiber project has been on hold since 2016, when the company stopped expanding and reportedly cut many jobs related to the project.

When is Google fibre coming to the uk or are they not bring it to the uk?


Pin


Lock


1 Recommended Answer 2 Replies 62 Upvotes


I wanted to know when or if Google fibre was coming to the uk


Recommended Answer Recommended Answers (1)


Hi Dantaining,


At this time we have no plans to expand Google Fiber internationally.


- Robert, the Google Fiber team
report_en: Google Fiber is Google’s fiber-optic broadband service, launched in 2010, that delivers up to 1,000 Mbps internet on a month-to-month, all-inclusive plan [1]. It currently operates or is being installed in 18 U.S. metropolitan areas, including Atlanta, Austin, Charlotte, Chicago, Denver, San Francisco and Seattle [1]. Google paused most expansion in 2016, reportedly cutting many jobs tied to the project [2]. Since then it has announced only one additional city, West Des Moines, Iowa, which is still several years from service launch [1]. Asked about international availability, the Google Fiber team states there are “no plans to expand Google Fiber internationally” at this time [3]. Consequently, while the network offers gigabit speeds within its existing U.S. footprint, significant growth—especially outside the country—appears unlikely for the foreseeable future.

question_en: Asking for my class, what's a gerund?
pos_context_title_en: What is a Gerund? Definition, Examples & Exercises (www.gingersoftware.com)
Gerunds // Purdue Writing Lab (owl.purdue.edu)
What is a Gerund? Definition, Examples of Gerunds (writingexplained.org)
pos_context_en: Gerunds are words that are formed with verbs but act as nouns. They’re very easy to spot, since every gerund is a verb with ing tacked to its tail. There are no exceptions to this rule.

. A gerund is a verbal ending in -ing that is used as a noun.
2. A gerund phrase consists of a gerund plus modifier(s), object(s), and/or complement(s).
3. Gerunds and gerund phrases virtually never require punctuation

Gerund definition: A gerund is a noun formed from a verb. A gerund will always contain the ending “-ing.”


What are gerunds? Any verb ending in “-ing” and used as a noun is a gerund.


Examples of Gerunds:


Verb/Gerund


* to run/running
* I run every day. / I like running.


In the first sentence, “run” is used as a verb. I am “doing” the action “to run.” In the second sentence, “running” is used as a gerund (noun) and “like” is the verb.


* to sing/singing
* Sara sings. Singing makes Sara happy.


In the first sentence, “sings” is used as a verb. Sara is “doing” the action “to sing.” In the second sentence, “singing” is used as a gerund and “makes” is the verb.


Note: A gerund will always be used as a noun and does not replace the progressive form of the verb.
report_en: A gerund is a verbal ending in “-ing” that functions as a noun [2]; in other words, it is a word formed from a verb but acting as a noun [1]. Every gerund always carries the “-ing” ending—there are no exceptions to this rule [1]. Because it behaves like a noun, a gerund can appear where nouns normally do, for example as the object in “I like running” [3]. A gerund phrase expands on the gerund by adding modifiers, objects, or complements, and such phrases almost never require punctuation [2]. Gerunds are also distinct from the progressive verb form: in “Singing makes Sara happy,” “singing” is a noun (gerund), whereas in “Sara sings,” “sings” is the main verb [3].

question_en: Why are countries like Iran and Saudi Arabia seemingly unfazed (or otherwise not extremely worried) by the recent drastic drop in oil prices, but Venezuela's economy is quickly becoming one of the worst in the world, due mainly to the same drop in oil?
pos_context_title_en: Venezuela's financial crisis exacerbated by oil price war, coronavirus (www.reuters.com)
Venezuela's financial crisis exacerbated by oil price war, coronavirus (www.reuters.com)
Saudi Arabia To Boost Oil Production To 10 Million Bpd As Prices Rise (oilprice.com)
Saudi Arabia To Boost Oil Production To 10 Million Bpd As Prices Rise (oilprice.com)
Why Does the Middle East Have So Much Oil? - FossilFuel.com (fossilfuel.com)
pos_context_en: A price war between world oil producers has slashed Venezuela’s revenue for its top export and exacerbated the country’s financial crisis as it also faces the coronavirus pandemic, U.S. sanctions and sliding crude output.

More than 90% of Venezuela’s export revenue comes from oil. The country risks generating less than $8 billion this year, a third of $25 billion in 2019, according to Caracas-based economic consultancy Ecoanalitica. Two other local consultants also projected the government will have less than half the funds it managed last year.

Saudi Arabia is expected to hike its crude oil production to 10 million barrels per day (bpd) by the end of 2021, up by 1.5 million bpd from May, due to rising global oil demand, Goldman Sachs said on Tuesday.

The global demand rebound and the strong domestic recovery in oil demand also prompted Goldman to raise its economic growth projections of Saudi Arabia. The U.S. investment bank now sees the Saudi economy rising by 4.5 percent in 2021, compared to an earlier forecast of 2.5 percent growth.

The oil-rich nations in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Syria, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Yemen, and Oman, account for about 3.4 percent of the world’s total land surface. However, these countries contain around 38 percent of the world’s total natural gas reserves and 48 percent of the total known reserves of crude oil (Sorkhabi, 2010). When people think about the Middle East, they think about oil. According to 2020 data from the U.S. Energy Information Administration, around 27 percent of the world’s current oil production is sourced from this region. For as long as fossil fuels have been a primary source of global energy, the Middle East has been one of the world’s foremost oil and gas suppliers. Because of the region’s ability to produce and sell massive quantities of oil and gas, economic development in the Middle East has largely been fueled by the fossil fuel industry.
report_en: Saudi Arabia—and, to a lesser extent, Iran—can weather low oil prices because they have vast, low-cost reserves, large sovereign funds, and, in Saudi Arabia’s case, the ability to quickly raise output to protect market share; Goldman Sachs expects Saudi production to climb to 10 million bpd by late-2021 as demand rebounds, and it still projects 4.5 % GDP growth for the kingdom this year [3].  Middle-Eastern producers collectively control almost half of global crude reserves, giving them long-term leverage and cheaper extraction costs that keep projects profitable even at depressed prices [5].  Venezuela, by contrast, is almost entirely dependent on oil—over 90 % of its export income comes from crude—and a price war has cut that revenue to an estimated <$8 billion in 2020, just one-third of 2019 levels [2].  At the same time, U.S. sanctions and years of declining output have strangled cash flow and access to finance, leaving no fiscal buffer to absorb the shock [1].  Thus, while Gulf producers can lean on scale, reserves, and financial cushions, Venezuela’s heavy reliance on a shrinking, sanction-hit oil sector and its lack of diversified income translate the same price slump into a full-blown economic collapse.
